IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A critical need exists for non-pharmacologic interventions that improve outcomes in patients with chronic autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA). This study will leverage infrastructure and resources from an RO1-funded cohort to longitudinally examine the effects of psychological stress, stress resilience, and mindfulness on RA disease activity and symptom severity. These findings will provide mechanistic targets for mindfulness-based interventions in RA, and inform a pilot randomized controlled trial of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) for improving outcomes among people with chronic autoimmune conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: TGF- ligands represents a diverse array of signaling molecules that have fundamental roles human biology and disease. In this proposal, we will characterize the molecular mechanisms of how ligands signal and how they are regulated. This information will provide mechanistic insight into the structure-function of TGF- ligands, augmenting efforts for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In sub-Saharan Africa, nontyphoidal Salmonella (NTS) serovars Enteritidis and Typhimurium are major causes of invasive bacterial disease in children, and we have developed two promising NTS glycoconjugate vaccine candidates. In this application, I will apply systems vaccinology to uncover predictive molecular signatures of NTS glycoconjugate vaccine responsiveness, and additionally, I will define mechanistic humoral correlates of protection using infant mice (mimicking the target population for NTS vaccines). These findings will inform the development of serological assays to evaluate candidate NTS vaccines in clinical testing, which has implications for the design of upcoming efficacy trials in human infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite ongoing efforts to improve outcomes in heart failure (HF), a leading cause of mortality and elevated healthcare costs, 30-day HF readmission rates remain elevated and a quarter of these are preventable. Community health worker (CHW) care delivery has been shown to improve healthcare outcomes but inefficiency limits its scalability. Implementation of a 30-day digitally-enabled CHW intervention for HF patients may provide support for similar interventions in larger HF/cardiovascular populations by reducing 30-day readmissions and improving patient engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Community pharmacy is an underutilized location for identifying and engaging those who misuse opioid medications. Our highly experienced, interdisciplinary research team proposes the current powered randomized controlled trial across 14 community pharmacies to test the efficacy of the Brief Intervention-Medication Therapy Management intervention (BI-MTM). The establishment of the BI-MTM model will result in a major impact for addressing the opioid epidemic, preventing opioid use disorder and overdose, and safeguarding patient health in a novel community-based service setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current grant proposal uses novel genetically engineered mouse models to investigate how genetic changes in the digestive enzyme chymotrypsin increase susceptibility for pancreatitis, a progressive inflammatory disease of the pancreas. The underlying hypothesis is that chymotrypsin deficiency results in pancreatitis in the context of additional genetic or environmental risk factors. Results from this study can advance the development of novel therapeutic and preventive interventions for acute and chronic pancreatitis in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. cGMP phosphodiesterases (PDE6 family) that are expressed in the rod and cone photoreceptor cells are the key effector enzymes in vision and depend on a specialized chaperone, aryl hydrocarbon receptor-interacting protein-like 1 (AIPL1), and the ubiquitous heat shock protein 90 (HSP90) for their maturation and activity. Mutations in PDE6 and AIPL1 underlie severe retinal diseases in humans, including retinitis pigmentosa, achromatopsia and Leber congenital amaurosis. We aim to elucidate the mechanisms underlying AIPL1/HSP90-assisted maturation of PDE6 to enable development of new therapeutic approaches for treating the visual disorders linked to PDE6 and AIPL1.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The design of new drugs to treat major mental disorders remains challenging and error-prone. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis would benefit from new therapies that prevent the immune system from attacking healthy tissue, without the immune-suppressive side effects of existing treatments. We have shown biomaterial depots deposited in lymph nodes - key tissues that determine how immune responses develop, promote selective tolerance during pre-clinical models of multiple sclerosis. In this project we will determine how these selective effects are induced and maintained across key immune populations - T and B cells - to generate knowledge that contributes to design of effective and selective MS immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis Products (THC,CBD) are widely used by HIV+ individuals; however, interactions between HIV, ART, cannabinoids and the endoCB system are poorly understood. Furthermore, the blood-brain barrier serves as a gatekeeper in regulating the delicate neuronal environment and its dysfunction is considered a hallmark of NeuroHIV. We propose to investigate how cannabis products alter important functions of the BBB (i.e. transport, immunological and physical barriers) and the implications on HIV neuroinflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because developing strategies to directly monitor calcium signaling and neurotransmitter release will significantly advance fundamental knowledge of how neurons communicate with each other. The contribution will be highly significant because dysregulation of Ca2+ signaling is a key early–stage process of neurodegeneration in age-related retinal degenerations, glaucoma, diabetic, and optic neuropathies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma has an unusually high propensity to metastasize to the brain and these brain metastases have extremely poor prognosis and limited treatment options. In the brain microenvironment, melanoma cells are frequently found invading deep into the cortex by traveling along the perivascular surface of blood vessels and this vascular-tropic pattern of growth is associated with poor survival in melanoma patients. The experiments in this proposal will explore the contributions of a perivascular-induced TGFβ-PDGFRβ signaling axis and how this signaling cooperates with PTEN loss to sustain invasion and survival in the brain; insights into these mechanisms provide an opportunity to guide the development of unique vascular-directed strategies to prevent or treat brain metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Treatments for atrial fibrillation, which affects ~6% of Americans who are 65 years of age and older, are limited by the suboptimal efficacy and toxicities of pharmaceuticals and radiofrequency ablation/surgery, and high rates of recurrence. We now apply innovative proximity labeling, novel mouse models, and groundbreaking cryo-EM high-resolution imaging and structural biology studies of the human recombinant RyR2 channel to elucidate mechanisms responsible for atrial arrhythmias and reduced contractility. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to public health and to the NIH mission to discover basic mechanisms underlying human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The correct segregation of the genomic material during cell division is an important process, which is fundamental to life, and any segregation error has severe implications for the organisms. By providing unique and novel information on the spindle structure and function, we will gain a better understanding of the forces and mechanisms involved in the process of chromosome segregation and ultimately healthy mitotic spindles. The data acquired in the frame of this proposal will be valuable to identify new therapeutic approaches and targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) have achieved remarkable progress over the last decade, the dexterity of current brain-controlled bionic hands is limited by a lack of understanding of (1) how posture and forces of the arm and hand are encoded in primary motor cortex and (2) how manual interactions with objects are encoded in primary somatosensory cortex during active control. To fill these gaps, we will characterize the sensorimotor representations of the limb during a variety of prehensile behaviors (reach, grasp, transport) and leverage these results to develop next-generation motor decoding and sensory encoding algorithms for brain-controlled bionic hands.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed resource will continue to provide state-of-the-art facilities with unique capabilities for muscle/fiber diffraction and macromolecular SAXS to the bio-medical and structural biology community. Through our fiber diffraction program, we hope to illuminate the mechanisms behind pathologies such as inherited cardiomyopathies, traumatic brain injury, and cancer metastasis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Approximately 2 billion people worldwide are chronically infected with T. gondii and harbor tissue cysts in their organs and tissues, and thus are at risk of reactivation should their immune system decline. Existing drugs suffer from toxicity, allergic reactions and are unable to eliminate chronic infection. The proposed research will identify new drug candidates for eradicating chronic infection, including within the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We propose novel statistical tools to elucidate the clinical signiﬁcance of prognostic factors in breast cancer survival and to summarize the residual survival time after breast cancer recurrence. Through the application of the proposed methods, we expect to gain new knowledge about the progression of heterogeneous breast cancer, which will lead to better targeted therapies for patients and advances in breast cancer survival. While the proposed research focuses on breast cancer research, the proposed statistical methods will have a broad applicability for other chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project explores a novel mitochondria-derived nucleic acid component in cardiomyocytes, R-loop (termed as mtR-loop) which plays an important role not only for cardiomyocyte function but also for inflammation responses of immune cells after sepsis. This proposal incorporates 3D-epigenomic information to unveil the novel mechanism involved in aberrant pathological mtR-loop accumulation during septic cardiomyopathy and provides proof-of-principle that will enable precise engineering of transcription regulation in cardiovascular medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The majority of HIV infections occur at a mucosal surface, here we focus on oral transmission which is a worldwide issue. Our goal is to identify early interventions influencing oral transmission, utilizing the SIV- macaque model, that results in optimal virologic and immune outcomes. The long-term goal is to identify early therapeutic approaches for HIV infected individuals that improve immunological and disease outcomes following oral transmission, with potential implications for transmission at other mucosal sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adductor laryngeal dystonia (AdLD) is a disorder that causes uncontrolled spasms of the `vocal cords' during speech, causing severe speaking difficulty and a reduction in quality of life. Although the cause of the disorder is not fully understood and there are no treatments for AdLD that produce long-term benefits, our recent findings have discovered that AdLD is associated with a lack of neural inhibition that may be linked to the spasms. The current study builds on these findings to determine if repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is effective for increasing neural inhibition, enhancing voice function and improving quality of life for people with AdLD and other voice disorders or types of dystonias.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses a critical limitation in social communication rehabilitation for adults with traumatic brain injury, namely the lack of practical, valid, and person-centered clinical assessment tools. This project will address this need by integrating rehabilitation and communication theory with stakeholder perspectives to develop, refine, and evaluate the first social communication clinical assessment tools that are short, valid, and guide person-centered treatment. Valid, reliable, and person-centered social communication assessment is the first step to effective communication rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neural encoding for human bipedal walking is largely unknown, and yet is important for understanding the pathophysiology of gait disorders in Parkinson’s disease. Here, we study the neural control of gait in Parkinson’s patients already implanted with a novel neural stimulator that can wirelessly stream brain signals during gait in the laboratory and at home. Our proposal seeks to shed light on the mechanistic role of the motor cortical-basal ganglia network dynamic in regulating human walking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: The U.S. has declared a national public health emergency to combat the current opioid crisis that is causing over 30,000 deaths per year. This project uses new systems genetics approaches, open source genomic data and software, and a new type of hybrid rodent mapping panel to precisely define causal linkages between DNA variation and voluntary oxycodone intake. The results may lead to novel therapeutic targets for treating opioid use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroinvasive herpesviruses are the causative agents of a number of severe diseases including encephalitis, shingles, neonatal infections, and keratitis. The goal of these studies is to develop a working understanding of the unusual multi-step genome delivery mechanism of these viruses that supports their neuroinvasive properties. The long-term goal of this work is the development of advanced resources in the continuing efforts to develop antivirals, vaccines, and viral vectors for repair of in-borne genetic errors and treatment of nervous system associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii is a ubiquitous parasite that chronically infects up to 1/3 of the human population by persistently infecting neurons in the brain. Though asymptomatic in most, this persistence enables the reactivation of T. gondii in patients with acquired immune deficiencies, such as AIDS patients, in whom the infection can be deadly. This work seeks to use stem cell-derived human neurons to develop a molecular understanding of how T. gondii persists in this cell type, ultimately enabling the development of better, curative therapies for those with toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Muscle-generated force is transmitted to tendon across a specialized interface called the myotendinous junction (MTJ). The MTJ is susceptible to injury due to constant exposure of force during physical activity. The objective of this proposal is to identify how the extracellular matrix and mechanical loading establish and maintain the strong linkage between muscle and tendon as this knowledge will be essential for developing therapies to restore functionality to the damaged MTJ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mood and anxiety disorders are frequently associated with aberrant communication between limbic and cognitive neural networks, which may trigger emotional dysregulation. We propose to study small subregions of limbic structures such as the hippocampus and amygdala, using combined structural and functional connectomic analysis and determine how they relate to core symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders. A better understanding of limbic connectomic impairments, and how network organization elements capture differences and commonalities across individuals with mood and anxiety disorders, may provide improved diagnostics and inform more effective treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The liver exhibits significant sexual dimorphism and spatial heterogeneity within the liver lobule in physiological function and disease manifestation. We show that sexual dimorphism in the liver is spatially zonated due to coordinated interaction between local zonation signals including Wnts and systemic sexual dimorphism signals including growth hormone. We propose studies to characterize zonated sexual dimorphism in the liver, determine the mechanisms that drive it, and test whether it controls sex differences in liver response to non- alcoholic fatty liver disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Hearing loss, including deafness, poses obstacles to children's language development and social relationships. This project employs innovative, longitudinal modeling of objectively measured naturalistic behavior to investigate young children's vocal interactions in preschool, and the influence of those interactions on their language development. The project will indicate whether understudied processes of peer- and teacher-influenced language development differ between children with hearing loss and their typically hearing preschool peers over months and years. These efforts will pave the way for classroom-based interventions to enhance the language development of children with hearing loss and other children with language delays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The auditory midbrain (inferior colliculus) is an important auditory integration center whose dysfunction has been associated with a large number of central hearing impairments. Proposed research will increase our understanding of the organization, physiology, and development of local synaptic networks in the inferior colliculus and explore the role of these networks in generating impaired sound processing. Results from this research will help to fill an important knowledge gap about the neuronal circuits that underlie auditory processing and will help to better understand the cause of perceptual hearing impairments that can result from anomalous hearing experiences during childhood including those resulting from otitis media with effusion.

PHR: This project seeks to increase the functional impact of established aphasia treatment by combining the benefits of complementary learning approaches through adaptive timing models. Successful outcomes will show that adaptive computer-based treatments provide a novel way to produce large, durable, and generalizable improvements and will develop the next generation of aphasia-specific timing and learning models. This study has high potential clinical impact as treatment paradigms from this study are clinically feasible and implementable in the near term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Block of nerve conduction using applied electrical signals is a promising approach to control neural activity with myriad potential clinical applications including treatment of pain, diabetes, and heart failure. However, the continued development and clinical translation of electrical nerve block is limited by the lack of selectivity over which specific nerve fibers are blocked. We will design and test novel nerve block waveforms and electrodes that will enable the continued advance of medical device therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This application aims to develop a structured, on-site summer environmental health sciences research program for high school teachers and students from three Indigenous communities in the Northern Plains. High school teacher-student teams will conduct high-quality, locally relevant environmental health sciences research through collaboration with Columbia University and Missouri Breaks Industries Research Inc (MBIRI) researchers that collectively have decades of experience in environmental health sciences research. Through this research as well as through developing professional skills, both for students and teachers, we ultimately aim to enable the participants to pursue research and professional careers in environmental health sciences/STEM, and, ultimately, to contribute to the prevention and control of diseases of environmental origin inclusively and with diverse perspectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment-resistant prostate cancer negatively impacts thousands of men every year, and new therapeutic strategies are urgently needed to improve patient outcomes. This work will evaluate therapeutic opportunities for the long noncoding RNA (lncRNA) SChLAP1, an underexplored driver of aggressive prostate cancer, with the objective of validating drug-like small molecules that inhibit its oncogenic functions. The long-term goal of this work is to yield a precision medicine- based strategy for aggressive and treatment-resistant prostate cancer while helping to establish lncRNA targeting as a therapeutic paradigm in oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Advanced stage ovarian cancer often spreads along currents of abdominal fluid and remains the leading cause of deaths from gynecologic tumors in the US. These currents confer fluid shear stress on ovarian cancer metastases, which changes the molecular characteristics of the tumors and makes them more resistant to chemotherapy. This proposal will develop a light-activatable nanotechnology to improve photoimmunotherapy and overcome fluid shear stress-induced chemoresistance in ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Granulomas are a hallmark of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection; but not all granulomas are successful at eliminating Mtb. This proposal seeks to unravel the differences in local adaptive immune responses between successful (Mtb eliminated) and unsuccessful (Mtb persists) granuloma outcomes in both lung and lymph node tuberculosis. The ultimate goal is to use this knowledge to guide the selection of appropriate antigens to re-elicit a successful response through vaccination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Assisted Reproductive Technologies have helped many couples worldwide to conceive children. However, adverse metabolic and cardiovascular outcomes have been observed, which are associated with ART procedures. Using our advanced model for IVF, this proposal will study reproductive outcomes in offspring induced by ART and the underlying sex specific mechanisms involved. Considering that healthy offspring is one of the main goals of ART, it is critical that these offspring are not wholly dependent upon ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although numerous urinary tract infection (UTI) vaccines have been developed and tested over the past 30 years, no effective vaccine has yet emerged. We recently developed a novel vaccination strategy and formulation that resulted in the complete eradication of uropathogenic bacteria harboring in the bladder of UTI prone mice for the first time. We wish to undertake additional studies in mice to optimize the vaccine delivery method and identify surrogates of vaccine efficacy which will facilitate first-in-man studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The sense of taste allows us to identify nutrients and avoid toxins within food, which is essential to maintain health and homeostasis. Taste dysfunction can lead to malnutrition and a decreased quality of life, but identifying the underlying causes and potential treatments for taste dysfunction is hindered by a limited understanding of how taste receptor cells and peripheral gustatory neurons re-establish connections in the taste bud during taste receptor cell turnover. This proposal seeks to define synaptic partnerships and dynamics during the continual turnover of taste receptor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Caenorhabditis elegans has been a workhorse for gene discovery and pathway analysis, and is the only established system where high-throughput genetic analysis can be conducted in the context of a living multi-cellular organism. The goal of this research is to develop viral vector-based technologies to facilitate large scale genetic screens based on targeted gene overexpression, which would be of wide interest within the C. elegans community and fuel years of genetic discovery across a range of disciplines. Our goals are to achieve targeted gene activation in C. elegans using vesicular stomatitis virus to deliver a single guide RNA (CRISPRa), and to develop Orsay virus as a vector to exogenously deliver genes of interest into C. elegans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The misregulation of proteins involved in gene silencing is proposed to play a causative role in a subset of pediatric gliomas associated with poor prognosis. This research proposal will define the mechanisms of how these proteins affect gene expression to promote tumorigenesis. Findings from our project will facilitate the development of targeted therapies for these clinically challenging tumors that lack effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiac muscle cells have highly specialized pathways to ensure the quality of muscle proteins that are required for contraction. Genetic mutations that impair key proteins in these pathways, are implicated in causing human cardiac muscle weakness resulting in heart failure and premature death. In this proposal, we examine the mechanisms for development of cardiomyopathy by one such mutation, namely R120G in a chaperone protein, alpha-B crystallin (HSPB5), to understand the efficacy of stimulating autophagic pathways for mitochondrial quality control in preventing protein aggregates and cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis is a severely debilitating disease with no disease-modifying treatments. Although it is considered primarily a disease of the elderly, sports-related injuries can lead to post-traumatic osteoarthritis in people of all ages. Molecular mechanisms regulating osteoarthritis are poorly understood, and in this application, we propose in-depth investigations into the development of a calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase family member as a new generation therapeutic target that protects against trauma-induced osteoarthritis, representing a major breakthrough in anti-osteoarthritis treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to public health Cell motility is a fundamental cell behavior that contributes to normal immune system function and is hijacked by cancer cells to spread, and we have developed a simple yet powerful animal model to study cell motility and engulfment (cells eating other cells). Our work has led to a novel understanding of a class of human immunodeficiencies and a novel strategy to improve cancer therapy. The current proposal is to uncover additional molecular mechanisms of cell motility and engulfment for the benefit of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

Maintaining healthy mitochondria can delay the onset and progression of photoreceptor degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE) The COVID-19 pandemic is the most threatening public health challenge in the 21st century – the number of cumulative cases has reached 184.8 million as of July 7, 2021 with 3.996 million deaths (case-fatality rate of 2.2%), making COVID-19 the third leading cause of death in the US in 2020. Before effective measures such as mRNA vaccines are developed, non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are key for effective control; following development, optimal vaccine allocation becomes vital. This research explores novel NPI and vaccine allocation strategies using simulations for controlling COVID-19 and other infectious diseases (pandemic preparedness).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis is the predominant killer of cancer patients. Understanding how tumor cells respond to and evade cancer suppression mechanisms in order to metastasize is essential for the development of therapies that effectively prevent this lethal process. This project aims to characterize the mechanism by which the secreted protein APOE acts via its receptor LRP1 on melanoma cells to inhibit their invasion and metastasis, with potential future applications in therapeutically exploiting this mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The short-term goal of this K99/R00 application is the development of the PI as an independent investigator skilled in the use of participatory systems science and community-engaged approaches to select and adapt an intervention, lung cancer prevention and risk reduction interventions, and intervention development and implementation science. The proposed research will select and adapt an intervention protocol to reduce lung cancer risk among Central Appalachian Kentucky women through a community-engaged process and will pilot test the selected intervention using a two-armed randomized controlled trial. The long-term goal is to reduce lung cancer disparities among Appalachian women and for the PI to become an independent researcher and expert in community-engaged intervention development for cancer risk reduction among Appalachian women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)], the major lipoprotein carrier of oxidized phospholipids, has consistently been implicated as a risk factor for calcific aortic valve disease through human epidemiological and genetic studies. However, the mechanisms by which Lp(a) and its oxidized phospholipids (OxPL) mediate the development and progression of calcific aortic valve disease in vivo are not known. This proposal will fill these gaps in knowledge through comprehensive analysis of aortic valves, including quantitative molecular imaging of calcification, proteomics, and hemodynamics in transgenic mice expressing Lp(a) that bind OxPL and mutant Lp(a) that do not bind OxPL, which are uniquely available only in our laboratory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults experience declining mobility, which leads to diminished quality of life, high health care costs, and thus constitutes a major health care problem. It is unclear what factors lead to mobility decline, but energy production by the mitochondrion is thought to play a role. This longitudinal study utilizes new methodology to measure systemic mitochondrial function in blood cells of older people over time, to understand the role of mitochondrial function in age-associated physical function decline.

PHR: Project Narrative The Mouse Peroxisome Research Resource (MPRR) serves as a central resource for mouse models and monoclonal antibodies for basic and translational research in peroxisome biology. The MPRR is a community-driven resource that enhances basic research to better define the roles peroxisomes play in human health and accelerate preclinical testing of therapeutic hypothesis aimed at developing and implementing improved treatments for peroxisomal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infects nearly all individuals and alters cellular metabolism upon infection of naïve B cells in order to establish a latent memory B cell reservoir and promote tumorigenesis in immune compromised hosts. As such, discerning the mechanisms by which EBV induces metabolic changes is imperative for understanding EBV-mediated tumorigenesis and the impact of metabolism on normal B cell maturation in the germinal center. The proposed studies will further elucidate the role of the viral protein EBNA-LP in remodeling cellular metabolism through transcriptional co-activation of metabolic genes and may ultimately lead to potential therapeutic targets of EBV-related malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Orientia tsutsugamushi is an understudied bacterial pathogen and global health threat that causes scrub typhus, a potentially deadly disease that afflicts at least one million people each year. This project will determine how O. tsutsugamushi virulence factors called Anks modulate immune defense mechanisms. Doing so will expand understanding of how Orientia and similar pathogens manipulate host cell functions to cause disease and may identify novel targets for treating scrub typhus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The Michigan Institute for Clinical and Health Research at the University of Michigan seeks to develop a new postdoctoral T32 training program to prepare early-stage postdoctoral fellows for impactful careers in translational science and research. Trainees receive personalized support for their training needs, multi-level training to enhance their professional networks, communication and dissemination training for diverse audiences, and training in diversity, health equity, and inclusion. The overall objective of this training program is to help form the next generation of investigators that strive to improve the lives of individuals and their communities through translational science and research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE While metal toxicity is broadly toxic to bacteria, how they respond to this toxicity and the order in which they do so remains unknown. This project will explore the effects of copper and zinc overabundance on Streptococcus pneumoniae to elucidate bacterial systems used to respond to metal stress, how the bacteria enact that response, and which systems are targets of metal stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the described research program is to develop new classes of chemical compounds to be screened for efficacy against various diseases. The synthetic approach described in this proposal, which involves a tungsten-activated benzene substrate, is fundamentally different than other known approaches to cyclohexene and cyclohexane compounds, and allows access to new materials with widely diverse shapes that are rich in amines, amides, carboxylic acids, esters, and heterocyclic fragments groups that are ubiquitous in pharmaceutical agents. Access to such compounds improves the chances for the discovery and development of new medicines to improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The genomes of multicellular organisms are utilized distinctly over time and space as cells multiply and specialize during normal development. Understanding this process is of critical biomedical significance, as mis-regulation of the human genome underlies many diseases, including the devastating ability of cancer cells to acquire drug resistance and to metastasize. Identifying the initial steps that poise developmental genes for activation or repression, providing a mechanistic understanding for how regulatory decisions occur, and discovering how cells aberrantly switch state in cancer are all critical goals of our research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative People with immunocompromising conditions, including end stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal transplantation, are at increased risk of developing severe infections. Vaccination is the preferred mode of protection against infections but people with the highest risk of infectious morbidity tend to have poor responses to vaccines. This study will identify actionable inflammatory and/or metabolomic factors and immunogenomic characteristics associated with decreased responses to vaccines in people with ESRD with and without transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which infects immunocompromised people, can communicate among its own populations using a signaling system called quorum sensing. We seek to understand how quorum sensing evolves over time and influences interactions with other microbes, with the idea that these studies will eventually lead to potential new treatments for bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project develops new methods for DEER spectroscopy. DEER is a technique that measures the internal motions of proteins, which are crucial for many molecular-level processes in the human body. The resulting data are essential for understanding the molecular basis of life and disease and for providing the knowledge base necessary to develop new drugs

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Differences between cells determine how they respond when in a new environment or when challenged with a drug. However, quantifying differences between cells and measuring whether and how those differences dictate what cells do is challenging. This proposal describes the development and application of new methods to measure how cell-to-cell differences dictate response to challenges, including drugs used to treat human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A defining feature of cells are membrane bilayers that separate them from their environment and, in human and other eukaryotic cells, delineate intracellular compartments with specialized functions. Here we address the fundamental question how cells make and maintain these membranes. Dysfunction in membrane lipid homeostasis is linked to a number of neurological disorders, including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases, among many others. Our work will inform regarding disease mechanism, prerequisite for the development of therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Errors in cell division have been linked to developmental defects and disease in humans. We take inter- disciplinary approaches to decipher the molecular mechanisms required for accurate cell division. Our findings have the potential to facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies based on targeting cell division and the cytoskeleton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The Center for Clinical and Translational Science (CCTS) and its tristate Partner Network of eleven institutions in the Deep South are dedicated to improving health and advancing health equity in a region disproportionately burdened by chronic diseases. The Center will expand its diverse, highly-trained clinical and translational research workforce, assembling faculty, trainees, clinical research professionals and community stakeholders to create collaborative synergies in clinical and translational science research, to catalyze team science-driven investigation into new therapies and health care delivery paradigms and to enhance the dissemination and implementation of evidence-based knowledge toward health impact. This work will complement and inform translational research efforts to improve public health locally, regionally and beyond as the CCTS remains poised to serve as a national resource for responding to current and future public health emergencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Dissemination and implementation (D&I) science is the study of how to effectively and efficiently spread evidence-based practices and interventions to the people who can benefit from them. It is important to integrate this type of science into the clinical and translational science spectrum because it helps ensure that new treatments and therapies are not just developed, but also effectively implemented and used in real-world settings. This can ultimately lead to improved health outcomes for individuals and communities. This postdoctoral training program will train new scientists in D&I science so we can take better care of people and improve inequities in health and health outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: Alabama;Postdoctoral Fellow;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: CTSA Postdoctoral T32 at the University of Alabama at Birmingham

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will provide spatial and temporal knowledge on how phosphorylation regulates the function and organization of proteins in the cell, which will allow devising approaches to control cellular functions and phenotypes. This research will also provide mechanistic insight on deleterious protein variants. Collectively, this research will be relevant in combating genetic diseases and diseases where signaling malfunctions, including cancer, metabolic, neurological and infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative More than fifty hereditary human diseases are caused by the expansions of simple DNA repeats within individual genes, including such debilitating neurological and neurodegenerative disorders as fragile X syndrome, Huntington’s disease, Friedreich’s ataxia and others. Recently, long-read sequencing revealed massive expansions of simple DNA repeats genome-wide in human cancers. Thus, understanding the unprecedented mechanism responsible for large-scale repeat expansions has broad biomedical implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to improve health care delivery and reduce health care disparities in our geographic region. The Deep South Translational Research Mentored Career Development Program (K12) is a regional partnership of 9 institutions of higher learning (4 academic medical centers), and 2 not-for-profit research organizations. We will train and mentor the next generation of translational researchers and scientists with a primary focus on health outcomes and disparities among diseases disproportionately represented within an area of the southeastern US known as the “Deep South”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Adversity experienced during childhood is associated with an increased risk of developing many of the most common diseases of aging in adulthood, such as obesity, cognitive impairment, and cardiovascular disease. This project will address how DNA methylation contributes to the observed relationship between adverse childhood experiences and adult-onset diseases that involve diverse organ systems, by identifying DNA methylation variation associated with early life adversity in a multi-tissue dataset and determining its functional importance through associations with gene regulation. This project will provide insight into how social determinants of health “get under the skin” to contribute to disparities in age-related disease, with the potential to contribute to the future design of intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Ferroptosis is a form of cell death driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This type of cell death occurs in various human diseases such as neurodegeneration, lung, and kidney disease. Identifying the ways that cells die during ferroptosis will potentially lead to better treatments of these diseases as well as new ways to combat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE  Building upon our successes over the past four years under U19 AG060917 and its ADRD supplement, we have established a highly collaborative research program based on the benefits of team science that transcends across multiple disciplines, including aging, bone biology, metabolism and neuroscience. The fundamental premise is to determine whether the pituitary hormones FSH and LH, which have been solely linked to fertility, can be targeted to treat three diseases of public health magnitude—osteoporosis, obesity and Alzheimer’s disease—that affect millions of aging women and men worldwide. Towards this, we will use our lead therapeutic antibody, MS-Hu6, genetically–engineered mouse models, and a compendium of cutting– edge technologies to understand the underlying biology of pituitary hormone action on bone, body fat and brain and to advance new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Cilia are narrow microtubule-based cell protrusions, which contribute to human health as they possess critical roles in cellular motility and signaling. The assembly of cilia depends on the intraflagellar transport (IFT) motility pathway, which shuttles many ciliary building blocks from the cell body into cilia. This study will investigate how IFT binds to its cargoes and how the transport frequency is regulated; we will also explore alternative, non-IFT routes of protein entry into cilia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial calcium transport proteins regulate important physiological functions, including cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic calcium signaling, and the initiation of cell death. This project will determine their molecular mechanisms and the mechanisms by which small-molecule compounds modulate their activities. The results will advance our molecular understanding of the physiologically crucial mitochondrial calcium transport process, and can provide key information to facilitate the development of new medicines to treat diseases related to abnormal mitochondrial calcium homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The CTSA Postdoctoral T32 at Indiana University will create and retain a diverse trainee workforce in translational research through training in the science of translation. Through this training our trainees will be able to implement principles of team research and process innovation as key elements in their research program. By utilizing the broad scope of programs available at Indiana University, Purdue University, and the University of Notre Dame we will leverage the trainees' existing skills to further their ability to cross system boundaries through team-based research, as well as provide a thorough exploration of career opportunities available to them in translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Severe hypotension and refractory shock are of major importance in critically ill trauma and sepsis patients, but the mechanisms leading to impaired vascular function and vasopressor refractoriness are poorly understood. In this project, we will investigate novel mechanisms by which the functions of key vasopressor receptors are regulated during the cardiovascular stress or “fight-and-flight response”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanism of host CD4+ T cell responses, induced by tumor-specific Tc9 cells, in suppressing the growth of relapsed tumors. We will determine 1) the role and importance of Tc9 cell-induced host CD4+ T cell responses in recognizing and eliminating relapsed tumor cells, and 2) the role and mechanism of IL-24-DC circuit in tumors and tumor draining lymph nodes in eliciting tumor-specific CD4+ T cell responses and preventing the recurrence of tumors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is paradoxically associated with improved survival during sepsis; however, the mechanistic basis for this protection is not understood. This project will investigate alterations in immune cell phenotype, function, and metabolism during sepsis in patients and rodents with underlying obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: The CTSA Predoctoral T32 at the University of Alabama at Birmingham will support the training and advancement of predoctoral PhD and/or MD students in clinical and translational science and communication across the translational spectrum from basic scientists to clinical scientists to population scientists from 11 institutions across Alabama, Louisiana, and Mississippi. The mission of the Deep South Predoc T32 program is to inspire and develop future clinical and translational scientists by immersing trainees of diverse racial, ethnic, gender, disciplinary, and institutional backgrounds in a novel scheme of team science training and peer mentoring to build communication and leadership skills across the translational spectrum. Our long-term aim is to generate well-equipped clinical and translational scientists who continue to work in diverse teams focused on innovative and creative research in the Deep South, a region that is disproportionately affected by health disparities and inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Protein biosynthesis, also known as translation, is a complex multi-step process essential to every cell and is catalyzed by the ribosome. Building on our solid expertise and previous experience in studying the structure and functions of the bacterial ribosome, the modes of action of ribosome-targeting antibiotics, and mechanisms of drug resistance, our future research will proceed in three main directions: (i) elucidating mechanisms of ribosome stalling; (ii) uncovering molecular mechanisms of context-specific action of ribosomal antibiotics; (iii) providing structural bases of antibiotic resistance. The newly gained knowledge will expand our understanding of fundamental aspects of protein synthesis and uncover the molecular mechanism of action of the most basic as well as the newest antibiotics that, in turn, will aid the future development of antibiotics that inhibit growth and possibly kill pathogenic bacteria more potently than the currently available drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells elicit numerous behaviors to maintain the structure and function of tissues during both normal homeostasis and stress. The proposed study leverages the robustness of the Drosophila intestinal epithelium to investigate the principles underlying complex cell behaviors, which contribute to the maintenance of epithelial structure and function. Thus, the proposed study will promote our knowledge of how to keep epithelia healthy and prevent diseases associated with abnormalities in epithelial homeostasis.

PHR: Project Narrative Transmembrane receptors are the major mediators of signaling for cells to communicate with the environment, playing essential roles in many cellular processes. The goal of this research program is to understand the structures and mechanisms of these receptors, paving the way for developing targeted therapies for diseases associated with these receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Recently recognized, long-lived, “memory like” natural killer (NK) cells (lymphocytes of the innate immune system which lyse antibody coated virally infected target cells) generate a more vigorous antibody-dependent cell mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) response compared to their naïve counterparts. The proposed study will lead to development of novel mouse models of ADCC that reflect the situation in humans more accurately. These mouse models can be used for pre-clinical development of monoclonal antibody therapeutics in the public health’s interest for treating cancer and infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will compare the effectiveness of a 6-month Mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) intervention compared to health education in improving blood sugar control in patients with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes. If the proposed study finds that MBSR has a beneficial effect on glucose control, it would support the integration of MBSR as an adjunct intervention for improving blood sugar control in type 2 diabetes. Additionally, MBSR could be adapted for other chronic diseases that have also been linked with increased stress and adverse health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: SUMMARY: This project will define the complete A2A G-protein activation profile at single pathway resolution, investigate A2A signaling in melanoma, and determine if A2A is altered by caffeine. Additionally, it will delineate the anti-melanoma effects of caffeine, providing mechanistic and biomolecular insight to the many epidemiological observations, potentially leading to new therapeutics. This deep mechanistic understanding of A2A signaling in melanoma will also help inform interpretation of ongoing clinical trials with A2A antagonists, and help guide future studies with other GPCRs expressed in melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggression is a prevalent social behavior across vertebrate species, yet, it is a costly behavior with potentially deadly consequence and thus needs to be carefully and properly directed. Patients with certain psychiatric illness are at an increased risk of expressing poorly directed and exaggerated aggression and our difficulty in treating these pathological conditions stems from our ignorance of the neural mechanisms that support properly directed aggression under normal conditions. The proposed project is aimed at elucidating the molecular and circuit mechanisms that support directional aggression through fighting-outcome-based social learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Osteoporosis is a disease of aging that leads to ~2 million fractures and ~$17 billion in healthcare costs annually. Based on key preliminary findings, our proposal aims to translate evidence from rodent studies showing that the sympathetic nervous system is an important regulator of bone metabolism to a simple, cost- effective, and safe approach for osteoporosis prevention. Specifically, we will test whether a commonly used cardiovascular drug, atenolol, can prevent bone loss over 2 years in postmenopausal women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As one of the most successful medical interventions in human history, vaccines elicit antibodies to afford immune protection that has eradicated small pox and all but eradicated polio, diphtheria, tetanus, mumps, and measles from the developed world, transforming public health practices in the process. To explore mechanisms underlying anti-viral antibody responses towards development of sophisticated vaccine strategies to deal with recalcitrant infectious agents, here we will analyze the induction of a highly specialized subset of B lymphocytes, i.e., those producing cytokine IL-27 with pleiotropic functions, by vaccinia virus, which was the small pox vaccine and is currently used as vectors of several vaccines (including the HIV vaccine in clinical trial and a recent SARS-CoV-2 vaccine). We will also address the role of IL-27-producing B cells in optimizing protective anti-viral antibody response and underlying mechanisms, including how such B cells to promote the growth and differentiation of antibody-producing B cells, thereby opening a new avenue of research in the vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative: This project will study organizational principles of brain pathways with a combination of chemical tracing and diffusion MRI. The ultimate goal is to assess and improve the accuracy of diffusion MRI, which is currently the only technique for imaging these pathways non-invasively and studying their role in the healthy and diseased brain in vivo. The unique dataset collected by this project will provide a testbed that can aid the neuroimaging research community in identifying shortcomings of current diffusion MRI analysis techniques and provide guidance towards seeking alternative approaches that overcome these shortcomings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance: Osteoporosis and low bone mass (osteopenia) are estimated to affect 55 percent of the American population over the age of 50, with nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates (NBPs) among the most accessible and least expensive treatments. Given the “crisis in osteoporosis treatment” and the fear of adverse side effects from treatment with NBPs, including atypical femoral fractures (AFFs) and osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), there is an increasing interest in the identification of molecular factors that may mediate the effects of these drugs. This proposal therefore aims to identify and investigate factors that play a role in these drugs' mechanism of action.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Kirrel3 is necessary to form specific types of neural connections called synapses and genetic changes in Kirrel3 are emerging as a risk factor for autism, intellectual disability and, other mental illnesses. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic carriers of hepatitis B virus (HBV) are at high risk of developing liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Our proposed work will explore fundamental aspects of HBV protein translation and genome replication, discover host factors that promote or inhibit HBV infection, and establish a cell culture-based system to inform the development of next-generation HBV antivirals. These efforts will contribute to the ongoing effort to develop new and improved anti-HBV therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will combine proteomic, global genomic, molecular, and informatic approaches to provide broad insights into the molecular mechanisms by which liganded nuclear receptors and signals activate enhancers that can constitute a functional connectome. We will elucidate the roles of previously unsuspected enhancer and promoter complexes that participate in the formation of RNP condensates critical for acute enhancer activation network. Finally, we will harness real time imaging of enhancer activation and interactions with subnuclear architectural structures, combined with single molecule imaging to complement our proteomic and genomic approaches to forge new models of acute and chronic enhancer activation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a major public health problem that is strongly influenced by cigarette smoking and genetic predisposition. Although previous studies have identified genomic regions associated with COPD, the networks of interacting genes and proteins that influence COPD have not been identified. We will use protein-protein interaction data to build biological networks related to COPD susceptibility, which will provide new insights into the biological mechanisms causing COPD and suggest new pathways for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health in its ability to determine the role of motherhood biographies as a key mechanism in explaining health disparities among midlife women, an understudied population. This proposed research will identify the most health-disadvantaged subpopulations of midlife mothers and nonmothers with attention to differences by 1) motherhood characteristics, 2) educational attainment, 3) race-ethnicity and 4) potential mechanisms (e.g., mother-child relationship). In doing so, this proposal will lead to new evidence-based interventions and public policies designed to improve women's health and reduce health disparities in midlife and beyond, a key goal of NIA. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Climate change is one of the most important global problems of our time. The consequences for human health are already being felt, and pulmonary morbidity and mortality are increasingly impacted by wildfires, urban and rural air pollution, altered aero-allergen exposures, the repercussions of severe storms and flooding, the changing patterns and severity of pulmonary infections, and other factors. Our goal is to train students and postdoctoral fellows for cutting edge research in the pulmonary impact of climate change and strategies to mitigate the effects.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The laboratory mouse remains the most powerful model organism for biomedical research due to its shared mammalian physiology and its well-characterized and accessible genome. Advances in DNA sequencing technologies and tools for genetic engineering mean that the laboratory mouse can now be engineered with unprecedented speed and sophistication; such that now, more than ever, scientists are relying on laboratory mice not only for basic research on disease mechanism but also for direct modeling of human genetic mutations in the context of complex mammalian physiology, gene-by-genome interactions and pre-clinical drug testing. The Mutant Mouse Resource and Research Center at The Jackson Laboratory provides a biorepository for these valuable mouse models for the research community and leadership for best practices in mouse genetics, model development, and research reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE STATEMENT The premise of our proposed study is that adipose tissue T cell miRs play a crucial role in diet-induced obesity by regulating crosstalk between adipocytes, T cells and macrophages. We will test an overall hypothesis that T cell miRs-10a, -125b and -1247 are essential for this regulation. These studies are highly innovative in that they are expected to establish how high fat diet (HFD) regulates miRs, obesity-induced chronic inflammation, T cell homeostatic expansion and macrophage function, which together contribute to many pathophysiological consequences of obesity and may constitute a promising therapeutic strategy for obesity and related metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cachexia is a syndrome of muscle and fat wasting that causes reduced quality of life, increased caregiver burden and premature death in patients with many chronic conditions, including congestive heart failure. There are over 6 million people in the United States with heart failure and as many as 1 million of these individuals have cachexia, yet the biologic reasons for this horrific complication are completely unknown. The research proposed in this application aims to narrow this knowledge gap by studying the molecular mechanisms of cardiac cachexia in heart failure with the long-term goal of developing new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for this common and deadly disease complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the NIAAA, in the United States roughly 6% of adults have alcohol use disorder and almost 27% of adults have engaged in binge-drinking in the last month suggesting there is a serious demand for therapies to prevent excessive alcohol consumption. Fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) is a secreted endocrine factor that signals to the brain to decrease alcohol consumption and genetic variation around the loci encoding FGF21 and its receptor, β-klotho, are associated with increased alcohol consumption in humans. Thus, by investigating the mechanism by which FGF21 inhibits alcohol consumption, we aim to discover potential mechanisms driving pathological alcohol consumption while also highlighting potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudouridine is a pre-mRNA modification installed co-transcriptionally by pseudouridine synthases (PUS), which influence splicing regulation. Alternative splicing is important during normal liver function and is rewired in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and expression of multiple disease linked PUSs correlates with poor HCC prognosis. This proposal seeks to elucidate mechanisms of splicing regulation imparted by pseudouridine in HCC cells, which is important for understanding basic cancer biology that could result in new diagnostics, prognostics, and/or therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We study the impact of high shear stress on the aberrant regulation of genes that leads to functional abnormalities causing occlusion of pulmonary arteries in pulmonary arterial hypertension. We build vascular tubular structures to study endothelial interaction with smooth muscle cells under high shear stress, and pursue the genomic and functional sequelae resulting from a reduction in a critical transcription factor, ERG, and how these abnormalities can be corrected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Acute and chronic alloimmune reactions against allografts are the major causes of transplantation rejection. Developing safe and effective immune suppressive treatments to achieve long-term transplantation tolerance has been difficult because we don’t have strategies to specifically intervene with multiple components of the alloimmune reactions without compromising the entire host immune system. Here we will develop an orthogonal vaccine to synthetically bridge the crosstalk between antigen presenting cells and engineered regulatory T cells to simultaneously and specifically suppress alloimmune reactions at both the effector site (allograft) and the priming site (allograft draining lymphoid tissue) for long-term transplantation tolerance.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Malawi HIV integrated treatment and prevention guidelines have recently adopted evidence- based interventions including Dolutegravir based antiretroviral therapy, Pre-Exposure prophylaxis and integrated service delivery but require implementation science research to bring the interventions to scale for maximum impact. The University of North Carolina (UNC), the University of Malawi, College of Medicine (COM), Kamuzu College of Nursing (KCN) and Ministry of Health (MOH) will build upon nearly two decades of experience in HIV training activities and institutional research capacity strengthening in Malawi to expand HIV implementation science skills among research-focused faculty at COM, KCN, MOH and partner affiliates. Our program will develop both investigators and strengthen systems in the COM and KCN to assist the Malawi government to conduct high quality implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After losing a loved one, most older adults are resilient and return to normal functioning within a year; however, in some individuals acute grief becomes intense, protracted, and debilitating, leading to complicated or prolonged grief. This novel study is anticipated to provide evidence that specific abnormalities in the emotion regulation brain circuitry could, in the future, serve as neurobiological indicators of complicated grief. Such biomarkers could also be used to test the efficacies of treatment or prevention strategies that aim to prevent the development of complicated grief in older acutely grieving individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The definition of the clinical target volume in which high doses of radiation are delivered to treat cancer is the weakest link in the radiation therapy chain. It is currently a cumbersome manual process in which a radiation oncologist draws the target contours manually, with many uncertainties involved, leading to a large variability between contours drawn by different physicians. In collaboration with a leading company in radiation treatment planning, we develop a machine learning based approach to define the clinical target volume semi- automatically, which will lead to greater efficiency in defining the clinal target, more consistency, and better treatment plans for the patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Project Viva is a longitudinal cohort study of mothers and their children, originally enrolled during early pregnancy 1999-2002. The wealth of data and bio samples already available in the cohort provide a unique opportunity to continue to study the influence of early-life environmental exposures on development of chronic diseases including obesity, cardiovascular disease, and asthma. The support from this application will help improve the availability of Project Viva data to the wider research community, maintain participants’ engagement in the study, and position Project Viva to continue to examine novel scientific questions into the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The increase in blood pressure, called Hypertension, is the main cause of heart attack, stroke and need of dialysis; however, the causes of this disease are unknown in 90% of the patients. In this proposal, we will explore a potential cause of hypertension that originates in the malfunctioning of small arteries of the kidneys.  We believe that our proposal may explain up to ~20% of the hypertensive individuals and will help to develop new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a major cause of birth defects causing permanent neuronal damage in thousands of infants in the United States every year, and also causes significant disease and death in individuals with weakened immune systems, including transplant recipients and certain cancer patients. New therapeutic options are necessary to block HCMV-associated disease. The immediate goal of our research is to elucidate how HCMV takes control of cellular metabolic resources to ensure successful infection, with the ultimate goal being to use this knowledge to develop novel anti-viral therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall Core: Maier and Zhang) The University of Arizona Superfund Research Program (UA SRP) addresses the unique human health risks arising from exposure to arsenic in the US Southwest, an area with a rich history and future of mining. Here, disadvantaged mining communities experience several routes of arsenic exposure, and Native American communities in particular exhibit increased diabetes prevalence. Our goal is to build a mechanistic model of the contributions of chronic mine waste-arsenic exposure to the development of diabetes and associated metabolic disease to inform risk assessment tools that can be used to predict exposures and associated health outcomes and to inform public health prevention and interventions in communities that neighbor mine waste sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Administrative Core; Maier, Zhang, Ramirez-Andreotta, Isaacs) The primary tasks of the University of Arizona Superfund Research Program Administrative Core include guiding our Center as a whole to define the human and environmental health risks associated with metal mining in arid environments. The Administrative Core also leads our Center in the development of innovative, cost-effective, long-term, evidence-based solutions that will effect change in the current mining industry practices and ensure the protection of human health and the environment. The final task of the Administrative Core is to coordinate the communication of Center findings to our stakeholders including NIEHS, our sister Superfund Programs, Federal, State, and Tribal regulatory agencies, the mining industry, and affected communities.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL COMPONENT  The “Squirrel Monkey Breeding and Research Resource” (SMBRR) maintains the only self-sustaining national research resource of laboratory-born squirrel monkeys, their tissues and other biological materials, as well as the expertise to carry out research on this important research animal. Scientists with NIH grants utilize squirrel monkeys to study many diseases that threaten human health including Alzheimer's disease and other disorders of the central nervous system, drug addiction, malaria, and viral diseases. The definition and quality of the SMBRR's resources have reduced the number of squirrel monkeys needed, and in some cases, biomaterials from the SMBRR have reduced or eliminated the need for living animals to accomplish research goals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Data Management and Analysis Core: Aikseng Ooi and Nirav Merchant)  Understanding the roles of arsenic in complex diseases like diabetes requires an integrated approach that  combines vast quantities of information from multiple fields, including biomedical science, geology, and  environmental science. The Data Management and Analysis Core serves as the primary storage and analytical  service for the data generated from various experiments investigating arsenic toxicity. DMAC builds upon the  CyVerse infrastructure and utilizes state-of-the-art hardware, software, and analytics to merge the findings of  various scientific disciplines into new multifaceted insights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many babyboomers who began using cannabis as young people, and who have continued use for years, are now entering later life, and NIA and NIDA have called for research on the implications of cannabis use for the health and well-being of this group of adolescent-onset persistent-to-midlife cannabis users. The project will generate new evidence about the impact of life-long use of cannabis on cognitive reserves, neural reserves, financial reserves, epigenetic- maintenance reserves, the biological aging process, and on potential risk for disease, including Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders. The proposed work will yield the first comprehensive portrait of how well midlife long-term cannabis users are prepared for old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Community Engagement Core: Chief, Rainie, Maier)  The University of Arizona Superfund Research Program (UA SRP) Community Engagement Core (CEC) will  utilize community-based participatory research to address increased exposure to arsenic and the impact of  exposure on metabolic diseases, particularly diabetes risk, in Native American communities living near mining  sites. Recent evidence suggests that Native American communities are disproportionately impacted by mining  and arsenic contaminated water, resulting in increased rates of diabetes in Native Americans. The tools  developed by the UA SRP CEC will be used for multi-lateral communications with Native American communities  to enable these vulnerable populations to make informed decisions on health issues related to mining, arsenic  contamination, and remediation efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the population ages, identifying the patients with heart disease who will benefit most from more aggressive treatment, and which others might do better with more conservative care, is critically important to improving public health. In this proposal, we will combine different data sources for patients who underwent aortic valve replacement or coronary artery stent procedures to determine whether and how frail elderly patients should be treated differently than non-frail patients. Using this information, we will develop and implement tools that can help patients and their clinicians select treatment strategies that are most aligned with their preferences and appropriate for their health condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic diseases, such as diabetes and obesity, are costly chronic diseases and affect millions of individuals in the USA leading to significant morbidity and mortality. By using experimental mouse models and in vitro cellular assays, we will determine the mechanisms by which a G-protein coupled receptor in gastrointestinal tissue regulates energy and glucose homeostasis. This study will shed a light into the molecular pathways that mediate nutrient sensing and hormone secretion in the gut, which may provide therapeutic potentials to treat diabetes and obesity.
