IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  We have limited structural information on membrane proteins and channels, but they play an important part in numerous biomedical diseases such as heart disease and cancer. New biophysical tools are urgently needed to study membrane proteins. The research discussed in this MIRA R35 application will develop new biophysical methods for studying the structural and dynamic properties of integral membrane proteins and channels. We will also apply these methods to probe the structure of several different biological systems.  We will focus on investigating the structural and dynamic properties of integral membrane proteins in the KCNE family which is responsible for the modulation of voltage gated potassium (Kv) channels including KCNQ1 (Q1). This channel is expressed throughout the body to regulate physiological functions and mutations in this channel are linked to several diseases such as Long QT syndrome and other heart diseases. Increased understanding of the molecular underpinnings of KCNE modulation of potassium channels, specifically Q1, would help expand our understanding of the etiology of these diseases. We will study three members of the KCNE family: KCNE1(E1), KCNE3(E3), and KCNE4(E4). When E1 forms a complex with Q1, it causes the activation kinetics of the channel to slow, giving rise to the slow-delayed rectifier potassium channel, IKs, which is crucial to the repolarization of cardiac action potential. E3 forms a complex with Kv channels that are voltage-independent under physiological ranges. Q1/E3 channels are important for cardiac action potentials and transport of nutrients across epithelial cells. A major gap in our understanding of E3 is due to limited structural information. E4 has been shown to inhibit current in Kv channels, including Q1. Previously, the role of E4’s tetraleucine motif has been tied to its inhibitory effects and interaction with Kv channels. It is currently not understood how the tetraleucine motif drives protein-protein interactions and how this leads to changes in the structure of E4 Presently, E3 and E4 are being studied in the Lorigan lab to provide knowledge regarding structure, topology, and dynamics which can lead to better molecular level understanding as previously done with E1.  Over the next five years, we will: (1) Develop new biophysical techniques to dramatically improve structural studies of membrane proteins, (2) Probe the structural and dynamic properties of E3, and E4, (3) Elucidate the binding mechanism of E1 and Q1 to help us better understand the mechanism of Q1 regulation, and (4) Apply the membrane protein techniques that we develop to investigate the structure of several biologically important integral membrane proteins (S2E Coronavirus Envelope Protein, Canonical Holin, TRPV1, and Grp94) using pulsed EPR spectroscopy. The TRPV1, and GRP94 projects will be done via collaboration. Each lab will send us samples for pulsed EPR measurements. Transformative biophysical techniques will be developed to study the structural and dynamic properties of membrane proteins. These state-of-the-art pulsed EPR spectroscopic techniques will move the field forward by dramatically increasing sensitivity and distance measurements of membrane protein systems such as E3 and E4. Also, a new polymer-based membrane mimetic system will be developed that will enable researchers to more easily conduct structural and functional measurements of membrane proteins in a lipid bilayer. The size of the SMALPs can be fine-tuned by the polymer to match the size of the membrane protein complex. The state-of-the-art pulse EPR techniques, unique spin labels, and our powerful SMALPs membrane systems will dramatically improve our ability to study the structure and dynamics of a wide variety of different membrane protein complexes of various sizes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Copper is an essential trace metal required by mitochondria to produce energy from the food we eat. Genetic defects in copper transport to mitochondria result in debilitating and often fatal pediatric disorders for which no approved treatment is available. In the proposed research, we seek to build on our recent discoveries in copper trafficking to mitochondrial energy-generating machinery and leverage this information to discover copper- transporting drugs with therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Eukaryotic genomes are partitioned into distinct functional domains by chromatin modifications. This project will investigate the Polycomb Group chromatin modification system and will generate information about the control and function of Polycomb Repressive Complex 2, a conserved histone methyltransferase that is mutated or dysfunctional in human Weaver syndrome and multiple cancer types. This work will ultimately facilitate development of new tools to prevent, diagnose and treat cancer and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The selective transformation of small molecules by naturally occurring proteins known as enzymes produces important products that have far-ranging roles in biological function from signaling pathways to fighting disease. Medicinal chemistry would benefit from having the same tools to selectively transform small molecules for the creation of therapeutic drugs. This project seeks to use computational modeling techniques to increase the fundamental mechanistic understanding of how enzymes enable selective transformations and to improve the rational approaches that can be used to mimic natural enzymes in medicinal chemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (relevance to public health) Understanding the physiological responses of human pathogens such as Vibrio cholera and Pseudomonas aeruginosa to environmental and genetic perturbations and connecting these responses to underlying gene regulatory controls will potentially open up treatment strategies at a systems level. Elucidating adaptive strategies to the inhibitory effects of SCFA on bacterial growth will provide valuable input to the rationale design of probiotics, to endow them with unique fitness advantages in the gut environment so that they can outcompete the undesirable pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Voltage-gated proton channel are proteins that help white blood cells kill bacteria, sperm fertilize eggs, and heart muscle remain healthy. But their abnormal function can promote leukemia, breast cancer metastasis, autoimmune diseases, and brain damage in stroke. By discovering how proton channels work, and which of their parts are important, this project will enable designing drugs to control their activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Even though the ribosome has evolved to make all the cellular proteins, synthesis of specific polypeptides can be problematic. Cells produce special accessory factors to assist the ribosome in synthesizing the difficult- to-make proteins, but how these factors work and when their help is needed is unknown. Finding the functions of the molecular aids of the ribosome will advance our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of protein synthesis and provide foundation for developing new medicines and treating diseases related to faulty protein expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We combine structural, biophysical, and biochemical techniques to probe the relationships between macromolecular structure, dynamics, and function. We are particularly interested in studying these relationships in large protein-nucleic acid complexes involved in biological processes such as DNA damage repair and mRNA cleavage and polyadenylation. Through the characterization of the three-dimensional structures, protein motions, and biological functions for such protein complexes, our research program will encourage a richer appreciation for how these complexes function in the cell and how alterations in structure and/or dynamics from mutation could lead to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2 is transitioning from pandemic status to becoming an endemic virus, like influenza, and seasonal vaccinations will likely become the primary method for limiting disease. Despite the overall effectiveness of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2, some people are at increased risk of not developing protective immunity, most notably immunocompromised populations such as solid organ transplant recipients on life-long immunosuppressive medications. This research aims to determine how immune dysregulation before vaccination, driven by differences in mycophenolate mofetil immunosuppressive treatment, impacts the development and long-term maintenance of protective immunity against SARS-CoV-2, and ultimately how this dysregulation can be corrected to improve responses to vaccination in this and other at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Improving our knowledge of the structure and mechanisms of human and herpesvirus DNA replication machineries have tremendous significance for the future of medicine. Structure-based design of anticancer compounds targeting human DNA replication is underway, and the data generated by Project 1 will enable the development of drugs selective to viral, bacterial, and potentially yeast polymerases—but not human proteins. Successful completion of Project 2 will foster the discovery of novel medicines for treating a wide range of diseases caused by human herpesvirus and will also facilitate finding solutions to address the problem of drug resistance in these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: The T32 postdoctoral training program of the Scripps Research CTSA aims to establish a new generation of early career scientists capable of bridging science and medicine in the context of a rapidly changing world of healthcare and emerging diseases. Basic science, elucidation of mechanisms of diseases, discovery of new therapeutic approaches and drugs, and digital monitoring of health are primary areas of investigation for our members. In addition, an important component of citizenship is included in our training to promote three important core competencies: (i) mentorship, (ii) inclusion of all groups regardless of gender, racial, and cultural backgrounds, and (iii) community engagement.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall Tulane National Primate Research Center (TNPRC) has one of the largest specific pathogen free (SPF) rhesus monkey breeding colonies in the US, a resource that has provided animals for NIH funded research projects for several decades and is a critical component of the Center's successful research program. Over half of all research projects at TNPRC are initiated by outside investigators, making this resource essential to the success of many NIH-funded researchers across the country. Experienced leadership and significant infrastructure investment, combined with proven techniques in breeding colony management, ensure continued responsible stewardship of this nationally recognized resource.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most common human diseases are difficult to study because they are genetically complex. Conducting human genetic studies that include enough subjects with sufficiently detailed data to make definitive conclusions remains challenging, despite significant advances in genome technologies (e.g. DNA sequencing and editing). Most of these obstacles can be overcome by using standardized, genetically diverse laboratory mice, which offer known and reproducible genetic and phenotypic variation. The goal of the Special Mouse Strain Resource at The Jackson Laboratory is to: i) maintain and distribute these unique mouse populations to the biomedical research community, ii) further develop advanced resources for systems genetics and, iii) to provide leadership in best practices for research and reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial pneumonia leads to an uncontrolled response of the immune system that frequently causes lung injury/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The molecular mechanism by which macrophages resolve infection-associated injury in the lung is not fully understood. Our research is aimed to support the novel concept that TRPV4 integrates the mechanical properties of the matrix and infectious signals to drive macrophage activation functions to protect the lung from injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Narrative Transcutaneous vagal stimulation is an emerging, promising modality for atrial fibrillation, yet patient selection and stimulation parameters have not been optimized. This proposal will address these unmet needs by aiming to optimize the stimulation parameters of transcutaneous vagal stimulation and guide selection of the ideal candidates for this novel noninvasive therapy for atrial fibrillation, using physiological and biochemical biomarkers. By introducing an optimized treatment protocol for transcutaneous vagal stimulation, this approach has the potential to impact clinical practice and improve outcomes among a large number of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dendritic cells (DCs) play key roles in orchestrating immunity to pathogens. Multiple subsets of functionally specialized DCs exist, but DC function can also be modulated by microbial and tissue-derived stimuli. We have recently demonstrated a major role for the metabolic sensors mTOR and GCN2 in regulating DC development and function, and the underlying mechanisms of this “metabolic imprinting” will be explored.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Paget’s Disease (PD) is a common bone disease, characterized by highly localized pagetic bone lesions (PDLs) that result from local increases in bone destruction, followed by rapid formation of bone that is of poor quality. However, the mechanisms responsible for the highly focal nature of PDLs, why PD is diagnosed in elderly patients and why the lesions persist for long periods are unclear. This proposal will determine the role of osteocytes, a type of bone cell that comprises 95% of the bone cells in the adult skeleton and can persist for decades, in the development of PD and PDLs, which is currently is unknown.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative Macrophages are crucial for the recovery from acute inflammation, however, the mechanisms that modulate macrophage function during this process remain unclear. This proposal tests the hypothesis that the induction of miR-147 in macrophages represents an endogenous protective pathway to control lung inflammation through suppression of its target NDUFA4. Our proposal addresses the urgent need to understand the mechanism of macrophage-mediated control of lung inflammation and facilitates the development of new therapeutic targets for acute respiratory distress syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: We have recently identified the Notch pathway as an important regulator of stem cell maintenance and differentiation. The goal of this study is to use Notch signaling to enhance expansion of bone marrow derived mesenchymal stromal cell (MSC) and subsequent MSC sheet-mediated allograft healing. Data generated by this proposal will likely 1) identify optimized cell populations for generating tissue engineered periosteum (next generation MSC sheets), 2) develop a novel therapeutic approach to enhance the repair of massive devitalized bone allograft and lead to advances in treatments that affects the lives of patients with large bone defects, and 3) pave the path for large pre-clinical animal studies and subsequent clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Sepsis affects millions and kills hundreds of thousands of Americans annually. Currently, no therapy exists to stabilize the deleterious response of the host to invasive infection. In this application, we propose to conduct research on a molecular pathway that appears to be highly promising for enabling clinicians to individualize treatment decisions in the intensive care unit. This project proposes new ways of understanding genetic risk factors in the Tie2 pathway and their influence on the wide spectrum of sepsis manifestations in order to move our community closer to the promise of personalized medicine in the intensive care unit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Filarial nematodes from the family Onchocercidae, including Brugia malayi, cause the devastating human filarial diseases, elephantiasis and river blindness. These nematodes can only cause disease in humans if they are also infected by a bacterium, Wolbachia pipientis. Understanding mechanisms of Wolbachia survival within these nematodes can provide new information towards the treatment of human filarial diseases and a fundamental understanding of pathogenic nematode biology.

PHR: Project Narrative This R24 resource grant builds upon our existing infrastructure to develop the 96 strain Hybrid Rat Diversity Panel (HRDP) to be used to broadly study disease mechanisms, the impact of the environment, and for therapeutic drug development. In addition, the HRDP provides a genetically stable population that can be reused and renewed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Circadian clocks impact nearly every aspect of our health, and their chronic disruption by working on a rotating shift schedule can cause a variety of diseases, including obesity. New findings indicate that the mechanisms involved are highly sex-specific and contribute broadly to the overt biological differences between males and females. The experiments proposed in our application seek to identify these novel circadian clock mechanisms.

PHR: NARRATIVE Proposed project investigates how DNA regions of key genes inherited from the mother and father interact with each other to regulate gene expression in stem cells. Disruption of such process causes multiple human diseases, including cancer and tissue degeneration, and our findings will contribute to understanding these pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell migration is an important process that occurs in many physiological and pathophysiological contexts, including embryogenesis, inflammation, wound healing and tumor metastasis. Our published and preliminary data indicate a previously unrecognized role for contacts between the endoplasmic reticulum and the plasma membrane in the migration of metastatic cells. This project seeks to understand the mechanisms by which calcium influx and lipid transfer are coordinated at these sites, and how they regulate cell motility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The clinical and financial burden of aortic stenosis (AS) in the United States (US) is high with ~780,000 patients >60 years of age suffering from severe AS. Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) has emerged as a safe and effective therapeutic option for patients with symptomatic severe AS with >50,000 TAVRs now being performed annually across >500 hospitals in the US. This study will enable us to identify practices and processes of care associated with lower rates of death, complications, and readmissions after TAVR at top-performing hospitals, with the hope to share these ‘best practices’ across all hospitals in the US to improve outcomes of patients with severe AS undergoing TAVR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Autonomous aldosterone production from one or both adrenal glands (primary aldosteronism, PA) leads to hypertension, low potassium and, if not recognized and appropriately treated, serious cardiac and renal complications. The current methods to diagnose and guide treatment of PA are complicated, invasive (adrenal vein sampling) and reliant on referral centers. The proposed research aims to implement comprehensive histologic, genomic and steroid profiling analyses to develop a simple peripheral blood test which would accurately distinguish between PA forms (uni- vs. bilateral) and other causes of hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Respiratory failure is the most common cause of death in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which is a variably progressive neurologic disease without a known cure. Using a previously developed prediction model for respiratory failure, the current research will identify patients at high risk of respiratory failure upon diagnosis, will gather patient input on respiratory care early in disease, and will perform a small trial of a pulmonary exercise in patients at high risk of respiratory failure. This work will set the stage for larger trials of early respiratory therapies on high-risk patients, so that we may develop a personalized approach to treating respiratory failure in ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 antiviral therapy must be taken continuously to prevent viral rebound due to the presence of a latent viral reservoir. We have found that the initiation of antiviral therapy changes the environment within the host to promote the formation of a large majority of the latent reservoir at this time. The proposed studies will extend these observations to examine other forms of the latent reservoir and to explore the stability of the reservoir after the return of an inflammatory state. We will also examine the differentiation state of the cells that are carrying the latent virus before and after therapy. Collectively these studies will provide a framework for developing new strategies to inhibit the formation of that part of the viral reservoir that forms during therapy initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart rhythm disorder, with a 25% lifetime risk of developing atrial fibrillation once an individual reaches the age of 40 years. Obesity, a very prevalent condition, and epicardial adipose tissue are associated with atrial fibrillation and may be involved in the pathogenesis of the atrial substrate leading to atrial fibrillation; importantly, weight loss improves treatment for atrial fibrillation. This study will assess the proteomic, transcriptomic, and metabolomic features linking epicardial adipose tissue to atrial fibrillation, in order to identify new targets for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memory deficits are a common complication from the surgical resection or ablation of the hippocampus in the treatment of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE). Modern surgical techniques allow very precise targeting of the hippocampus, but clinicians need better tools to preview the postoperative memory deficits at this same precision. We will examine whether electrical stimulation through stereoelectroencephalography (SEEG) electrodes placed in the hippocampus, a procedure already required for some patients with MTLE, can generate memory deficits and thus be of clinical use to preview the effect of resecting more precise volumes of tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Many children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) have enlarged dorsal striatum and striatal-dependent learning problems, which may be central to clinically significant impairments. Prenatal stress is a risk factor for ASD; translatable targets for prevention and intervention of ASD are goals of studying prenatal stress in model systems. We will study a novel mechanism—increased striatal neuron generation—in mouse models of prenatal stress, test its importance for striatal growth and striatal-dependent learning, and examine its regulation by prenatal maternal and placental mechanisms which we and others have implicated in prenatal stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Members of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily (TNFRSF) regulate proliferation of immune cells or induce programmed cell death, and many of them are candidates for antibody-based immunotherapy, e.g., antagonists of TNFR1/2 and CD40 for treating autoimmune and agonists of OX40 and 4-1BB in cancer immunotherapy. Recently, we made an unexpected finding that, for a few members of the TNFRSF, there is a defined auto-inhibitory state that keeps the receptor inactive in the absence of ligand. The proposed research aims to investigate the general applicability of this finding and its mechanistic basis, while developing new antibodies that specifically modulate the auto-inhibitory state for potential treatment of autoimmune diseases and/or cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this application are to investigate the enzymes involved in the production of unusual dideoxysugars found on the lipopolysaccharides of pathogenic Gram-negative bacteria, to study the enzymes required for the biosynthesis of the O-methyl phosphoramidate modification observed in bacterial capsular polysaccharides, and to examine the enzymes needed for the construction of the nonulosonic acids observed in bacterial surface polysaccharides. The components of this application are linked together in that both unusual sugars and modifications thereof play key roles in bacterial invasion and serum resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This series of studies will contribute to a better understanding of how the brain learns the articulatory movements involved in speech production and how it remains able to adjust those movements based on hearing our own speech sounds. The knowledge gained from this work will make it possible to improve theoretical models of the processes involved in speech sensorimotor learning and to pursue new directions of research on the etiology of developmental speech disorders in which sensorimotor learning may be impaired. In addition, the research findings will suggest innovative techniques for treating speech disorders in children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Alpha thalassemia (AT) is a disease that affects hemoglobin production; while patients with severe forms of AT require chronic transfusions or a stem cell transplant, there are currently no gene therapy strategies for them, indicating a major unmet medical need. In this proposal, we will design and test three complementary gene therapy or editing strategies that will either result in restoration of alpha globin production, or persistence of embryonic zeta globin production. At the end of these experiments, we expect to have generated substantial pre-clinical data that may be developed into an IND with the FDA for an innovative first-in-human phase I/II clinical trial for ex vivo correction of HSCs from patients with AT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative T cells are key players in immune responses that are essential to protect the host against a variety of pathogens and cancers. In some cases, their uncontrolled activity can also lead to pathologies such as inflammatory or autoimmune diseases. It is thus essential to understand the mechanisms underlying their activation and regulation. This activation is mediated by the T cell receptor, which when triggered, leads to a cascade of intracellular events involving several molecules. In this proposal we will investigate how the molecule, THEMIS and the mechanisms it employs, regulate the function of T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Although the viruses of bacteria and archaea (phage) are touted to be the most abundant organisms on Earth and research with bacteriophage has played and continues to play a central role in the development of molecular biology and biotechnology, there remain fundamental unanswered questions about the evolution of these viruses and their contribution to the ecology and evolution of their hosts. The proposed jointly theoretical and experimental study of the population biology and evolution of bacteriophage will address and answer three classes of questions: 1- Existence conditions; under what conditions will phage be maintained and regulate the densities of these host populations? 2- Horizontal versus vertical transmission: under what conditions will natural selection favor the evolution and maintenance of a lysogenic rather than a purely lytic mode of phage replication? 3- The evolution and maintenance of adaptive immunity: under what conditions will selection mediated by virulent and temperate phage lead to the evolution of and maintenance of CRISPR-Cas - mediated adaptive immunity? !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We are studying an organism in which a natural transplantation reaction mediates the transmission of stem cells between two individuals, which then compete to contribute to regeneration. Our studies will continue to provide novel insights into the mechanisms which underlie these diverse processes, and have major significance, from preventing a rejection reaction after transplantation, to understanding how cancer cells outcompete normal cells for resources and growth. In the organism we study, the interaction between transplantation and stem cells in many ways resembles how humans accept or reject bone marrow transplants, but in a simplified fashion that provides opportunities for novel approaches to study these questions that cannot be done in other species.

PROJECT_TITLE: Allorecognition, parasitic stem cells and regeneration in a basal chordate

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project examines the phytochromes, a superfamily of photoreceptors that can detect to a broad range of colors and can transmit that information to the cell to control many aspects of biology. Plant phytochromes are a major stumbling block in improving agricultural yield by mediating the shade avoidance response caused by competition for light among neighboring plants, while their bacterial relatives have proven a valuable source of imaging reagents for biomedical research and of photosensory reagents for synthetic control of cellular processes with light. Work under this project will provide new insight into color tuning, the usage of light energy, the integration of light with signals such as temperature and pH, and the transmission of information within these photoreceptors and to the rest of the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overdose deaths involving cocaine continue to escalate while cocaine use disorder continues to present a disturbing chronic health problem and a heavy individual and societal burden in the United States. Medications to promote the success of psychosocial treatment are needed to mitigate these harms to human health. Our preclinical research focuses on neural pathways and druggable targets that impact the “final common pathway” for drug-seeking and the results of this research will inform not only the addiction-related biology of the brain but will ultimately chart the course to new therapeutics for treatment of cocaine use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signals communicating the need to maintain balanced blood production and aged blood cell removal must be correctly conveyed to the marrow's hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and covey proper blood cell removal signals. These molecular mechanisms are intensely studied to provide new insight into the potential for novel therapeutic approaches in blood disorders, specifically affecting platelet and red blood cell counts. The proposed work will yield a transformative understanding of how liver-produced factors contribute to maintaining red blood cell production in the bone marrow at a steady state and provide new insight into novel therapeutic approaches for patients with blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Extensively use of glucocorticoids is a major risk factor for fracture and delayed fracture healing. Given the current COVID infection rate in the US population and the significant number of COVID patients who needed glucocorticoid treatment, a post pandemic surge of fracture and delayed fracture healing is widely anticipated. Except surgical intervention, there is few FDA approved therapy for glucocorticoid-induced delayed fracture healing at present. To address this urgent unmet need, we seek to develop a novel thermoresponsive macromolecular prodrug of Tanshinone IIA (ProGel-TAN) as a highly effective and safe treatment of glucocorticoid-induced delayed fracture healing in this project.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Th goal of this project is to develop and validate a transgenic large animal model of Dravet syndrome in which the role of seizures and cardiac arrhythmias in sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) can be investigated. Rabbits more closely replicate the human cardiac action potential compared to mice and provide a complete organism to translate to the clinical setting. If validated, this work will be a significant advance over currently available Dravet syndrome models and will better inform the translatability of neuro-cardiac mechanisms of SUDEP to human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to design, test, and validate an interpretable, trustworthy, and generalizable ML architecture that leverages magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to estimate brain age accurately. Our efforts will map neuro- anatomic features of MRI-predicted brain ages that reflect accelerated aging observed in mild cognitive impair- ment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We will synergize our interpretable ML approaches with genome- wide association (GWAS) to (A) find genes associated with the neuroanatomic features in question, (B) identify genetic factors acting on brain aging features that predict MCI/AD diagnosis, and (C) develop and validate a polygenic risk score (PRS) of vulnerability to accelerated brain aging observed in MCI/AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative A three-tiered approach is being implemented at the University of Texas at Arlington to transform our biomedical engineering design experience through a program that will facilitate team-based hands-on experiential learning and mentorship that spans the undergraduate degree plan. We will specifically implement new components of a team service-learning design course at the sophomore level, a summer clinical immersion program with local hospitals and emergency medical services at the junior level, and a team-centered workshop led by local industry experts on the translation and commercialization of medical devices to augment the senior design experience. Through these enhancements to our program, we target the development of fundamental skills to prepare our engineering students for serving in the biomedical workforce and entrepreneurship in the biomedical industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Down syndrome (DS) is one of the most common genetic disorders with a prevalence of 1 per 700 liveborn infants in the United States and is associated with an increased risk of developing cerebrovascular disorders (CeVD), which commonly present with stroke as the first evidence of disease. The proposed research will result in the creation of a validated, non-invasive, low-cost, biometric screening tool for young persons with DS in order to address the pressing need of reliable screening of CeVD in at-risk individuals. This proposal presents a five-year research career development program with training that will position me with a unique set of interdisciplinary skills to enable transition to independence as a physician-scientist to study the prediction and prevention of CeVD in persons with DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The studies in this project will explore the therapeutic potential of targeting KDSR, a metabolic enzyme which we hypothesize plays and important role in preventing buildup of a toxic metabolite (3KDS) in multiple subtypes of cancer cells such as triple negative breast cancer cells. This toxic metabolite may be produced in higher levels in cancer cells compared to normal cells and tissues, making this a potentially cancer-selective therapy. We will identify the factors that produce this toxic metabolite in cancer cells and compare/contrast their activities in cancer cells versus normal cells. These efforts will help us develop effective strategies around this new target, such as how to identify the cancer subtypes that would respond well, and what toxicities to normal cells to be aware of.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a severe lung disease in premature infants characterized by abnormalities in blood vessel and air sac development. How endothelial cells regulate formation of blood vessels and air sacs during lung development, and how this is disrupted in infants with BPD is not fully understood. In this proposal, we will study how delta like 4, an endothelial molecule, regulates blood vessel and air sac formation during normal and abnormal (BPD) lung development to identify new therapies for BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The regulatory interface between the genome and epigenome is inherently important across biological systems and disease states due to its control of gene expression, among other fundamental cellular processes. Yet because this interface is highly dynamic and varies depending on genomic locus, it is difficult to probe and control in direct ways and could have consequences for the accuracy of genome and epigenome editing. Here we propose multiple parallel approaches to engineer proteins that can bind DNA modifications in a genomic sequence-specific manner.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): The proposed research and career development plans are relevant to public health because Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) affects nearly a quarter of adults in the United States who drink alcohol, leading to 88,000 deaths, crime, and $249 billion in costs per year. This proposed project is relevant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need for the development of innovative methods to manage infections associated with cardiovascular implantable electronic devices (CIEDs). Within this project, 21MedTech is developing a novel bioresorbable envelope that releases a controlled amount of antibiotics over time to reduce CIED associated infections. Success with these goals and FDA clearance will enable release of an innovative product that will improve morbidity and mortality outcomes in patients with CIEDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Our perception and enjoyment of food is often described in terms of “flavor”, which involves the interplay between taste and aroma (smell). However, we have surprisingly little scientific insight into how the brain creates the multisensory experience of flavor. Here we take a unique approach to this issue, tracking brain activity of animals from birth to adulthood to uncover how the foods they eat shape their flavor processing system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (or lupus) is a chronic, often debilitating autoimmune disease that attacks a number of parts of the body. Damage to the kidneys (lupus nephritis) is a serious and common complication of lupus, affecting approximately 50% of patients, and current treatments are only partially effective and have serious side effects. Our proposal focuses on novel mechanisms of kidney injury in lupus: iron-induced inflammation, fibrosis and cell death (ferroptosis). Our studies will help us better understand a novel mechanism of renal injury in lupus, and whether blocking these processes could serve as a new or complementary treatment strategy for lupus nephritis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Neuroscience Postbaccalaureate Research Education Program (NeuroPREP) will contribute to national efforts aiming to address these systemic problems by increasing access for UR students to graduate training in Neuroscience. We will build regional networks of Schools to identify, recruit and foster program participation from students who currently lack access to in-depth research experiences. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children who experience early life adversity are often more sensitive to stress later in life, which can more easily lead to anxiety disorders and depression. This work seeks to identify how early experiences become encoded in the brain through changes in the three-dimensional structure of DNA. We will develop novel molecular tools to test how these structural changes may render the brain more sensitive to future stress experience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment resistant depression (TRD) in older adults is a leading cause of disability, dementia, and poor quality of life. Deficient slow waves sleep is at the nexus of depression and cognitive dysfunction in older adults, but novel treatments have not targeted this core pathophysiology. These combined Phase 1 and Phase 2 mechanistic clinical trials will investigate whether propofol confers slow wave sleep enhancement, resulting in longer-term improvements to sleep structure, cognitive function, and mood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This NRSA F30 fellowship will provide an invaluable training opportunity for a future physician scientist as she develops into an emerging leader in cardiovascular and pulmonary disease related research. The proposed studies will investigate the impact of chronic e-cigarette vapor inhalation on cardiopulmonary function and explore the efficacy of an antihypertensive drug, losartan, in preventing any detrimental effects. Findings from this study will further our understanding of the negative consequences of e-cigarettes and may identify novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of e-cigarette related cardiopulmonary dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Parkinson disease (PD) often develop a combination of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric problems that adds substantial morbidity, mortality and economic burden to patients, families and society. In order to develop and evaluate more personalized interventions, individual-level biomarkers are needed. This study will apply new, innovative neuroimaging approaches to identify individual-level brain network biomarkers of PD, examine the relationship of these biomarkers with clinical features and neuropathology, and determine if these biomarkers predict longitudinal cognitive decline and dementia in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Mediator complex (MED) is one of the key factors in transcription machinery, and we identified Med30 gene is highly amplified in various of cancer patients, and significantly co-amplified with the oncogenic transcription factor Myc. However, little is known about the functional contribution of MED30 to transcription activity of Myc, in synergistic way to promote cancer progression; and how the Mediator big complex stabilizes itself. The proposed studies are aimed at understanding the roles of cancer-related MED30 and MED at the molecular, cellular, and physiological levels, gaining insight into phase separation-involved protein complex stabilizing mechanism, and the potentials of inhibiting MED30 as a therapeutic strategy for disrupting Mediator complex in overactive-transcribed cells including Myc-amplified cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Advanced age is a leading risk factor for many different health risks, thus interventions that target common underlying age-related molecular alterations would be especially beneficial. SIRT6 is a gene shown to regulate multiple cellular functions that change during the aging process, and increasing SIRT6 function can extend lifespan. This proposal seeks to better understand and optimize the role of SIRT6 as a pro-longevity gene, with the goal of translating these findings to prevent and treat age-related health issues and extend healthy lifespan in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, First, Middle): Afonin, Kirill, A PROJECT NARRATIVE  Beyond their traditionally known roles as carriers and regulators of genetic information, nucleic acids have auspiciously emerged as versatile therapies for taking advantage of cellular pathways to drive the sensing, targeting, and silencing of a variety of diseases. With MIRA support, we will explore additional nanotechnology- based therapeutic options that enlist a biocompatible nucleic acid-encoded platform (SMART NANPs) for the controlled immunostimulation and modulation of therapeutic responses. This research program aims to advance the envisioned technology towards personalized medicine and aid in addressing top public health challenges in the U.S. as they relate to cancer (through vaccines and immunotherapies), cardiovascular diseases (through regulated coagulation), and drug overdose and safety (through the biodegradable nature of the platform and its functional regulation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the DNA sequence defines what proteins are possible, when and where a DNA sequence is translated into a protein is determined by ‘epigenetic’ modifications that occur on top of (‘epi’) the DNA sequence (‘genetics’). The location and timing of epigenetic modifications are controlled by groups of proteins that ‘write’, ‘read’, and ‘erase’ these modifications. We focus on a group of 'reader' proteins linked to human inflammatory diseases with the long-term goal of finding new ways to target these proteins with chemical probes and small- molecule drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peroxisomes are subcellular compartments housing critical metabolic reactions and are essential for normal human and plant development. The experiments of this proposal utilize a genetically tractable multicellular organism to elucidate the molecular regulation of the biogenesis, dynamics, and degradation of this essential organelle. Results from these studies will illuminate mechanisms of peroxisome dysfunction that contribute to common age-related diseases and inherited peroxisome biogenesis disorders, which are often fatal in infancy or childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: This research uses a quantitative pharmacology approach to understand the complex distribution and metabolism of antibodies and their small molecule payloads from the whole organism to single-cell level. By combining high-resolution molecular imaging approaches to quantify distribution with computational simulations of drug transport, more effective antibody drug conjugates can be rationally designed for cancer immunotherapy and newer non-oncological disease applications.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of urinary incontinence (UI) on American women is immense in human and financial terms, and continues to rise with the growing population of older adults. The goal of this proposal is to improve the care for UI provided to an ethnically diverse population of women and, in doing so, decrease the utilization of specialty care while improving patient outcomes and reducing disparities in care. Three Southern California medical groups will participate in implementation of PCOR evidence, and the intervention will be evaluated in a cluster randomized controlled trial and results disseminated broadly.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A Practice-based Intervention to Improve Care for a Diverse Population of Women with Urinary Incontinence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Data that offer precise descriptions of data—metadata—are critical scientific resources that facilitate the discovery, reuse, and reproducibility of the data to which they refer. Our goal is to create methods and tools that improve the quality of scientific metadata hosted in public repositories, and thus enhance the discoverability and re-use of public biomedical datasets. Making data more accessible through scientifically rigorous metadata will accelerate the ability to make transformative data-driven biomedical discoveries using public data archives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a ubiquitous gamma-herpesvirus associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), which has an estimated global cancer burden of ~78,000 cases per year. On average, more than 90% of adults worldwide are seropositive but control of the latent and lytic infection cycles is paramount to EBV pathogenesis in the nasopharynx. This proposal seeks to redefine the EBV principal oncoprotein, latent membrane protein 1 (LMP1), as a virulence factor that facilitates the induction of the lytic cascade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the elderly population in United States continues to grow rapidly, Alzheimer's disease poses a major public health challenge, and the disease may disproportionately burden older African Americans. Our proposal is designed to reduce the knowledge gaps regarding the role of modifiable risk factors such as perceived stress and how it may differentially impact cognitive function in high-risk groups. Findings from our proposal would lay the foundation of understanding the association of stress and cognitive impairment, mechanistic pathways, and targeted interventions to reduce Alzheimer's disease disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This study will establish basic cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying neuron-glia communication across lifespan. The project is focused on elucidating the roles of Toll-like receptor signaling in mediating interactions between dying neurons and phagocytic glia. The TLR pathway is an evolutionarily conserved component of the innate immune system and its dysregulation is linked to human disorders. By establishing how this pathway directs neuron, neurite, and synapse clearance in the developing and adult nervous system, this research will build an essential foundation for effective clinical approaches to treating neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The major problem being addressed by this study is the lack of understanding on how to modulate the process of clearance of glutamate, the main chemical for communication in the brain. We have developed compounds that modulate the activity of glutamate transporters, the proteins responsible glutamate clearance in the brain. Our goal is to fully understand the mechanisms of modulation of the activity of these transporters, using these compounds and refined and modern technologies. This information could lead to the development of therapies for many CNS disorders that have dysfunctional levels of glutamate, including traumatic brain injury, stroke, ALS, epilepsy, neuropathic pain among others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood flow within the brain must be tightly controled to prevent damage to small blood vessel in cases where perfusion pressure is too high or in ischemia, where pressure is too low. Blood must also be redirected to highly active brain regions to maintain activity. We propose a series of studies that will investigate a class of molecules called “transient receptor potential channels” that detect the brain’s needs and redirect blood flow to maintain an optimal state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Managing gestational weight gain offers lifelong health benefits in both mothers and their offspring, and is especially critical in pregnant women with overweight and obesity who have increased risks for adverse health outcomes. The proposed research aims to test efficacy of the enhanced, Healthy Mom Zone 2.0 intervention that adapts dosage intensity to regulate gestational weight gain (primary outcome) and impact secondary outcomes (maternal physical activity, energy intake, sleep, eating behaviors; infant birth weight; implementation markers) using an innovative, automated digital platform with remote delivery and model-based predictive control system to deliver personalized dosage recommendations. Impact of this research is an effective and scalable intervention for dissemination in the real world (e.g., adjunct to prenatal care) to manage prenatal weight gain and ultimately reduce risks for adverse perinatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Neutrophils initiate organ damage in many autoimmune diseases driven by antibody-antigen immune complexes. We have shown that IgG antibody deposition within blood vessels triggers rapid neutrophil capture and tissue injury via their IgG receptors, called FcγRs, suggesting that these receptors serve as a key link between autoantibody deposition and organ damage. In this project we will interrogate whether FcγR activated neutrophils convert into longer lived antigen presenting cells, which activate T cells to fuel inflammation and associated organ damage in autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with the complications of advanced liver disease often have difficulties after hospital discharge that result in early readmission. Poor outcomes for these patients during this transitional time could be improved through the use of innovative transitional care models. This proposal aims to examine the effect of a transitional care model, The Transitional Liver Clinic, in reducing readmissions, improving quality of life, and improving patient experience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrosis is the excessive accumulation of interstitial extracellular matrix (ECM) generated by activated fibroblasts and is a condition that can affect nearly every organ of the body. However, how activated fibroblasts are epigenetically regulated to maintain its activation and allow for pro-fibrotic gene expression is unclear. By elucidating how the ECM and fibrosis-inducing viruses alter fibroblasts’ chromatin landscape, this innovative study will expand our current understanding of how fibrotic disease develop, with the potential to uncover novel molecular linchpins that could serve as biomarkers or therapeutic targets in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major obstacle to rational HIV-1 vaccine design is the lack of an animal model where the induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) can be achieved in a consistent and reproducible manner and the molecular events leading to bNAb elicitation deciphered. This application proposes a novel “reverse vaccinology” approach in SHIV infected and SOSIP Env trimer immunized rhesus macaques to overcome this roadblock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dysregulated immune response in ARDS patients is directly related to severity and lethality of endemic and pandemic respiratory viruses. R-3750 is a functionally directed synthetic biology medicine that rebalances the immune system, eliminating self-destructive immune responses without compromising the immunological recognition of pathogens. R-3750 combines the safety and ease of administration of a probiotic with the targeted delivery of an immunologically focused drug that can be used to mitigate viral-induced ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Policies to limit the use of electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS, or e-cigarettes) are of major interest to public health decision makers across the US, who must balance the potential risks of ENDS to adolescents (e.g., nicotine addiction, adverse effects on brain development) and potential benefits to adults (e.g., for smoking cessation). Public health research can inform policymaking, but strategies are needed to effectively disseminate such research to policymakers in the face of potentially complicated tradeoffs. This project will develop and evaluate a dissemination strategy – a decision support tool – that could improve the accessibility, usefulness, and public health impact of research evidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The basal ganglia play crucial roles in regulating brain function such as cognition and voluntary purposeful movements, and abnormal development and/or function of these brain nuclei have been associated with childhood neurological disorders including attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) and Tourette’s syndrome. Recently human patient studies have revealed that, like in mice, the Gsx2 transcription factor is essential for basal ganglia development. In this proposal, we combine mouse genetics with molecular, biochemical, and genomic studies to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the role of Gsx2 in basal ganglia development with a specific focus on modeling a known pathological human variant using a novel mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Excitation induced entry of calcium ions into neurons through L-type voltage-gated calcium channels (LTCC) influences neuronal plasticity by regulating synapse structure and gene expression. Elucidating LTCC mechanisms regulating neuronal plasticity is relevant for understanding normal learning and memory as well as learning deficits in intellectual disabilities, neuropsychiatric disorders and neurodegenerative diseases. Changes in LTCC channel function and regulation of synapse structure and gene expression have been implicated in cognitive impairments associated with Alzheimer’s disease, Down syndrome, autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder, and schizophrenia. Linkage of LTCC’s to multiple neuropsychiatric and neurological diseases further supports a key role for these channels in regulating central forms of plasticity that control neuronal function throughout the brain. Previous studies demonstrated that highly localized signaling processes occur near the LTCC that are important for both channel modulation and downstream signaling to transcription factors in the nucleus. However, the molecular mechanisms that coordinate coupling of LTCCs to signaling molecules that regulate synapses in neuronal dendrites and also transcription factors that ultimately act in the nucleus are not well understood. Thus, given LTCC links to multiple nervous system diseases, it is becoming increasingly important to understand these fundamental mechanisms by which LTCCs control synapse structure and neuronal gene expression. Accordingly, here we will characterize fundamental mechanisms by which LTCCs regulate postsynaptic dendritic spine structure and also relay information from synapses to control gene expression in the nucleus, including in pathways relevant to synapse loss Alzheimer’s, autism, and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Over 5 million older adults annually receive post-acute care services from skilled nursing facilities and home health agencies to facilitate the transition from the hospital back to the community. Stakeholders have raised concerns that upcoming Medicare payment reforms for skilled nursing facilities and home health agencies may have negative effects for some patient populations. The proposed study will provide critical information for policymakers, healthcare providers, and payers on the impact of these payment reforms on access to and quality of care overall and across vulnerable patient populations and diagnostic subgroups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered that removal of CD2 increases FOXP3 expression and immunoregulatory functions of regulatory T cells (Tregs). We propose some mechanistic studies to uncover molecules and/or signaling pathways involved in determining the fate of Tregs, targeting of which could alter the immune balance toward tolerance. Also, using a pig-specific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) that we have developed, we will explore the translational aspects of this discovery in humanized mouse model of xeno-islet transplantation (CD2-KO anti pig CAR Treg therapy).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 3% percent of infants and children 6 to <72 months have strabismus (crossed eyes) or amblyopia (lazy eye). The development of amblyopia and strabismus are the result of abnormal vision development in the first few years after birth. The knowledge we gain about the roles of the sensory and motor visual systems and how they communicate during early vision development, particularly in farsighted infants and young children, will lead to the ability to identify infants at highest risk and thus result in improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is to develop an ultra-low-input RNase footprinting approach for simultaneous quantification of cytosolic and mitochondrial translation. The method will open up an avenue to examining the transcriptomic translation using primary tissue samples for both basic scientific research and clinical prognosis. We will apply it to study the dynamic regulation of translational control during hematopoiesis and build the functional network mediated by mitochondrial translation factors. Our study will lead to novel insights into physiological roles and molecular mechanisms of translational regulation.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We have shown that the absence of sufficient dietary fiber triggers an increase in the abundance of mucus degrading bacteria in the colon, leading to erosion of the protective mucus layer and higher susceptibility to development of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The goal of the proposed work is to determine the host and bacterial mechanisms involved in disease development and to investigate a newly revealed connection between dietary soy protein and production of an anti-inflammatory metabolite called isobutyrate. This knowledge will be used to improve gastrointestinal health and treat or prevent chronic disease such as IBD and colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Stores provide over two-thirds of calories and added sugar in the US diet, and product placement within stores influences consumer decisions. A policy that prohibits high-sugar and high-sodium products at store checkouts has the potential to reduce population risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes by lowering consumption of sugar- sweetened beverages, candy, sweets, and salty snacks—the most common foods and beverages at checkout. This project will evaluate the impact of the nation’s first healthy checkout policy on the healthfulness of store food environments and food and beverage sales, and it will examine implementation factors that influence policy effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Bioengineering Experience for Science Teachers “BEST” Program NARRATIVE Meaningful professional development for teachers requires a focus on specific academic subject matter as well as pedagogical knowledge. A research experience in a bioengineering laboratory at a major research university can enhance knowledge of a high school teacher, making it possible to more effectively communicate the nature of bioengineering concepts and applications to his or her students. In combination with guided instruction in developing Next Generation Science Standard- aligned curriculum, the laboratory research can be translated and applied in high school classrooms using research-supported pedagogical practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative C. difficile toxin B (TcdB) is a dominant virulence factor contributing to diseases associated with C. difficile infection (CDI). However, TcdB sequence variations pose a challenge in developing effective therapeutics for the treatment of CDI. Here we seek to develop receptor-decoy-based therapeutic proteins that block a broad range of toxins, as well as novel vaccine candidates that provide effective protection again most of the known TcdB variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: CHICAGO ASSN FOR RESEARCH & EDUC IN SCI
PHR: Extensor tendon injuries of the hand are more common than anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Outcomes after treatment vary, with some patient reported outcomes reporting the same quality of life as two and five finger amputees. The goal of this research is to understand the causes of the functional deficits with a view towards improving patient outcomes following extensor tendon injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Parkinson's disease (PD) is recognized as the second most common age-related neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease, affecting up to 1% of the population above the age of 60 and 4-5% above the age of 85. According to the National Institute of Health, about 1 million people in the United States are suffering from PD. Mutations in LRRK2 are known to be the most common genetic causes of PD. Elucidation of the molecular regulation of LRRK2 in PD in this proposal will lead to understanding how the regulation affects the actions of LRRK2 in nigrostriatal pathway. Accomplishment of this study will advance our understanding of the physiologic and pathophysiologic actions of LRRK2 as well as identification of novel therapeutic targets for LRRK2-associated PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a life-threatening condition which affects ~4% of the population ≥ 65 years of age and for which the only efficacious intervention is surgery. Emerging evidence implicates a causal role for low density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) and suggests that the intensive LDL-C lowering with PCSK9 inhibitors may be a potential strategy to prevent and treat AAA. This project will integrate human genetic evidence and a mechanistic clinical trial to obtain data that would support conducting a large-scale efficacy trial in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative For those over 65, age represents the highest risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and our National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease makes clear the need for early identification and monitoring of the disease, its progress, and any treatments. There is a critical need for a highly sensitive measure of hippocampal function to assess change in memory and hippocampal function over time, both for monitoring of disease progression and to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment approaches. The development of the clinical Mnemonic Similarity Task will improve sensitivity compared to existing neuropsychological assessments, making it an extremely valuable tool for tracking progression of disease or decline and critical for determining the effectiveness of treatments, both pharmaceutical and behavioral.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to explore how radiation damage drives systemic immune imbalances and late organ damage and how this interfaces with changes in circulating miRNA signatures. Ultimately, our goal is to tease out which of these miRNA changes are specific for acute and late radiation tissue damage and build a biomarker panel that would inform on triage decisions after a radiological incident. The appeal in being able to predict the propensity of an exposed individual for developing late effects in a tissue-specific manner after irradiation can not be overstated, and the relevance of these studies may additionally extend to patients receiving cancer radiotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Minority youth have the highest rates of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including human papillomavirus (HPV) and chlamydia. This study will investigate the real-world effectiveness of the HPV vaccines in an inner- city population of adolescent and young adult women of color. In addition, this study will evaluate the impact of the cervicovaginal microbial environment on the risks of HPV and STIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The environmental bacterium Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is now recognized as a significant, multi-drug resistant pathogen, but it remains greatly understudied. Our data document that S. maltophilia has a type IV secretion system and two protein effectors that impact the viability of competing bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a prominent pathogen that can co-infect the human host. We hypothesize that these secreted proteins influence microbial interactions during infection and may be potential tools for disease control, and therefore the proposed studies are aimed at defining how these novel secreted effectors function and on what other important microbial competitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Hookworms are parasitic worms of global importance, infecting nearly 500 million poor people, and causing serious anemia in children, pregnant woman, woman of childbearing age, and the elderly. Current control depends on drugs to which other parasitic worms have already become resistant. We will investigate the mechanism of resistance to one of these drugs, pyrantel, using a resistant hookworm strain we have isolated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA damage interferes with DNA replication leading to genome instability – the hallmarks of cancer, aging, and other diseases. The long-term goal of our research program is to understand DNA damage bypass pathways, such as translesion synthesis and template switching, which help mitigate the effects of DNA damage during replication. Our proposed studies are relevant to public health because they will provide important insights into the maintenance of genome stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell-adhesion receptors are key molecules for cellular communication and have emerging functions in numerous cellular processes. The research proposed in this application will yield key insights into fundamental molecular mechanisms that underlie the function of two poorly understood families of cell-adhesion receptors in multicellular organisms (namely the 33 adhesion G Protein-Coupled Receptors (aGPCRs) and the four teneurins). This research will provide critical knowledge into the molecular mechanisms of intercellular communication, and since many aGPCRs and teneurins are found mutated in neurological disorders and cancers, this research is expected to provide crucial clues for the development of novel strategies to understand and treat these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although antiretroviral drugs can suppress HIV infection, these drugs do not eliminate latently infected cells that resupply active virus and thus require life-long administration with cost, compliance, resistance and chemo- exposure concerns. Combining computer-based design, synthesis, medicinal chemistry and state-of-the-art in vitro and in vivo modeling, the proposed studies will evaluate a new concept and new compounds for reversing HIV latency including conceptually new analog and prodrug latency reversing agents (LRAs) representing the most effective and best tolerated LRAs thus far, determine mechanistic requirements for their LRA activation using PKC inhibitors and transcriptomic analyses, determine synergies and tolerabilities between our new and known LRAs, and test the best performing LRAs or LRA combinations with kill components in an integrated kick and kill strategy evaluation, collectively serving as a preclinical prelude for HIV eradication and clinical evaluation.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative Mutational inactivation of translesion synthesis DNA polymerases and of the protein factors that function with them cause an increase in cancer proneness. Our studies will provide an understanding of the mechanisms via which intrinsically error-prone translesion synthesis DNA polymerases are made to conduct predominantly error- free replication through DNA lesions in human cells – essential for cellular homeostasis and genome stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Abnormalities in cell migration lead to severe developmental defects and contribute to numerous disease states, including heart disease and cancer - the two leading causes of death in the United States. The current proposal will delineate the mechanistic basis for novel regulation of cell migration by novel mechanisms including actin coding sequence and posttranslational arginylation, with the goal of enabling the development of new therapeutics that regulate aberrant cell migration and adhesion in these disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Initiative to Maximize Student Development in Translational Medicine (IMSDTM) Training Program will recruit, matriculate and support diverse predoctoral students from underrepresented populations in biomedical research that translates to human clinical applications to address human health and disease globally. Trainees will benefit from the vast expertise of experienced mentors, state-of-the-art facilities, and substantial institutional programmatic resources and extra- mural funding. Together, activities to encourage inclusivity, synergism in training, and unique experiential opportunities will provide diverse cohorts of predoctoral trainees with the necessary skills to confront threats to human health as they embark upon academic or non-academic research careers in translational medicine research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will pilot test an online class to promote healthy relationships for autistic adults. 160 autistic participants age ≥18 years old will be randomized to the class (HEARTS) or to an active control condition. The goal is to produce a new and innovative relationships intervention within a neurodiversity framework that is highly accessible, delivered at low cost, effective, and satisfying to participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Whether and how cells detect and respond to the presence of lipid stores is largely unknown. Here we define how factors modulating gene expression bind to cellular lipid droplets, and how such sequestration alters their response to available glucose in the medium. Because this gene expression network is of broad importance to mammalian metabolism, these findings will have a broad impact on our understanding of the consequences of cellular lipid accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because of a growing need to innovate the current Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) clinical trial recruitment and assessment process in order to enhance trial efficacy. We propose the application of an online video game as a potential enrichment tool to predict long-term declines in older adult cognition and daily function relevant to AD, thereby aligning with new initiatives in NIA to identify key behavioral patterns/signals that are sensitive and specific to AD. The online nature of this proposed research allows for a fast, affordable and engaging enrichment technique that is particularly timely in the context of COVID-19, where participants can participate remotely in their homes without physical face-to-face contact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The goal of these studies is to understand how nerves in the skin may be silenced by parasitic worms found in contaminated soil when they penetrate the skin. We think that protective immunity against these worms may be dependent on interactions between nerve and immune cells in the skin, but this has not been studied before. The proposed experiments may also identify novel analgesic or anti-inflammatory compounds derived from these worms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Our internal biological clocks have a profound effect on many aspects of physiology and behavior including the sleep-wake cycle. Disruption of circadian rhythms causes sleep deficiency and puts people at higher risk of neurocognitive impairment. Our research focuses on a particular mechanism that links energy sensing in the cell with the circadian clock and how deregulation of this mechanism causes consequence in circadian, sleep and other neurophysiological functions.
