IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Glioblastoma (GBM) is lethal brain tumor with a median survival of 15 months. Therefore novel therapy is urgently needed. Following analysis of data from The Cancer Genome Atlas, and subsequent experimental validation studies, we have identified a subgroup of GBM patients who can be treated with a novel combination of a specific drug and a research diet. We expect that our studies will shed new insights into a novel glioblastoma therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We have found that a group of interferons (IFNs), named IFNλ, are critical for modulating inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs) in both mice and humans yet can play opposing roles during the development and repair of disease, respectively. We found that IFNλ can dampen tissue damage by acting on neutrophils, but also decreases tissue repair by acting on intestinal epithelial cells. Employing both mouse and human model systems and patient-derived tissues, we propose to unveil the mechanistic basis for these activities, anticipating that these studies will be foundational for developing novel and effective therapeutic interventions against IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Occupational exposure to manganese (Mn) through welding fumes continues to bear the risk of developing neurological impairments, with a safe exposure limit to airborne Mn being unknown. This study will define the dose-response relation of Mn deposition and elimination in the human brain, and investigate oxidative stress markers and neurotransmitter changes in a cohort of welders using personal air sampling and novel, non-invasive brain imaging techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy. Understanding the spatial-temporal characteristics of human brain Mn deposition and neurochemical responses of the human brain will have significant translational impact on our understanding of the Mn dose-response relationship in welding, and will help defining a safe level of occupational exposure to Mn.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Anthrax is an acute infectious disease that affects both animals and humans with a high mortality rate. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because the discovery of the molecular mechanisms of anthrax lethal toxin, the major virulence factor in anthrax infection, is critically important in order to develop potential therapeutics that could prevent anthrax-induced mortality. This application will develop the new concept of the reactivation/mobilization of toxin-disrupted pathways as a mechanistic-based targeted therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early-life lead (Pb) exposures are known to result in pervasive effects on cognition and behavior that can persist across the lifespan, and, in some cases, across generations of descendants. There is increasing evidence linking developmental lead exposures, cognitive decline, and neurodegenerative disease risk in aged populations. The mechanistic underpinnings of these effects of toxicant exposure are unclear. Here, we seek to delineate how developmental lead exposure causes genetic and epigenetic changes that lead to adverse neurological health outcomes and transmit this public health issue over several generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Several neurodegenerative disorders are linked to lysosomal dysfunction whereby neurotoxic aggregates accumulate in and rupture lysosomes. Thus, neurons rely on lysosomal quality control mechanisms to rescue lysosomal membrane integrity or sequester damaged lysosomes via selective autophagy. The fundamental mechanisms activating the selective autophagy of lysosomes in neurons are unknown, and therefore, this proposal will investigate conserved mechanisms within lysosomal quality control, providing a groundwork for our understanding of lysosomal dysfunction in neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many solid tumors display a desmoplastic response characterized by an extensive deposition of collagen by cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) which contributes to cancer progression and promotes therapy resistance. The proposed research will investigate the metabolic regulation of collagen production in CAFs. A better understanding of the unique metabolic requirements for CAF-mediated collagen production will help to identify targets to reduce tumor desmoplasia and thereby create novel therapeutic vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Basic biochemical mechanisms fundamental to human health arise from understanding the structure of large biological molecules, both proteins and nucleic acids. X-ray crystallography has been a key method for uncovering their function, and it continues to grow in importance as brighter X-ray sources and more sensitive detectors are developed. This is a computational technology project intended to provide a sharper picture than previously available, allowing some reactions to be followed with snapshots over time, and other experiments to avoid X-ray damage that would otherwise interfere with the measurement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Biofilms are communities of bacteria that adhere to one together and attach to surfaces; by virtue of growing in a biofilm, bacteria become highly resistant to antibiotics or immune responses and cause recurrent, hard-to- treat infections. In this project we will investigate the structure of key staphylococcal surface proteins and their interactions that hold bacterial cells together in the biofilm. The results from this research will provide new insights into controlling bacterial biofilm formation and reducing the risk of recurrent infections. 1

PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy plays an important role in animal health and development, and defects in this process are associated with a variety of human disorders including neurodegeneration, cancer and inflammatory diseases. We are investigating novel mechanisms that control cell context- specific regulation of autophagy during animal development, including cargo-specific autophagy pathways. The recent association of autophagy with multiple diseases, and interest in manipulating autophagy for therapeutic purposes, illustrates the importance of investigating the mechanisms that control cell context-specific regulation of autophagy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Pyroptosis is a highly inflammatory form of cell death mediated by the gasdermin family members, and is implicated in infections and autoimmune or autoinflammatory disorders. This proposal will leverage our expertise in structural and biochemical studies of gasdermins and inflammatory caspases to investigate the post-translational regulation of gasdermins by proteases, ubiquitin ligases, palmitoyltransferases, and other enzymes. Better understanding of the mechanisms of gasdermin regulation is highly significant, which may stimulate the development of novel therapeutics that target pyroptosis and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The efforts of my research program have been directed at probing the actions of membrane receptors and their G protein signaling partners that influence cell growth, differentiation, and development. These studies have culminated in a series of exciting new discoveries that describe how these signal transduction pathways are linked to the assembly of multi-protein complexes that regulate the metabolic activities of cells and the biogenesis of extracellular vesicles, important in embryonic stem cell function, differentiation, cellular senescence and aging, cancer, and infectious disease. By probing the signaling mechanisms that regulate these metabolic complexes and the biogenesis and function of extracellular vesicles, together with elucidating their structural features, we expect to gain new insights into the critical roles they play in a broad spectrum of biology and disease, as well as highlight new targets and strategies for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: The proposed research will lead to new fundamental insights into how the active transport and positioning of essential cellular cargos in bacteria are spatiotemporally driven and coordinated with each other and the cell cycle. The research also lays the groundwork for exploring therapeutic avenues aimed at disrupting the spatial organization of cellular cargos associated with bacterial pathogenicity. Finally, this work will generate the necessary fundamental knowledge for engineering transport systems for protein-based organelles for synthetic biology and biomedical applications, such as the biological production of drugs, drug delivery, and bioimaging.

PHR: The degradation of long-lived organelles and large protein aggregates by selective autophagy is critical for organelle quality control and maintaining cellular homeostasis. We are studying the initiation mechanisms of selective autophagy to better understand how dysfunctions in this process may lead to a loss in the degradation of organelles.

PHR: This grant works to improve methods for cryo electron microscopy and tomography, to image cells and molecules at subnanometer resolution, 100-1000x finer than the best optical microscopes. The methods developed here will help extend these methods to extract information about not only static structure, but motion and interactions between molecules at the same high resolutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria undergo constant surveillance, integrating a variety of signals into a cohesive feedback program that coordinates with the nucleus to ensure prompt homeostatic rebalancing critical for optimal mitochondrial function and cellular health. My lab has been instrumental in studying mitochondrial surveillance, with a particular focus on the ESRE network and its interactions with other protective mechanisms. Identifying the relationship between mitochondrial damage and changes in lipid homeostasis, propagation of the ESRE-activating signal to the nucleus, and how changes in RNA metabolism are coordinated to ensure a prompt response will help identify methods to promote improved health across the human lifespan.

PHR: Project Narrative  The Durrant lab aims to advance pharmaceutical and basic-science research by developing leading-edge computational techniques for designing and optimizing bioactive small molecules. Our tools characterize drug- gable binding pockets on the surfaces of disease-implicated proteins, predict pocket flexibility, suggest small- molecule ligands, and propose chemical additions to improve binding. Building on our previous research, we will continue to develop and apply innovative computational technologies, with an expanded focus on accuracy through machine learning, accessibility, and broad adoption.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Regulated cell death is a critical feature of normal development and a healthy response to environmental or chemical stresses. Failures to control cell death correctly can cause serious diseases, such as neurodegeneration and cancer. The goal of this research program is to gain a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms that control regulated cell death, how these mechanisms go awry in diseased cells, and the most effective strategies for targeting regulated cell death therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  The efficient and modular synthesis of small organic molecules is critical to the pharmaceutical industry. Thus, development of new methods that access difficult to prepare structural motifs or improve efficiency of synthetic sequences are significant and contemporary research objectives in organic chemistry. The primary expected outcomes of our program of research are the introduction of new and unique alkene functionalization reactions that will facilitate the synthesis of a wide range of molecules that are challenging to prepare through alternative methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During recovery of consciousness after general anesthesia, common clinical problems occur such as delirium and delayed awakening. There are no available treatments for these problems because the mechanisms underlying recovery of consciousness after general anesthesia are unknown. The goals of this MIRA proposal are to understand how cognition recovers after general anesthesia in rodents, and to test whether recovery of cognition may be accelerated by activating specific neural circuits involved in memory, attention, and arousal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The ubiquitin proteasome system is currently underexploited for therapeutic interventions despite a vast number of proteins and complexes associated with this vital system. Our understanding of ubiquitin signaling mechanisms as mediated by the many forms of ubiquitin modifications is still lacking. Chemical tools are central to the efforts in unraveling the complex pathways and mechanisms in ubiquitin signaling and they also provide new ways of exploiting the ubiquitin pathway enzymes for drug development, thus achieving therapeutic benefit in treating human diseases such as neurodegeneration and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge for quantitative biology and precision medicine is that we lack a clear understanding of the mechanisms that underpin cellular plasticity and heterogeneous cell fate decisions in response to environmental and therapeutic perturbations. Our goal is to fill the gaps in our mechanistic and network-level understanding via hypothesis-driven, systematic genetic and chemical perturbation studies that leverage cutting-edge, high-throughput, multiplexed technologies, and predictive computational modeling. We expect that our studies and the generated results and models will provide opportunities to improve precision medicine via enabling the control of population heterogeneity and guiding cells toward the desired phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA methylation is a key epigenetic regulator of genome-templated processes, and dysregulated DNA methylation signaling is a defining molecular feature of human cancer and other diseases. This proposal seeks to understand how DNA methylation is inherited through cell divisions, why DNA methylation patterns change in cancer and aging cells, and how these changes contribute to disease states. As DNA methylation antagonism is a major clinical strategy for epigenetic therapy, these studies also have the potential to identify biomarkers and next-generation therapeutic targets for the management of cancer and other diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance The ability to repurpose biological systems for applications in chemical synthesis has broad-ranging impacts on multiple research areas in biomedical science, including medicinal chemistry, drug discovery and green biotechnology development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public health relevance statement Transmembrane transition metal transporter proteins, and their interacting donor and acceptor metallochaperones, are key cellular hubs that evolved to selectively control metal fluxes across biological membranes, finely regulating metal levels in all prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. This research program aims at unravelling the fundamental molecular determinants governing metal cargo delivery, selection and vectorial substrate translocation in metal transporter and associated metalloprotein families that feature diverse chemical, mechanistic and energetic requirements, and are central to physiology, disease, and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of mitotic cell division is for the two resulting daughter cells to contain exactly the same complement of genetic material. Every mitotic cell division must take place with remarkably high fidelity, since errors in mitosis that lead to unequal division of genetic material are intimately linked to human pathologies such as birth defects and cancer. The goals of our research are to understand the molecular mechanisms that ensure error-free mitosis and to determine the causative links between activated cancer signaling pathways and chromosome mis-segregation.

PHR: NARRATIVE Many tumor types are characterized by altered patterns chemical tags found on the histone proteins that package the human genome, leading to defects in gene regulation and DNA repair. Insights into the molecular mechanism by which cells attach and remove these tags, as well as how the tags regulate gene expression, can be used to devise new treatments. This research is being used to drive efforts to develop drugs to treat cancers that are resistant to current therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Riboswitches are ubiquitous mRNA regulatory elements in bacteria that control expression of genes. This research seeks to develop an atomic-level and mechanistic understanding of how riboswitch RNAs regulate gene expression through their ability to directly bind small molecule metabolites and apply our knowledge of riboswitches to develop tools for tagging and tracking single RNA molecules in live mammalian cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Proposal Title: Harnessing divergent reactivities of unusual intermediates as platforms to explore high Fsp3 amine chemical space. Project Narrative: Bioactive amine motifs occur in diverse molecules of key importance to human health, but the lack of diversity in current drug libraries has increased interest in high Fsp3 chemical space, defined as the # sp3 C/total # C. This project uses mechanistic insight to tune the reactivities of unusual intermediates (methyleneaziridines, aziridinium ylides, 2-amidoallyl cations) to achieve mild, versatile syntheses of stereochemically rich, densely functionalized N-hetero- and carbocycles, including those in bioactive molecules that bind to specific ribosomal subunits. These modular and unified strategies to build N-heterocycles of varying ring sizes and substitution patterns from a simple pool of precursors is an attractive addition to the synthetic lexicon, given the prevalence of such rings in FDA-approved drugs.

PHR: Project narrative Each time a cell divides it must produce accurate copies of its chromosomes by replicating the chromosomal DNA. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. Rapid evolutionary processes such as CRISPR gene drives promise novel strategies for the control of vector-borne diseases by enabling the dissemination of transgenes that suppress vector populations or reduce pathogen transmission. However, important questions still loom large about the practicality of these approaches in real-world applications. The goal of the proposed research is to develop simulation approaches and population genetic models that can better incorporate rapid evolutionary processes, to help us gain a better understanding of their expected outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE A person's health and welfare depend on making decisions that are in his or her best interest, but the neuronal mechanisms of decision making are poorly understood. The proposed research delineates the neural circuit for human-like decision making in a model organism whose genes can be manipulated directly, quickly, and inex- pensively. Successful completion of the proposed research will establish a new model system in which to as- sess the function of networks of human genes associated with complex behavioral traits.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Liang, Jie): Project Narrative We will develop computational models and tools to construct probability landscapes of networks of stochastically interacting proteins, DNA/RNAs, and other molecules, and to quantify the flow maps of fluxes and the exact topology of these landscapes, so their behavior and roles in influencing cellular phenotypes can be better understood. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The present proposal uses advanced spectroscopic and computational methods to uncover the coupling between structural dynamics and function of proteins and nucleic acids. The underlying premise is that such coupling plays a fundamental role in biological processes, including folding, recognition, allostery, regulation, and catalysis. Thus, elaboration of the roles of conformational dynamics in actuating and regulating these processes is essential for understanding human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our research program over the next five years will employ powerful advances in molecular genetics, light microscopy and atomic force microscopy to investigate mechanisms that regulate the cytoskeleton during cell division in the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans. Our major goals are to (i) advance our understanding of cytoskeletal regulation in general, as lessons gained from C. elegans oocytes and early embryos are likely to prove relevant in a wide variety of animal cell contexts; (ii) more specifically to advance our understanding of acentrosomal spindle assembly, which is important for both meiosis and mitosis; (iii) explore the C. elegans oocyte cortex as a model for investigating the role of microtubules in an animal cell cortex; and (iv) collaboratively apply Atomic Force Microscopy to isolated C. elegans blastomeres and oocytes to investigate the biophysical properties of animal cell cortices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The regulation of transcription in humans has a significant impact on many aspects of health and disease, but the effects on phenotypes are not fully understood, especially in the context of new genes and their functional innovation. We propose to use fruit flies as a model to investigate the extent of gene expression variation and the role of transcription factors in the evolution of new genes and new expression. The findings of this research will be valuable in our understanding of transcription-associated disorders such as Li-Fraumeni syndrome and verbal dyspraxia, as well as the regulatory mechanisms underlying sperm fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Pathogenic and symbiotic bacteria interact with animal hosts and protect themselves from their environment and antimicrobials such as antibiotics when they grow in biofilms, communities of microorganisms that are attached to each other and/or to a surface using self-secreted molecules such as polysaccharides, and they can leave these protective reservoirs to seed infections elsewhere. We seek to understand the signals and underlying mechanisms that trigger bacteria to form and leave from biofilms using a simple animal model system comprised of the bacterium Vibrio fischeri and its animal host whose natural association depends on these processes. Building on past work, we are poised here to understand how the environmental signals—both inside and out of the animal—trigger production and secretion of specific molecules including the polysaccharides that promote attachment, where and when those molecules are produced, and how bacteria extract themselves to migrate elsewhere, a set of studies that we anticipate will help inform on strategies to treat problematic biofilms that occur in the context of human infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to understand how selfish genetic elements known as transposons are able to escape or evade silencing by specialized host pathways that target TE activity. This research is relevant to human health because almost half of the human genome is composed of transposons and transposons are major contributors to genetic variation among individuals. Understanding the biological functions of transposon- derived DNA is important for interpreting the human genome and inferring traits and disease risk from patient genotypes, thereby supporting the NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The mTOR signaling pathway is a conserved regulator of cell growth that is linked to common human diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and neurologic disorders. A central mTOR function is to control the translation of mRNAs. This proposal seeks to discover how these mechanisms target specific classes of mRNAs and understand their function in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative High levels of cellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) are associated with macromolecular damage and the pathology of a wide-range of neurogenerative disorders and aging. At physiological levels, ROS play a central role in signaling through post-translational modifications, which serve to limit or cope with the potential damage associated with cellular ROS. Our work focuses on the identification and mechanistic characterization of ROS-based signaling pathways that help to manage ROS within healthy cells, to ultimately determine what changes in redox signaling are associated with the loss in ROS homeostasis associated with disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Molecular motors are proteins that use ATP to carry a wide variety of cellular cargoes throughout cells. As in a city where trucks move cargoes, molecular motors are essential, and diseases result when they are misregulated. Understanding molecular motors’ detailed conformations is essential for understanding how they move. To learn more about molecular motors, novel techniques are required, and several new ones are being developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Germ cell differentiates into an oocyte that helps launch the next generation by supplying a maternal contribution of RNAs, proteins, complexes, and organelles that is critical to establish a totipotent zygote. Nevertheless, the mechanisms that establish this maternal contribution during oogenesis are incompletely understood. Using Drosophila as a model system, my lab has discovered a germ cell-to-maternal transition, wherein RNAs that promote germ cell-specific programs, such as those that promote germ cell differentiation, and entry into meiosis are excluded from maternal contribution to promote fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Anion channels, transporters, and scramblases of the TMEM16 and CLC families play key roles in physiology, controlling processes such as muscle excitability and repair, salt reabsorption, homeostasis of intracellular compartments and blood coagulation. While it is known that missense mutations that impair activity of members of both families cause a multitude of inheritable disorders, the lack of atomic level understanding of how disease- causing mutations impair the function of these proteins significantly hinders the development of tools specific pharmacological aiming to ameliorate these conditions. The goal of our project is to overcome these limitations by elucidating at atomic detail how TMEM16 and CLC proteins operate, and how disease mutation impair their activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance of this research to public health: Ionotropic Glutamate Receptors (iGluRs) are major mediators of excitatory synaptic transmission, essential for neurotransmission and proven factors for neurodegenerative and cognitive conditions. Plant ionotropic Glutamate Receptors (GLRs) are useful and tractable models to understand structure function relationships of iGluRs and are structurally akin to the human orphan Glu∂ iGluR family, the least studied and understood in human physiology. Dysfunction of human Glu∂ receptors is associated with cognitive deficits, cerebellar long term depression (LTD), cerebellar ataxia and atrophy, retinal dystrophy and schizophrenia, and some of these dysfunctional aspects have been mechanistically linked to mutations which are physiological for GLRs, turning the study of their functions in plants particularly relevant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Bacterial natural products are small organic molecules that are synthesized and released into the environment where they carry out a number of functions, including chemical warfare against competing organisms or communication with host cells. Recently, we have learned that only a small fraction of these natural products can be accessed by conventional methods and that the human microbiome is an especially intriguing source of small molecules that could have important impacts on health and disease. In this research proposal, we tackle both unresolved issues by applying new methods for the discovery and characterization of these hard-to-find or `cryptic' natural products, especially those in the human microbiome, and by expanding the chemical space and functional scope of microbial natural products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Determining the mechanisms of extracellular vesicle release, function, and clearance Project Narrative Cells release and take up extracellular vesicles during normal development as well as disease, but the in vivo functions of extracellular vesicles are still unclear. This work aims to define how extracellular vesicle budding is regulated, identify how they are processed after uptake, and determine their signaling and functional roles. Our findings will provide fundamental knowledge to design approaches to induce biomarker production, develop efficient drug delivery methods, and influence diseases from inflammation to cancer metastasis to viral spread.

PHR: Project Narrative. Numerous genetic diseases are caused by the misfolding of integral membrane proteins, which is a process that remains poorly understood. Based on our recent identification of various classes of biosynthetic defects, we propose a series of innovative experiments to determine how mutations cause these defects, how they impact membrane protein translation, and how they remodel membrane protein quality control. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will determine the mechanistic causes of phenotypic variation within and between individuals that differ in their genotypes, sexes, or environments in which they live. These causes of phenotypic variation are important in human health and disease—including mental health and genetic disorders—but they are extremely challenging to study in humans and mammalian model systems. To address that challenge, the proposed research will use fly models where phenotypic variation can be measured at scale and genetic mechanisms can be dissected with powerful molecular tools.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cholesterol and its metabolites are the most prolific small molecules in the human body and play multifaceted roles in health and disease. Yet no current therapies can directly intercept cholesterol metabolite activities, in large part because we lack the tools to fully define their molecular functions. In this work, we will fashion precise chemical tools and technologies to profile cholesterol metabolites on an interactome-wide scale, creating druggable opportunities to target their activities in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Most human complex diseases are multigenic, but our understanding of how biological processes are controlled by complex gene regulatory interactions in healthy states and how the operations are disrupted in disease states is lacking. In the PI’s research program, a suite of computational systems biology algorithms will be developed to construct and model gene regulatory circuits of higher complexity to fill an important gap in our understanding of cellular state transitions and their abnormal behavior in disease. The research efforts will provide important new information on the causes of human diseases and will also generate publicly available computational tools for building mechanistic models from omics data relevant to human health and to numerous diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cryptochrome (CRY) UV-A/blue light photoreceptors are found in humans and plants, where they regulate diverse processes like circadian rhythms, tumor suppression, metabolism, DNA repair, flowering, and growth. The proposed studies aim to determine the molecular mechanisms by which CRYs interpret light quality and quantity to regulate plant growth. Understanding the mechanisms of CRY and its associated signaling will lead to improved crop yields for human nutrition and the prevention and development of therapies for diseases linked to impaired CRY function like cancer, diabetes, and neuronal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will deliver an entirely automated approach to accelerate and broaden access to various glycans needed for analytical and biomedical applications from simple renewable precursors. Machine-assisted synthesis ensures rigorous experimental design to obtain robust and unbiased results by significantly reducing variability, ensuring authentication of key chemical resources, and improving reproducibility of experiments. Completely automated synthesis will enhance transparency, simplify the implementation of our protocols in other, even non-specialized, labs thereby increasing the availability of glycans, and aid global efforts to develop automated technologies, carbohydrate-based therapeutics, diagnostics, and analytical tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chloride ions are required for essential functions in the human body, spanning electrolyte balance, acidosis, innate immunity, circadian rhythms, and even taste sensation. At the same time, dysregulated chloride levels have been linked to diseases such as cystic fibrosis, hearing loss, hypertension, kidney stones, osteopetrosis, and pain. We are engineering new technologies for imaging chloride in living systems to fundamentally understand how cells store and regulate chloride in homeostasis and signaling, paving the way ultimately to therapeutically control this anion for the betterment of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The goal of our lab is to uncover the basic principles of gene and chromatin regulation that govern single-cell dynamic responses, distill them into predictive mathematical models, and use this information to build effective and reliable tools for genetic and epigenetic control of endogenous and synthetic genes in human cells. Using high-throughput synthetic biology and single-cell methods, we will systematically measure and model the mechanisms and dynamic capabilities of different gene regulatory components: human and viral transcription factors and chromatin regulators, and their associated DNA elements (enhancers, promoters, and insulators). These measurements, models, and tools are essential for understanding how gene regulation and epigenetic mechanisms contribute to cellular decisions such as cell differentiation, immune response, and cancer progression, and they will enable safer and more efficient genetic, epigenetic, and cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Automated docking is a workhorse for rational drug design, however, applying these methods to peptides has remained challenging, thus impeding the rational designing of peptide-based therapeutic approaches. We have been at the forefront of the development peptide-docking docking methods with our state-of-the-art physics- based docking engine, AutoDock CrankPep (ADCP), which can successfully dock linear and cyclic peptides with up to 20 standard amino acids, and we have established that AlphaFold2 multimer and ADCP can be combined to achieve higher docking success rates. We will further develop ADCP to support more therapeutic peptides; synergistically combine it with AlphaFold2 multimer; and explore the use of these protein-peptide docking methods for approaching peptide-peptide docking, yielding docking tools that will impact the research of many computational and medicinal chemists and biologist, contribute to our understanding of biological processes, and significantly advance biomedical research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is prevented through screening for colon cancer precursors and continued preventive exams over time. Risk stratification is a personalized medicine approach that identifies individuals at high risk and low risk and provides the right amount of CRC prevention through determining the timing and frequency of colonoscopy. In order to achieve risk stratification for CRC prevention we need models that incorporate the history of CRC screening and results for each Veteran, as well as incorporate other factors, like genetic risk factors. The goal of this project is to build statistical and computational methods, databases, and specimen biorepositories using the VA medical record that follow Veterans over time to support research into building tools that include polyp genetic information for better CRC risk stratification.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dementia is a serious issue for Veterans, particularly given the increasing age of Veterans in VA. We will use data from the Million Veteran Program (MVP), one of the world’s largest biobanks, to examine the genetic underpinnings of dementia risk in Veterans. This includes genome-wide association studies of MVP participants of multiple ancestry groups. We will also use new methods to increase the accuracy of dementia genetic risk scores in African American and Hispanic populations, reducing a possible source of health disparities. In addition, we will look for genetic variants that interact with combat related exposures and health problems that occur often in Veterans to increase risk of dementia. Finally, we will refine our algorithms for identifying cases of dementia in the VA electronic medical record, which will increase our power to detect genetic associations. All of this will represent a leap forward in what is known about the genetic architecture of dementia, and in African American and Hispanic Veterans in particular.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Gulf War Illness (GWI) is a chronic, debilitating illness suffered by Veterans of the 1990-1991 Gulf War. Veterans suffering from GWI are often subject to years of medical uncertainty as they make their way through multiple clinics to try to diagnose and ultimately treat their chronic symptoms, if possible. Complicating this medical journey is the absence of biomarkers that can be used to diagnose the conditions and that might provide clues as to treatments and etiology. We will use the Gulf War Era Cohort and Biorepository to test metabolomic biomarkers and combine metabolomics data with genetic variation to identify pathways important in Gulf War Veterans Illnesses. Our results hold promise for rapid incorporation of findings into biomarker discovery and validation and ultimately treatment studies and clinical trials.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Military personnel are at an increased risk of developing blood cell mutations due to their exposure to various environmental hazards. The goal of this proposal is to understand how hematopoietic mutation promotes cardiovascular diseases. The findings from the proposed studies will improve our treatment of two of the most important human health threats, cancer and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sarcopenia, the age-dependent loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength, is a major public-health problem that affects the elderly, leading to loss of mobility, long-term care institutionalization, and diminished quality of life. Muscle stem cells (MuSCs) are key drivers of muscle regeneration, and MuSC subpopulations exhibit considerable heterogeneity in their regenerative capacity, especially with aging. Here we will develop novel strategies to isolate, characterize and overcome the defects in the dysfunctional aged MuSC subset and the aged stem cell niche, informing potential therapeutics to improve skeletal muscle regeneration in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the leading cause of late-onset dementia affecting a large population of our aging society, yet we still do not have an effective way to treat this devastating disease. Towards this, the goal of this project is to understand the molecular etiology of AD by studying a strong genetic risk factor TREM2 which modulates microglial functions and immune responses in the brain. In vivo mouse models and in vitro iPSC cellular models will be used to collectively address the dynamic effects of TREM2-mediated molecular pathways to both inform disease mechanisms and suggest treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the 3D bioprinted stem cell platform developed here will permit a new degree of precision and sophistication towards in vitro modeling of brain development. This approach will enable modelling the dynamic architecture and physiology of the developing human brain, which is imperative for understanding neurodevelopmental disorders. Our work will accelerate the design and application of technologies for manipulating complex, multicellular human stem cell models with robotic level precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Breathing disorders, ranging from sleep apneas to respiratory failure, which is the leading cause of death in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), are caused by disruptions in the connections between the neurons and muscles that control breathing. This proposal aims to understand the genetic and molecular mechanisms that control the development and maintenance of respiratory neurons, in an attempt to identify novel therapeutic targets for respiratory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have discovered an E3 ubiquitin ligase, Cul5, that becomes activated following T cell receptor stimulation and then functions in T cells to limit their differentiation into pathogenic Th2 and Th2/17 cells. Cul5 thus prevents the development of asthma following allergen exposure. We now propose studies that will reveal the biology and mechanistic underpinnings of how this ligase functions in T cells. These studies will provide molecular insight into how Th2/17 cells develop and drive pathology, and will aid the rational design of therapies that target this pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the INF2 gene cause kidney disease in humans. Many different changes in this gene cause the filtering units of the kidney, the glomeruli, to function improperly. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Nicotine enhances auditory and cognitive functions because it mimics the brain’s system for “paying attention” to important sounds amid distractions (for example, understanding speech in a noisy environment). In part, nicotine does this by activating inhibitory neurons in the auditory cortex. Since age-related hearing deficits result in part from the loss of inhibitory neurons, this project will determine, in humans and mice, whether nicotine’s effects can compensate for reduced inhibition in aging and thereby restore auditory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Habits have a remarkable level of control over our everyday behavior, and they can be helpful (e.g., routine exercise) or detrimental (e.g., compulsive eating) to one’s well-being. Animal research has revealed specific brain areas that govern habit formation, allowing for further investigation to resolve finely timed neural mechanisms related to the acquisition and expression of habits. The project proposed here is pertinent to NIH’s mission that relates to developing necessary knowledge and insight about the precise neural mechanisms underlying how habits are controlled, how habits can be contextualized as arising from a network of brain areas, and how adulterations of normal habit signaling might contribute to obsessive-compulsive disorder, Tourette syndrome, and compulsive eating.

PHR: Project Narrative Enzymes called cytidine deaminases are essential for living organisms to regulate nucleotide homeostasis, protect against viral infections, and drive mutations at specific parts of their genome. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Surgical removal of the pancreas with autologous transplantation of the islets (“TPIAT”) relieves the severe unrelenting pain that can result from chronic pancreatitis. The islet autotransplantation portion of the procedure reduces the need for insulin therapy early after the surgery, but little is known about the long-term diabetes outcomes in patients who have had a TPIAT. In this study, we will evaluate how well islets function 5- 20 years after an islet autotransplant, what factors and hormones are important in regulating blood glucose [preventing high and low blood glucose], and whether diabetes complications are reduced by having functioning islets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Available influenza vaccines are insufficient to prevent infections, and alternate strategies are needed. A large proportion of influenza infections are acquired at home. This proposal involves dedicated mentoring of junior investigators in influenza transmission and its prevention, as well as effective execution of studies of factors that can be potentially modified to mitigate the risk of influenza transmission in households.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) the repeated cycles of muscle damage and repair lead to stem cell dysfunction but current therapies do not target muscle stem cells. The studies proposed here will assess the importance of telomere biology in the progression of muscular dystrophy, using new genetic mouse models that target the stem cell compartment. Our research is aiming to investigate the molecular mechanism of telomere dysfunction in skeletal muscle dystrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Programmed retrotransposon activation likely promotes animal development. Our proposed studies aim to understand during development how retrotransposon activity is regulated and what is the molecular function and long-term impact of their activity to the hosts. This research will have the potential to provide new insights on controlling retrotransposons and on harnessing their developmental roles to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Clostridioides difficile causes severe infections of the colon, infections that commonly arise after use of antibiotics that destroy healthy populations of microbes which prevent infection. Our proposed studies are defining the specific microbes that provide this protection, and their mechanisms of action. This knowledge will be used to help create more defined, effective and safe therapies for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia, with women being disproportionally affected, and the biology underpinning this disparity is not well understood. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding the developmental processes that elicit sex-specific inflammatory processes for sexually dimorphic onset and progression of Alzheimer’s disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to understanding the genetic and biological factors associated with aging and age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To inform regulatory decision making, manufacturers and researchers seek to quantify the properties of the emissions generated by e-cigarettes, cigars, and heated tobacco products. A Universal Smoking Machine Adaptor that works reliably with existing smoking machines and the newer tobacco products would be ideal. This project will determine the feasibility of such an adaptor, then design, validate, manufacture and support its use in the tobacco science community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Completing the aims laid out in this proposal will provide novel insights into both the pathology underlying cognitive impairment in Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and the specific mechanisms by which AUD increases the risk of Alzheimer’s Disease. Elucidating such mechanisms would be important not only from a basic science perspective but also from a clinical perspective in that it may reveal novel targets for interventions which can decrease the risk of dementia and cognitive impairment in individuals with AUD. As AUD and Alzheimer’s Disease are both common and debilitating disorders such revelations could result in a significant increase in both life expectancy and quality of life for millions around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Prostatic enlargement continues to be a significant and incurable health problem that will only become more prevalent as life expectancy increases. Thus, there is a dire need for alternative therapies to induce and maintain permanent disease remission. The objective of this proposal is to define the mechanism of how SOX2 maintains multi-potent progenitor cells and promotes prostate enlargement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent advances in multiplexed imaging have led to a new generation of technologies for the spatial profiling of the proteome at a single-cell resolution (spatial proteomics), which promise to revolutionize our understanding of cell-cell interactions in the human body. This project aims to develop computational methods to use spatial proteomics data for building a global human tissue atlas. Incorporating spatial information into our understanding of interactions at a single-cell level will reshape how we view development, aging, disease, and more.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The  burden  of  Alzheimer’s  disease  (AD)  and  Alzheimer’s  Disease- Related  Dementias  (ADRD)  is  enormous,  yet no effective therapeutics exist for a majority of disease symptoms. The studies outlined in this proposal will  allow  us  to  determine  the  cellular  and  molecular  mechanisms  underlying  microglial  regulation  of  Progranulin  levels  and  associated  neuropathological  phenotypes,  and  therefore  may  lead  to  the  development  of  improved  treatments for neurodegenerative diseases resulting from Progranulin reduction in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a chronic retinal degenerative disease that affects about 100,000 people in the United States annually and ultimately results with patients becoming blind early on in their adulthood. Regenerative therapies to treat this disease could reduce the incidence of blindness in RP patients as well as dramatically improve their quality of life. This project seeks to identify the gene expression networks that control the photoreceptor regeneration process so that current therapies can directly target and successfully treat patients with RP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Even though SYK and ZAP70 kinases are almost identical and serve analogous functions, their expression in B- and T-cells is strictly segregated throughout evolution. Whereas the reason for separation of the two kinases is not known, our preliminary results suggest that co-expression of ZAP70 with SYK favors the development of autoimmune disease and B-cell lymphoma. Based on these observations, we will test here the central hypothesis that strict segregation of the two kinases during B- and T-cell development is essential for normal lymphocyte selection and represents a central safeguard against the development of autoimmune disease and B-cell malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the US, traumatic injury is the number one cause of death for those under 45 years old and these deaths include many patients dying from the consequences of bleeding. Through leveraging the power of artificial intelligence (a scientific analysis approach similarly used in non-medical fields to help answer questions from large amounts of complex information), an integrated approach to measuring outcome will be developed utilizing biologic, clinical, and electronic medical record (EMR) data. The goal of this project is to lay the ground work for developing early warning detection systems that could identify those at risk of complications early and assist care providers in selecting the best treatment to minimize complications and death from hemorrhage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Crossing over is an essential aspect of meiosis, generating genetic variation and ensuring proper chromosome alignment and segregation. Unsurprisingly, crossover defects are a major contributor to infertility, a problem that impacts almost 1 in 6 couples, and it has been estimated that ~1/4 of fertilized human eggs have the incorrect chromosome number. Understanding how these crossovers are formed will likely have important implications for our understanding of infertility and miscarriage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed a promising brain-penetrant, small molecule drug candidate, called MW189, that targets dysregulated inflammation in the brain. The proposed Biomarker and Edema Attenuation in IntraCerebral Hemorrhage (BEACH) trial is a phase 2a proof-of-concept study of MW189 in patients with ICH. Success with MW189 will further de-risk the compound for subsequent larger trials of acute CNS injury and/or to develop the drug for Alzheimer’s disease and other age-related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A diminishment in the sense of smell (olfaction) with age is common and compromises quality of life, nutritional status, and personal safety. The olfactory stem cells and the sensory neurons in the nose disappear, and the population of dormant stem cells that are held in reserve fail to activate, despite the pathological changes in the tissue. We seek to activate the reserve stem cells in a controlled fashion in order to treat age-related smell loss; our goal is closely aligned with one of the mission areas of the National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The parasite which causes malaria uses a unique, specialized structure known as the basal complex to separate daughter cells during division. We identified a serine-threonine phosphatase involved in the basal complex which is essential for parasite growth and replication. Our goal is to identify and characterize this protein and its substrates and other interactants to determine the role it plays during the division process, as it could be an effective target for developing new anti-malarial drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In addition to T cells, the Tim 3:Bat-3 pathway is highly expressed in dendritic cells (DCs), where its role has not been well characterized. In T cells Tim 3 acts as an inhibitory molecule, is over-expressed on T cells in chronic viral infections and cancer to mediate T cell exhaustion in cancer and chronic viral infections. In contrast, Tim 3 is sub-optimally expressed in a number of human autoimmune diseases including multiple sclerosis, Psoriasis, Rheumatoid arthritis and Type 1 diabetes. This proposal will provide a greater understanding of how Tim 3:Bat-3 pathway regulates DC function so that the pathway can be therapeutically exploited in chronic viral infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with advanced prostate cancer respond poorly to immune checkpoint therapy (ICT). Although recent preclinical and clinical studies have shed some light into the mechanisms underlying the immunoresistance in prostate cancer, the cellular and molecular basics underlying immunoresistance in prostate cancer remain poorly characterized. The proposed work will determine whether cis-aconitate decarboxylase (ACOD1) regulates the functions of polymorphonuclear myeloid-derived suppressor cells (PMN-MDSCs) to promotes prostate cancer progression and resistance to ICT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutropenic (NTP) fever and bloodstream infections (BSIs) are common complications in the treatment of hematologic malignancy and are associated with increased morbidity and mortality. The proposed research will determine how the early gut microbiome predicts NTP fever and BSIs, as well as evaluate the impact of specific antibiotic exposures on the gut microbiome in patients receiving chemotherapy and stem cell transplant for the treatment of hematologic malignancy. The ability to predict NTP fever and BSI, utilizing the early gut microbiome, will have a significant public health impact by guiding preventive measures such as antibiotic prophylaxis in those at high risk of these events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the profound benefit of antiretroviral therapy (ART) to patient quality of life, HIV-1 remains an incurable infection. Our proposed studies aim to examine the role of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) in promoting the proliferation of latent HIV-1 infected memory CD4 T cells. The proposed program will create pathways for strong research productivity while still in residency and seeks to prepare our physician scientists to compete for post-doctoral research positions and future grant funding. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative While COVID-19 continues to be a health challenge, very little is known about how COVID-19 affects people living with HIV. Recent reports indicate that people with HIV may have increased susceptibility to developing severe COVID-19 disease when infected with SARS-CoV-2. Combining our nonhuman primate models of COVID-19 and SIV infection, we will characterize the effect of underlying SIV infection on the development of acute and post-acute COVID-19 sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway represents the predominant repair mechanism for dealing with double strand breaks (DSBs) throughout the entire cell cycle. Its understanding is of great importance for cancer etiology and cancer therapy, due to its significant role in maintaining genome stability and protecting cells from becoming cancerous. Through structural and functional studies, we seek to define the complex molecular mechanisms of NHEJ so that they may be targeted to develop improved approaches to antitumor therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to fill important gaps in current methods by developing a comprehensive set of tools to analyze accelerometer data to better understand the links between physical activity, sedentary behavior, and sleep and outcomes such as cardiovascular health, and to make open-source user-friendly software available to apply them. We propose methods to identify and account for non-wear periods through machine learning and multiple imputation approaches under a generalized linear mixed effects model framework in order to correlate behaviors with outcomes. The methods we develop and validate will be useful for studying questions of great importance to public health such as identifying signature patterns of physical activity, sedentary behavior and sleep that may be favorable for cardiovascular health and will provide insights into analytic approaches for studies that involve other types of monitoring data with public health relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative. Nicotine flux, the rate of nicotine emitted from ENDS, encapsulates several use-factors that impact nicotine emissions including power and liquid composition. Importantly, nicotine flux may serve as a measure of the rate of nicotine delivery, a key determinant of nicotine dependence. Nicotine flux therefore presents a potentially powerful regulatory lever, if it can be shown empirically to predict nicotine delivery and subjective effects relevant to dependence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a complex and progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting millions of people each year in the US, as well as being a known environmental risk factor for the development of Alzheimer’s disease-related dementia. However the mechanisms underlying the increased risk to develop Alzheimer’s disease-related dementia following TBI remain unclear. The salient findings from this project will significantly contribute to fundamental knowledge-base of the role of inflammatory response of astrocytes in the aging brain as determinants of outcome following TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative: Liver fibrosis is a highly conserved response to hepatic tissue injury. Cirrhosis arises as the common final outcome of uncontrolled fibrotic response, ultimately leading to disrupted hepatic architecture, portal hypertension and end-stage liver disease. Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The studies proposed within this application are designed to explore the CTGF/ADAMTS7 or CTGF/ECM1 axes as systems that regulate repair of the liver and its involvement in alcoholic fibrosis and hepatic progenitor cell activation. The overall goal of this proposal is to understand mechanisms underlying liver repair and to develop novel therapies that would prevent or reverse alcoholic fibrosis.

PROJECT_TITLE: Regulation of the pro-fibrotic connective tissue growth factor in alcoholic liver disease: mechanisms and targeting approaches

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Multiple myeloma (MM) is a plasma-cell malignancy with increasing incidence with age, median age of diagnosis at 70 years, and with African Americans affected at twice the rate of Caucasians. VA patients have increased risk of MM as there is a reported association with agent orange exposure. In a review of patient records in 2012, over 4,000 patients with MM diagnosis were seen in VA. One of the established therapies for MM is chemotherapy with stem cell transplantation, for which most veterans are not eligible due to age, disease state, and/or co-morbidities. Despite significant therapeutic improvements in MM, patients eventually progress and die from the disease, highlighting the need to identify novel targets and therapies. Leveraging our genomic and transcriptomic data, the proposed studies will identify the impact of dysregulated long-non coding RNAs (lncRNAs) on the pathobiology of MM, with potential to serve as therapeutic targets. These studies will define the functional landscape of lncRNA in MM and allow for development of translational therapies for veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: On average, 18 U.S. Veterans die by suicide each day. From 2009 to 2018, more than 64,000 Veterans died by suicide, which is roughly the same number of U.S. military fatalities that resulted from the wars in Vietnam, Iraq, and Afghanistan combined. Unfortunately, the genetic basis of suicide remains largely unknown. The overall objective of this application is address this critical gap in our understanding and discover novel, replicable gene x environment (GxE) interactions that increase Veterans’ risk for suicidal thoughts and behaviors. The findings obtained from the proposed work could fundamentally shift understanding of the biology of suicide, lead to new and improved treatments, and improve VA’s efforts to identify and intervene with Veterans at risk for suicide. As such, the present application has tremendous potential to advanced VA’s mission and improve Veterans’ health, safety, and well-being.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease that afflicts large numbers of veterans and leads to severe cardiovascular complications including end-stage kidney disease. Most forms of chronic kidney disease (CKD) that feature persistent tubular damage progress to organ failure. Treatments that curtail chronic tubular injury are therefore desperately needed. The realization that pro- inflammatory cytokines contribute to tubular damage in sterile forms of kidney disease presents an opportunity to develop novel therapies for the prevention of end-stage kidney disease. The proposed studies will examine regulatory factors specifically in the kidney tubular cell (KTC) that constrain inflammatory mediator induction both within the KTC and in infiltrating immune cells. Identifying these factors will benefit the veteran’s population by leading to the rational design of potent, immune-directed therapies to prevent and/or slow the progression of CKD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Regulatory CD4+ T cells (Tregs) express the transcription factor, Foxp3, and are necessary to maintain intestinal homeostasis; as such, they are an intriguing pharmacologic target for the immunotherapy of inflammatory bowel disease. The Tregs in the intestine are specialized to their environment with the local milieu defining the phenotype and function of the cells. We will utilize murine models and studies of human tissue to define the cellular and molecular pathways that drive maintenance and expansion of small intestine Tregs to identify targets to enhance local Treg numbers and function.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Uncontrolled hypertension is present in 37% of veterans, posing several risks to health, including cerebrovascular disease (CBVD) which increases the risk for Alzheimer’s dementia (AD). In fact, 80% of AD patients have some degree of CBVD, which can worsen response to drugs designed to target pure AD, which may be one reason why billions of dollars of investiment in drug development for dementia has had little impact on therapies. In addition to the 750,000 veterans who currently have dementia, there are predicted to be nearly 900,000 new cases by 2030, so we validate a new animal models and test two drugs to understand how to treat the complexity of this devastating disease which has a catastrophic toll on Veteran patients and their caregivers, global health, Medicare and the US economy and Federal budgets that fund the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Granulomas are collections of macrophages and lymphocytes that characterize a range of chronic inflammatory conditions. Here, we will investigate the cellular and molecular architecture of human tuberculosis granulomas to learn about how these structures mediate antimicrobial activity against the intracellular bacterium that causes tuberculosis as well as contribute to disease pathogenesis. The insights gained from this study are critical for understanding protective immunity against tuberculosis towards developing new strategies for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke and traumatic brain injury (TBI) are leading causes of major disability and death, and delays in diagnosis and treatment are associated with higher morbidity and mortality. Current diagnostic standards in stroke and TBI require that patients undergo computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging in a hospital setting to differentiate ischemic and hemorrhagic subtypes before initiating treatment. Our study proposes to develop a portable, noninvasive stroke/TBI detection and imaging system based on tri-coil eddy current damping technology, thereby rapidly identifying stroke subtypes, accelerating time-to-treatment, and providing early responders with information necessary to more efficiently administer triaged and appropriate intervention in the field or acute care setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As more people with cystic fibrosis (CF) live longer and healthier lives due to the advent and use of effective CF modulator therapies, a growing number are considering parenthood. However, minimal information exists about how parenthood affects those with CF, limiting the ability to make informed reproductive decisions and to support those who decide to become parents. This long-term, multicenter, observational study will determine the health impact of parenthood on men and women with CF in the era of CF modulators and is the first, large- scale epidemiologic data collection of how becoming a parent interplays with having a chronic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia after Alzheimer’s disease (AD), is rapidly progressive with a median time from diagnosis to death or nursing home half that seen with AD and extensive burden on both patients and family caregivers. There are no approved treatments, though some drugs approved for other diseases may partially or temporarily relieve some of its cognitive and motor symptoms. The proposed research would advance clinical testing of neflamapimod as a treatment to not only relieve symptoms but also treat the underlying disease process, potentially providing hope for DLB sufferers and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The continual trend of “lost in translation” in the search for a successful treatment for Alzheimer's disease (AD) calls for innovative approaches before a viable drug target is established. The outcomes of this research will yield valuable insights into whether a therapeutic shield such as a human ApoE2- based protein therapy that promotes brain metabolic resilience can potentially be developed into an effective and safe disease-modifying strategy for AD, which is vital to the present fight against this devastating and currently untreatable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of patients survive early phases of sepsis (cytokine storm) and go on to develop long-lasting immunoparalysis state that is characterized by the diminished ability to respond to secondary infections. This proposal will identify cellular and molecular mechanisms that define and support chronic state of immunoparalysis and inability of innate and adaptive cells of the immune system to exert their effector functions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the Twelfth, Thirteenth, and Fourteenth Annual American Society of Health Economists (ASHEcon) Conferences is to enable the community of health economists, health services researchers, and health policy researchers to gather and present research, exchange ideas, gain new skills, and learn about current policy issues. The research presented at each conference encompasses several aspects of health economics and policy research, including both health care and health behaviors. We aim to provide a forum for emerging ideas and empirical results of health economics research to be showcased and discussed.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Advanced chronic kidney disease represents a major cause of morbidity and mortality for our Veterans and is frequently associated with anemia, the inability of the body to produce adequate numbers of red blood cells. This grant investigates the role of mitochondria in the regulation of erythropoietin, the hormone that is made by the kidney and is essential for red blood cell production. Work proposed under this grant will further our understanding of the metabolic causes of anemia associated with kidney failure. This project has potential for the development of novel therapeutic approaches for the management of anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The high prevalence of obesity among veterans is a major health concern because obesity is associated with life threating illnesses including high blood pressure, a medical condition that promote cardiovascular disease. However, the processes by which obesity promote high blood pressure and other cardiovascular risks is not well understood. The research proposed in this application will fill this gap in knowledge by defining the mechanisms of by which the brain drives obesity-associated high blood pressure. This information can lead to improved treatment for cardiovascular disease, bettering the lives of the veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) constitutes nearly half of all heart failure hospitalizations, and HFpEF is responsible for the death of nearly 1 in 14 Veterans. However, currently there are no treatments that improve mortality in this disease. This proposal aims to test a promising new target that may alter energy utilization and metabolism in the failing right heart in HFpEF. This proposal also supports the training and career development of Dr. Vineet Agrawal to study the disease of HFpEF and identify new therapies for a disease that currently has none.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The excess risk for chronic kidney diseases (CKD) in black Americans is largely explained by social determinants of health and the presence of genetic variants in the APOL1 gene. The pathogenetic mechanisms responsible for the genetic association remain poorly understood, hindering the development of specific therapies. This project will anchor gene expression features present in patient-glomerular transcriptomes to those present in iPSC-derived podocytes, to provide novel insights into the molecular function and genetic pathways that distinguish APOL1-G0 from the kidney disease risk variants, laying a groundwork for prognostic biomarkers and novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coxsackievirus B is a common human pathogen that can cause acute and chronic pancreatitis. If we can understand how to block viral replication and the cell-to-cell spread of the virus, this would provide insight towards developing new antiviral therapies to limit the severity of pancreatic damage. We have identified several novel areas of virus-mitochondrial interactions, and based on our findings, we propose to test potential therapies in a mouse model of viral pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance our understanding of the pathogenesis of pancreatitis, a disease with considerable morbidity and mortality and currently without a treatment. Excessive inflammation is a major determinant of pancreatitis severity but its mechanisms are poorly understood The results will establish the importance of mitochondria as a clinically relevant modulator of the inflammation in pancreatitis and identify potential molecular targets amenable for pharmacologic intervention to normalize mitochondrial functions and reduce pancreatitis severity; thus, this proposal is relevant to the NIH’s goal to develop research strategies as a basis for disease treatment.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE While cancers are a major cause of death around the globe in people living with HIV infection, those in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, are much more likely to die from cancer due to shortages of trained cancer researchers, oncologists, and a lack of healthcare infrastructure and expertise in preventing, diagnosing and treating HIV-infection associated cancers. The Tanzania AIDS Malignancies Training and Research Program (TAMTRP) seeks to address these challenges to enhance the cancer research infrastructure of our partnering organization, the Ocean Road Cancer Institute (ORCI) in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania by training a cadre of Tanzanian fellows, researchers and practitioners with career interest in HIV associated malignancies. The TAMTRP program will enable the trainees to develop skills necessary to further both partners' research agenda in clinical research, public health, cancer biology and genomics/bioinformatics, which will translate to better clinical care for HIV-infected cancer patients globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Recombinant adeno-associated virus (rAAV) gene therapies are increasingly becoming a viable treatment option for incurable genetic disorders. However, they are not without toxicity or significant risk, with several rAAV-related deaths and numerous adverse outcomes reported during the past few years alone. Embarking on a new research direction, we will utilize our complimentary expertise in neuroscience, stem cell biology, and engineering to develop new methods for rAAV production and create the first rAAVs with engineered inverted terminal repeats (ITRs) that are safer for human gene therapy.
