IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading killer of women in the United States and worldwide, and women with premature age of menopause have elevated risk of developing CVD for unclear reasons. Preliminary data suggest women with premature menopause have increased risk of CHIP, a recently recognized asymptomatic blood condition associated with accelerated development of CVD and adverse CVD outcomes. The proposed study will investigate whether CHIP is responsible for CVD in women with premature menopause and will identify new targets for the prevention and treatment of premature menopause-associated CVD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is focused on developing gene transfer technology for and understanding the metabolic consequences of cystinuria, an inherited kidney disease in veterans. The proposed gene transfer strategies and knowledge gained with cystinuria could lead to development of new therapies for a variety of other human kidney diseases which plague veterans. Our research approach is therefore extremely significant and relevant to the health of veterans and the overall mission of research within the VA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Evidence of cerebellar dysfunction which correlates with the severity of cognitive and emotional symptoms in Veterans with psychiatric disorders is beginning to be elucidated. Aberrant dopamine signaling arising from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) is also a likely contributor to many psychiatric disorders, and it is known that cerebellar nuclei project to the VTA, the heart of the mesolimbic dopamine system which mediates reward and fear learning. We hypothesize that a novel locus of aberrant function in psychiatric disorders stems from faulty circuitry between the VTA and the understudied cerebellum. We will target specific cerebellar-VTA circuits with cutting edge tools to map, characterize, and manipulate this circuit’s function in different cognitive domains. This will result in novel insights into mechanisms and novel interventions for cognitive and emotional symptoms in Veterans, which are of great interest.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a debilitating disease of the joints that affects over 10 out of 1000 Americans, including the Veterans. Further, the prevalence of RA is much higher in women than in men. This is of special relevance to women serving in the military. The aging Veterans constitute another group to bear the brunt of RA. The suffering and disabilities caused by RA impose a huge financial burden on the healthcare and rehabilitation of Veterans. Many potent drugs are available for the treatment of RA; but their prolonged use is associated with severe adverse reactions because these drugs that are given orally or by injection are distributed to all organs of the body. We propose targeted drug delivery to the joint as a better alternative. We reported that an arthritis drug entrapped in liposomes that displayed a novel joint-homing peptide (ART-2) on their surface was more effective than other modes of treatment in a rat arthritis model. We now plan to validate these findings in a different (mouse) model of arthritis to de-risk the technology for translational studies in RA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Several prevalent diseases in Veterans result in reduced oxygen content, or hypoxia, in vital organs of the body. These include anemia, heart disease, stroke, kidney disease, cancer, amongst others. Every cell in the body has the capacity to turn on genes and proteins in response to hypoxia in an attempt to counter the damage that otherwise results. In some cases, this hypoxia response is beneficial; in other cases, it exacerbates the disease. This proposal seeks to understand how the hypoxia response is controlled. The Potential Impact on Veterans Health Care based upon information gained from these studies is development of targeted treatments that enhance or repress the hypoxia response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 25% of human tumors harbor a gain of the “q” arm of chromosome 1, but the functional consequences of this large-scale dosage change are unknown. We will develop and employ novel computational and genetic strategies to characterize the functional consequences of this alteration. These studies will shed light on the physiological effects of a ubiquitous but poorly-understood feature of tumor genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age is the primary risk factor for cognitive decline, and the number of people with age-related dementia is expected to triple to 14 million by 2050 with no effective treatment solutions on the horizon. This research may demonstrate that senescent cells that accumulate with age throughout the body are a source of pro-aging proteins in blood circulation that disrupt brain function. Systemic elimination of senescent cells may reveal a vital new strategy to deplete the progeronic impact of aged blood, ultimately promoting healthy cognitive aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project uses an unprecedented, prospective, longitudinal data set, in a non-human primate model to identify age-related changes in the gut microbiome’s functional capacities across the lifespan. The results will reveal social and environmental drivers of microbiome aging, as well as microbiome features that predict maturation, physical/behavioral aging, and mortality. The proposed research is relevant to human health because it will provide targets for gut microbiome interventions aimed at sustaining healthy aging and improving health for people with microbiome-related disease. The project is highly relevant to NIA's mission of understanding processes that contribute to health and well being across the life span.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Disease, degeneration or aging of the nervous system are among the greatest public health concerns in the United States and are generally considered irreparable, often causing catastrophic damage to the functional capacity of the individual. Now, however, characterization of neural stem cells residing within specific germinal centers of the brain and in cell culture raises hope that functional regeneration of nervous tissue may be feasible, if we learn to exploit neurogenesis for clinical benefit. The research proposal here aims to study how existing brain cells control the integration of new members derived from endogenous neural stem cells in aging brains. If successful, this proposal will lead to advanced understanding of neural stem cell biology, possibly leading to the development of new drugs for repair and regeneration of the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a dysbiotic condition of the vaginal microbiome that affects ~29% of reproductive age women and is linked with higher risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes, postsurgical infections, and sexually transmitted infections. Current topically-applied medicines require frequent repeated administrations which can hinder convenience and adherence to treatment, particularly when undergoing multiple weeks of treatment. In this project we will use 3D-printing and computational modeling, iteratively enabled by functional investigation of prototype scaffolds, to design long-acting products that sustain phased-delivery of antibiotics and probiotics to restore and maintain vaginal health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Pancreatitis is a progressive, sometimes fatal, disorder characterized by inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreas functions. It is associated with severe pain, poor quality of life, and increased risk for the deadliest pancreatic cancer. Excessive alcohol consumption, smoking, and age are major risk factors for pancreatitis. The prevalence of these factors results in high pancreatitis incidence in Veterans. In addition, Veterans with pancreatitis have much greater risk of pancreatic cancer than non-Veteran patients. Currently, there is no specific or efficient treatment for pancreatitis, primarily because we do not understand underlying molecular mechanisms. Our recent findings revealed a previously unrecognized role of cholesterol dysregulation in disease pathogenesis and suggest repurposing the available cholesterol-lowering drugs for pancreatitis treatment. The present proposal will validate these results in preclinical mouse and cellular models in order to de-risk future clinical trials and drug development studies. Thus, the proposal addresses unmet and urgent clinical needs of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) has many causes that result in loss of neurons that the brain uses to store memories. Other cells in the brain with the crucial job of protecting neurons are called astrocytes, which can also be damaged in AD, yet have been studied less in AD than other forms of brain pathology. The goal of this project is to understand how damage to astrocytes, especially their ability to detoxify the brain, is involved in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Project Narrative Social isolation is a critical factor in the etiology of mental health conditions including substance use disorders. While public health efforts have focused on emphasizing positive social experiences to buffer against maladaptive decisions such as substance use, the neural dynamics of how social rewards can foster the development of healthy social connections remains understudied. This proposal will implement behavioral, neuroimaging and innovative, naturalistic social interaction methods to delineate mechanisms underlying social connection, forming a foundation for exploring how such processes are compromised in nicotine-dependent individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to improve understanding of the causes of infections of joint replacements and non-infectious causes of arthroplasty failure. We are targeting the microorganisms that cause infections directly as well as host response to them and to other causes of arthroplasty failure using a proteomic strategy applied to materials dislodged from the surfaces of knee replacements. Our prior work has led to new diagnostic techniques that are now part of standard guidelines; our new studies, proposed here, are poised to lead to even better diagnostic tests and to inform future treatment and prevention approaches for arthroplasty failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Light chain amyloidosis is an understudied and underserved blood disorder associated with delayed and under diagnosis, particularly among Black individuals, despite warning signs in the form of a premalignant MGUS state and multiple preexisting precursor diagnoses that frequently occur. This project will study patterns of precursor diagnoses in AL amyloidosis cases, associated racial differences, and identification of potentially undiagnosed AL amyloidosis patients using Bayesian machine learning algorithms. This application, in response to the NOSI: Diagnostics and Disease Management Tools for Use in Underserved Populations (NOT-HL-22-006), will create pathways to early diagnosis of AL amyloidosis when it is more treatable, yielding improved outcomes and prolonged survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: It has been a major unmet medical need for the development of efficient brain delivery across the blood-brain barrier with wide distribution of the therapeutic macromolecules to many types of brain cells in treating a wide variety of neurological diseases. The goal of this project is to develop a novel platform with advanced brain delivery of therapeutic proteins by coalescing in vivo epigenetic alteration of microRNA with targeted gene transfer and restricted transgene expression for improved CNS treatment of Hurler syndrome, a neurologic lysosomal storage disease (nLSD). Such therapeutic approach would have significant and broad application across many other nLSDs or neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graves’ Ophthalmopathy (GO), the most serious extra-thyroidal complication that develops in patients with autoimmune Graves’ hyperthyroidism, is characterized by increased orbital fat volume and extra-ocular muscle within the unyielding bony orbit, which can have deleterious consequences on eye function. We hypothesize that a novel enzyme, PAPP-A, is a key regulator of GO, and will test this hypothesis using orbital fibroblasts from patients with GO. We anticipate that the results of our proposed experiments could ultimately lead to a novel targeted therapy for patients with GO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The purpose of our proposed study is to elucidate how mutations in the heat shock protein DNAJC7 cause ALS/FTD, an untreatable and devastating neurodegenerative disease. We will use induced pluripotent stem cell- derived neurons in combination with quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics to elucidate the role of DNAJC7 in human neurons and determine how its dysfunction leads to their dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti lays its eggs preferentially in standing pools of water in and around human habitation that are infused with organic matter. Pregnant Aedes aegypti are highly attracted to the scent of fermenting African Bermuda grass hay in water, which has been exploited for trapping strategies that aim to lure this major disease vector to its death during the act of egg laying. An improved understanding of the chemosensory basis of Aedes aegypti attraction to hay infusion will help to identify new molecular targets to modulate mosquito egg laying behavior and inform the development of long-lasting synthetic oviposition attractants for improving traps used for mosquito population surveillance and control.

PHR: A detailed understanding of HIV-1 capsid ultra-structures of as they promote virus infection inside cells, remain unclear. This project will develop key correlative light and cryo-EM (CLEM) workflows to locate and structurally characterize relevant capsids inside cells. The tools developed in the project will improve throughput in structurally imaging of HIV-1 and advance our understanding of virus cell biology, which is of high public health significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative We have shown that air samplers in schools detect respiratory viruses, including SARS-CoV-2 and in- fluenza viruses. This project will deploy air samplers to 16 K-12 schools to explore whether air sampling accurately assesses SARS-CoV-2 and influenza virus risk in schools and forecasts transmission of these viruses in the communities where the schools are located. Viral sequencing of air samples will also be performed to ascertain which viral variants are circulating and spreading within and between schools and the broader community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) are both due to mutations in the DMD gene DMD occurs due to an absence of a functional dystrophin protein where as BMD is associated with the presence of partially functional dystrophy. However, a fundamental question remains; how much dystrophin is enough to provide benefit. Using large patient cohorts, we will assess the quantity of dystrophin and the molecular mechanisms that allow such expression, and correlate these with clinical features. In addition, using patient- derived cell lines, we will develop vectors for skipping of pseudoexon mutations, as an approach to therapeutic expression of full length dystrophin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because the ability to store and retrieve long-term memories is an essential cognitive function in human daily life, and dysfunction of proper memory storage is a debilitating symptom of many neuropsychiatric disorders such as dementia, major depression, and post- traumatic stress disorder. By utilizing multiple techniques and levels of analysis, including the manipulation and longitudinal recordings of brain-wide circuits over extended time periods, this research will facilitate new insights into the distributed nature of memory encoding in the brain and lead to new mechanistic understandings of mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Invasive fungal disease, estimated to kill over one million people annually, often begins when dormant spores are inhaled from the environment and break dormancy and start active growth within host lungs. If it was possible to perturb the establishment, maintenance, or breaking of dormancy, much fungal disease could be better-managed or possibly eliminated. The study will furnish important information about genes that are highly expressed in dormant spores, and rapidly disappear in actively growing cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Persons infected with HIV now have a life expectancy that approaches that of the general population, but they remain at a significantly elevated risk of developing cognitive impairments. Recent neuroimaging studies have identified the cortical brain circuits that are centrally involved in these generally mild cognitive impairments, but the underlying molecular mechanisms remain poorly understood, and the potential therapeutic options are very limited. The current project builds on several important discoveries in 2021 and will use advanced dynamic functional brain mapping, systems biology approaches, and structural equation modeling to determine whether parameters of the mitochondrial redox environment drive neuro-inflammation in persons with HIV and whether chronic cannabis use modulates these parameters, with the long-term goal of identifying viable therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will: a) quantify age-related change in decision making among >1,500 well-characterized older adults initially free of dementia, b) identify risk factors for decline and document a wide range of adverse consequences including adverse health (e.g., Alzheimer’s dementia) and financial outcomes (e.g., financial exploitation), c) determine the degree to which decline in decision making is due to aging-related changes in the brain and pathologic indices of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs). The proposed study offers an unprecedented opportunity efficiently determine the risk factors, consequences, and neurobiologic bases of age-related change in decision making and identify modifiable targets to preserve decision making in old age. Findings will have immediate translational implications for behavioral and policy interventions to improve health and financial wellbeing among older adults and greatly extend our understanding of the impact of aging and ADRD-related changes in the brain on financial and health decision making among cognitively healthy older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Rett Syndrome is a devastating neurodevelopmental disorder which primarily affects girls, and is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene. We propose to examine early deficits in cortical neurogenesis and neuronal migration caused by MECP2 mutations, as a way to understand fundamental changes in brain development in Rett Syndrome. These findings will help develop therapeutics targeting these early developmental stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Environmental disasters such as wildfires pose an increasing threat to a growing and aging global population and little is known about the impact of inhaled wildfire smoke on neurological and cardiovascular aging. We will examine the impact of inhaled wildfire smoke in terms of augmenting aging-related circulatory proteins and peptide fragments that compromise BBB integrity and alter microglial function to promote a reduced metabolic, senescent cellular phenotype that may be reversible with treatment of NAD+ boosting compounds and senolytic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Routinely collected data are increasingly used for HIV/AIDS research, but these data are prone to errors and may need to be supplemented with additional data collection. We will create novel statistical methods, study designs, and tools to guide strategies for collecting additional data on subsamples of patient records and for incorporating these additional data into analyses to improve estimation. The proposed methods will be applied to studies using data from the Latin American and East African regions of the International epidemiology Databases to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA) network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: High sugar consumption is associated with chronic diseases; among the sugars, fructose is the most detrimental, but we do not know why. The parent grant targets mechanisms by which fructose metabolism in the liver contributes to chronic diseases, while this proposal addresses non-hepatic metabolism of fructose, including 1) the amount of fat made in the gut and intestinal factors involved in regulating fat in the bloodstream, 2) how much fructose circulates in the bloodstream, and 3) how much fructose is used as fuel, thus producing CO2. This proposal is relevant to NIDDK's mission as conclusions reached by the ancillary and parent grants will contribute valuable mechanistic information to help lay the foundation for public health policies and strategies for preventing and treating chronic diseases.    parent grants will contribute valuable mechanistic information to help lay the foundation for public health policies and strategies for preventing and treating chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Inflammatory factors in inflamed joints of RA patients activate cells called macrophages to produce molecules called cytokines that drive disease pathology. The goals of this project are to understand mechanisms that control the balance and extent of inflammatory cytokine production by RA synovial (joint) macrophages. We anticipate that our studies will provide knowledge that can be used to develop new therapies to suppress inflammation and joint damage in RA patients.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE HIV transmission can be effectively controlled if new infection and treatment failure can be detected early. Increasing access to routine HIV testing, especially self-testing that allows individuals at risk to know their HIV status timely and privately, can greatly improve HIV prevention in the United States. This project aims to develop an easy-to-use ultrasensitive HIV self-testing device to allow lay persons to perform quantitative HIV antigen measurement with finger prick blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Brain atlases are essential in guiding studies on brain functions under normal and disease conditions. Currently available atlases and methods for building such atlases, even for simpler laboratory model organisms, are simplistic, not accurate, labor intensive to build and update, and difficult to use. This project will pioneer a technique to address the current challenges and may be generalizable to many other systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Researchers are devoting increasing attention to the grave and varied health-focused implications of mass incarceration – especially since the onset of the covid-19 pandemic – but there is no comprehensive historical study of health care in U.S. carceral institutions. Minimal Standards of Adequacy: A History of Health Care in U.S. Prisons analyzes how policy makers, the courts, medical professionals, incarcerated people, and others defined and experienced prison health services during the past century. It will enrich understandings of U.S. medical, policy, and legal history, and be an asset to stakeholders aiming to think critically and productively about how to improve the health and well-being of people in and beyond prisons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The only FDA-approved treatment for thrombotic stroke is tissue plasminogen activator, but it is used in less than 5% of stroke victims with no noted improvement in survival and with no direct neuroprotective effects. Here, we provide a blueprint for developing the first GPR31 inhibitor as an effective antiplatelet therapy that provides secondary neuroprotective effects for mitigating against the acute neurologic sequela of stroke for a potentially more effective and safer alternative option or adjunct to fibrinolytic therapy in this area of high unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, substance use behaviors contribute to the leading causes of mortality and morbidity of adolescents, and are associated with approximately $60 billion in economic costs per year. Influence from social peers can contribute to adaptive or maladaptive decision-making in adolescents and depends on the context and nature of the peers. Here, we combine a longitudinal cohort design, functional neuroimaging, novel behavioral economic paradigms, and a model-based approach to examine how social information influences decision processes leading adolescents to make risky or safe choices, including substance use behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa use a cell-cell communication process called quorum sensing to orchestrate collective behaviors required for virulence and biofilm formation. QS relies on the group-wide detection of extracellular signal molecules called autoinducers. These studies will provide insight into the role played by two newly discovered regulators that control the response of activated quorum-sensing receptors, potentially providing key information for the development of new medicines to combat bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Using a model system of ERα in breast cancer, we will a) identify distinct types of ERα-regulated chromatin interacting foci including promoter-enhancer, enhancer-enhancer and enhancer-repressor looping foci; and b) identify 3D-regulated breast cancer cell identities and sensitive-resistant transition cell subpopulations. The successful completion of our project may result in the better understanding of the contribution of enhancer- enhancer interacting network towards to functions of various biological processes, in particular breast cancer endocrine resistance, and on how 3D chromatin structure governs the breast cancer sensitive cell subpopulations into resistant cell subpopulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment and dementia is a major source of disability in Parkinson disease and Dementia with Lewy bodies, yet how these symptoms develop and progress is not well understood. The objective of this proposal is to understand the role of the pathological protein alpha-synuclein in causing the dysfunction of cortical circuits that leads to cognitive impairments, as well as how changing the activity of circuits might impact the advancement of Parkinson disease associated pathology. This knowledge will be essential for designing clinical trials to treat symptoms of cognitive impairment, or even slow the progression of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Sepsis remains to be associated with a significant morbidity and mortality, and the development of a novel therapy is urgently needed. Neutrophils are the first-line defense leukocytes for microbial eradication, and the de novo generation of mature neutrophils with high effector functions are needed, but immature neutrophils are also released into the circulation to match a demand for neutrophil number. In this proposal, we will examine our hypothesis that CD11c would be a critical regulator of neutrophil maturation and effector functions and will also screen CD11c small molecule agonists and antagonists.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 plays roles in proton extrusion, pH homeostasis, and production of reactive oxygen species in a variety of cell types. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The function of S1P-signaling in AD is more complex than assumed and demands further investigation. Our research will test a novel hypothesis that the S1P transporter Spns2 contributes to AD pathogenesis by promoting microglial pro-inflammatory activation induced by AD-related stimuli. By focusing on Spns2, this proposal holds a unique premise to reveal novel aspects of S1P-signaling in AD

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Single-particle cryo-EM, a method of molecular structure research pioneered in the PI's lab, has been further developed with the inclusion of time-resolved techniques to allow capture and structure determination of short- lived states. A combination of standard and time-resolved techniques will be applied to elucidate processes in protein biosynthesis with fundamental significance to public health. In addition, a novel method of data analysis aiming at characterization of the dynamic behavior of molecules will be applied to large datasets of important membrane-associated molecules: rotary ATPase and Cystic fibrosis trans-membrane conductance regulator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The primary objective of the Northern California Acute Care Research Consortium (NORCARES) Hub is to facilitate the enrollment of a diverse population of patients into SIREN clinical trials. The highly adaptable design of NORCARES includes an innovative Co-Hub and multi-PI model, allowing for flexibility to maximize patient enrollment regardless of the study focus. In this project, we seek to be leaders in SIREN and train junior investigators for future leadership roles in multicenter emergency care clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is the severe lung disease that occurs in 10% of all preterm births. BPD results from a disruption in pulmonary vascular and alveolar growth. Our lab has been one of the first to demonstrate that vitamin D has striking pro- angiogenic effects in the distal vasculature of the developing lung. This current proposal will utilize animal models of BPD and vitamin D deficiency to study how vitamin D regulates vascular development in the fetal lung and how antenatal stress, especially in the setting of preterm birth, alters vitamin D signaling and contributes to the pathogenesis of BPD. This will help will lead to therapies that improve quality of life for infants with this severe lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 1 diabetes (T1D) accounts for ~5% of diabetes (20 million patients worldwide), and T1D patients are predicted to triple by 2050. There is no cure for T1D or means to determine the onset and progression of the disease. These proposed studies will elucidate key mechanisms underlying the development of T1D for the future development of novel therapeutics to prevent, delay the onset, and reduce progression of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the factors associated with outcomes along the hepatitis C care continuum and systematic evaluation of interventions to improve these outcomes, with particular attention to the complication of HIV coinfection, are essential for designing hepatitis C elimination strategies among people who inject drugs. While some empirical studies have evaluated efficacy or effectiveness of interventions to improve the hepatitis C care continuum, understanding the population level impact, cost-effectiveness, and generalizability of these interventions remains an important need for evidence- based policymaking. Thus, this proposal is relevant to NIH and NIDA’s mission of acquiring and applying new knowledge to improve health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Endosomal pathway dysfunction is a well-accepted feature in Alzheimer’s disease cellular pathophysiology. Lacking and urgently needed are biomarkers of this pathway that can detect endosomal dysfunction in living patients and potentially accelerate drug discovery. The proposed study is designed to develop such biomarkers, using a mouse model of SORL1 dysfunction, mouse and human neuronal cultures, as well as human biofluids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal infections are a global health concern, and are due to defects in the neonatal immune system’s ability to respond to and clear pathogens. We have experimentally modeled fetal, neonatal and infant immune system development under normal and inflammatory conditions to uncover important mechanisms controlling the maturation of immune responses in these settings. The success of the studies outlined in this proposal may lead to the identification of therapeutic targets that can improve survival and long-term outcomes related to neonatal inflammatory exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in four children with septic shock die despite receiving intensive care and antibiotics, and cardiac dysfunction seems to contribute to this high mortality rate. No treatments exist for cardiac dysfunction in sepsis, and our goal is to better understand the causes of cardiac injury in children with septic shock to facilitate development of new medications to help these children recover and survive. We will study these processes using human cardiac cells and human serum, rather than animal models, to improve the ability to translate discoveries back to the bedside to improve patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most debilitating side effects of cancer chemotherapy is cognitive impairment, including problems with attention, learning & memory, and executive functions. We have found that this condition is particularly prevalent in individuals who have inherited APOE4, which is also the strongest genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease. The experiments here use a novel mouse model of chemotherapy-treated APOE4 mice to identify the molecular mechanisms behind this combined effect of APOE4 and chemotherapy, and to test whether there are preventative treatments to reduce this condition in those undergoing treatment for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women are at elevated risk of developing psychosis during the menopause transition, but the clinical, demographic, and neural factors predisposing to that risk remain poorly understood. Prediction of risk for developing psychosis earlier in life has benefitted from the systematic study of the time period just preceding the onset of frank psychosis–the psychosis prodrome. We propose to study the prodrome both retrospectively and prospectively in women during the menopausal transition, with the goal of identifying specific risk factors for development of psychosis during this high-risk period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle stem cell transplantation is emerging as a promising strategy for treating muscle-associated trauma and disorders, but the paucity in their quantity limits their therapeutic potential. The inability to maintain and expand these cells ex vivo further compounds this challenge. This research will develop a geometrically asymmetric culture platform that enable long-term maintenance and expansion of muscle stem cells by directing cellular polarity, division, and fate determination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle regeneration is critical for maintaining muscle structure and function following damage; however, older adults have impaired tissue regeneration, which leads to age-related skeletal muscle tissue remodeling, deterioration, and loss of independence. Appropriate therapies to improve muscle regeneration in older adults are needed, but the development of therapies is limited by the current understanding of nutrient and metabolic requirements of the regenerative process. This research is directly relevant to the NIH mission because it aims to understand a potential therapeutic target, serine and glycine metabolism, for the overall improvement of skeletal muscle regeneration and, thus, for the improvement of skeletal muscle health in the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the leading cause of death in the US. This Training Program thus addresses a critical need to train individuals in cardiovascular epidemiology, ultimately to better prevent CVD. Our Training Program reflects the changing needs of our trainees in research in cardiovascular epidemiology and aims to produce independent cardiovascular epidemiologists in multidisciplinary research settings competent in traditional as well as novel epidemiological methods in CVD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for the Prevention and Treatment of Visual Loss (CPTVL) provides new discoveries for restoring vision and related brain functions, which are important to a Veteran’s independence and quality of life. This is done through creative and scientifically rigorous interactions between clinicians and scientists who perform research in three main focus areas: 1) Rehabilitation of Vision Loss, 2) Ocular Biomarkers for Rehabilitation of Central Nervous System Disease, and 3) Technology Development, including Automated Telemedical Assessment of Ocular Disorders and Assistive Technologies. Research is translated with the goal of rehabilitating and restoring visual function. Examples of disorders that are targeted for rehabilitation include glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, macular degeneration, traumatic brain injury, optic neuropathy, multiple sclerosis, light sensitivity, and migraine.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Musculoskeletal diseases are the most common and disabling of conditions for Veterans. More than 1 in 3 suffer from osteoarthritis, the most common cause of disability and pain and termination of service. Our CReATE Motion Center will directly address this clinical need, across the spectrum of disease, by fostering a critical mass of expertise and a culture of innovation at the CMC VAMC in Philadelphia and the Atlanta VAMC. We will build on our cutting-edge infrastructure, extensive scientific foundation, and culture of mentoring and collaboration to establish a VA-based pipeline to move next-generation regenerative therapies from the laboratory to the patients that need them. Our CReATE Motion Center will restore joint health and mobility to Veterans, fulfilling the promise of regenerative therapies in the 21st Century.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We hypothesize manipulating brain energy metabolism through a ketogenic diet (KD) will benefit Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients. To test this, we will randomize AD participants to a three-month KD or Therapeutic Lifestyles Changes (TLC) diet intervention. We additionally include biomarker-based measures to define how a KD affects participant physiology, and to identify KD-related mechanisms of action.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Substance use (SU) disorders collectively represent the single most preventable cause of disease, disability, and death in the United States. Veterans are at higher risk than the general population for complications related to SU. Chronic pain is a risk factor for opioid drug use and is compounded by the other SU. Although SU and chronic pain both have a heritable component, isolating specific genes that affect risk across substances and that may also affect risk for chronic pain has been hampered by small sample sizes and ambiguous phenotypes. We will use the Million Veteran Program sample with SU phenotypes based on longitudinal quantity-frequency data from the VA electronic health record, and novel techniques in genome- wide association computational analysis to overcome the limitations of previous work and advance the field by enhancing the screening, diagnosis and treatment of multi-SU and SU disorders. Finally, incorporating pain phenotypes will help to elucidate the genetic variation that contributes to their frequent co-occurrence with SU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the leading cause of non-traumatic disability of young adults, affecting over 1 million people in the USA. The cause of the disease is unknown, the mechanisms that underlie the pathology are poorly understood and treatments are only partially effective, necessitating innovative strategies to understand the disease and susceptibility factors. In the proposed study we will determine if unique miRNAs found in MS patients are potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the last decade, obesity has emerged a major public health challenge, with implications for several disease conditions, such as cardiovascular diseases, cancer and metabolic syndromes (e.g. type-2 diabetes and insulin resistance). This project investigates novel roles of angiogenesis-linked receptor, neuropilin 1 (Nrp1) in obesity-mediated dysfunctions. We propose that obesity and concomitant increase of circulating free fatty acids promote the expression and interaction of Nrp1 with insulin substrates, which impact vascular Nrp1 functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Binaural hearing (i.e. hearing with two ears) provides substantial benefits in complex listening environments. The proposed study will determine the contributions of different characteristics of auditory signals to binaural hearing. This will both deepen our understanding of the binaural auditory system and lay the groundwork for techniques that can help populations, such as cochlear implant users, who have difficulty making full use of binaural hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative One of major postulates for the pathophysiology of schizophrenia is that glutamatergic signaling is altered in critical regions of the brain. Here we propose that another integral component of the glutamatergic receptor system, called mGluR5, is dysregulated in schizophrenia. In this proposal, we will identify the underlying mechanisms for mGluR5 hypoactivity and its important role in glutamatergic signaling, and the etiologic underpinnings that leading to changes in mGluR5 signaling in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Maintaining telomeres is necessary for cancers to grow and while most cancers use telomerase to extend telomeres, some use the alternate lengthening of telomeres (ALT) mechanism. We have assembled a large panel of ALT+ patient-derived cancer models growing in the laboratory and we will compare these across various cancer types and to non-ALT cancers. As we hypothesize that ALT+ cancers have common mechanisms of resistance to chemotherapy and also common sensitivity to novel drugs, we will test both standard drugs and novel investigational drugs against ALT+ cancer models to inform future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Efforts to treat Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), the most common and deadly form of a large group of lung fibrotic diseases, have mostly targeted the scarring process. However, IPF is also characterized by the appearance of abnormal stem cell populations in areas of damage, a process known as metaplasia. The studies outlined in this proposal will test the idea that metaplasia can alter lung function in fibrotic diseases, and develop a pre-clinical pipeline to test therapies that can target metaplasia in patients with IPF.

PHR: Project Narrative. The ability of cells and organisms to maintain metabolic homeostasis is fundamental to their health and long-term survival. This project will use recently developed tools to understand the role of a metabolic protein that has been shown to enhance health and longevity. The resulting data will help to understand how complex metabolic pathways are intertwined and how they can be leveraged to improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is common, often disabling, and lacks pharmacologic treatment for its core symptoms: impairment in social communication and restricted/repetitive behavior. We propose to apply three novel statistical and functional approaches to interpret ASD's common polygenic influences, with an emphasis on assessing the convergence of (i) polygenic risk and (ii) the more than 70 genes that have been associated with ASD through exome sequencing studies. These activities will improve our understanding of the genetic underpinnings of ASD, strengthen biological and therapeutic hypotheses, and generate methods applicable to the study of other neuropsychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in membrane remodeling underlie debilitating diseases from cancer to neurological disorders, and because membrane trafficking vesicles serve as the cellular entry mechanism for both harmful pathogens and therapeutic drugs. Therefore, the proposed research on the basic physical mechanisms underlying membrane remodeling is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is envisioned that a fundamental understanding of membrane remodeling will enable therapeutic manipulation of membrane traffic and other points of intersection between membranes and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tectorial membrane (TM) plays important roles in frequency tuning and amplification of sound waves. The TM displays sophisticated ultrastructure and domain-specific organization of matrix architecture. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Research Mentoring Internship (RMI) Program at UC Santa Cruz offers mentored research training, financial support, and professional development to students pursuing careers in genomic science or in the analysis of the ethical, legal, and social implications of that research. The RMI improves equity and access to careers in genomic science by contributing to the number of academically talented and underrepresented minority (URM) undergraduate students who successfully complete degrees in genomic science. Our efforts are valuable in terms of social justice, and the students who graduate from our programs constitute a valuable contribution to the American workforce, bringing skill, talent, and diverse perspectives to fields of knowledge that promise to dramatically benefit human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Metabolic and chronic liver disease are among the leading causes of death in the US, and therefore creates a significant burden to the national health system. Cholestasis (the accumulation of bile acids) is one of the most common causes of chronic liver disease and there are limited options for treatments. Our discovery that ABCD3 regulates bile acid and lipid metabolism will advance our fundamental understanding of physiologic processes, elucidate mechanisms for current therapies and may reveal novel opportunities for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is highly associated with increased leukemia risk. A better understanding of how aging-associated inflammatory changes in the bone marrow microenvironment could promote leukemogenesis will be critical for the development of new prevention and treatment interventions that restore a healthy tissue landscape. While we may not be able to prevent the accumulation of oncogenic mutations in blood-forming hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells over a lifetime, modulating tissue microenvironments to reduce selection for oncogenically mutated cells could significantly reduce leukemia risk and improve health-span of our aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The majority of donor kidneys require cold storage prior to transplantation, but this process usually leads to renal damage. At least 20% of cadaver donor kidneys cannot be used, and many have suboptimal results, due to cold storage activating cellular pathways that damage kidney tissue. Our goal is to identify these cold storage- induced pathways and develop new therapeutic strategies to successfully prevent damage to increase viability and to improve kidney function after transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: The objective of this proposal is to develop, optimize and validate a novel noninvasive MRI method for creatine imaging to study muscle specific oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS). To validate and demonstrate the translational utility of the method, the effects of age, sex, race and physical activity on creatine metabolism in muscle will be measured. Successful accomplishment of the goals of this project will lead to a noninvasive diagnostic tool for studying abnormal muscle specific OXPHOS, without the invasiveness of biopsy-based approaches. In addition, the method can help evaluate the efficacy of potential therapies targeting creatine kinase metabolism in a variety of conditions including aging and myriad other conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcopenia represents a highly prevalent, unresolved medical issue in an increasing aging and sedentary population. A pharmacologic therapy for muscle loss does not exist, and current diet/exercise therapeutic approaches are often ineffective and/or unfeasible. Findings from these studies may lead to novel approaches for the treatment of skeletal muscle atrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Caloric restriction is emerging as a potential antiaging strategy, but diets are difficult to maintain; because pharmacological approaches leveraging the mTORC1 pathway have undesirable side effects, new antiaging therapeutic targets are needed. The transcription factor CEBPB plays a key role in aging phenotypes via changes in the relative levels of two forms of the protein, yet the molecular mechanisms these two isoforms mediate are not fully understood, limiting our ability to precisely perturb this pathway. Here we use high- throughput quantitative imaging to dissect the mechanisms of CEBPB isoforms functions, and deploy synthetic biology approach to monitor and perturb CEBPB function in individual cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black women with ovarian cancer have the worst survival of all racial and ethnic groups, and this disparity cannot be entirely explained by differences in access to care or guideline-adherent treatment. We propose to leverage established observational studies to investigate cross-population comparisons of tumor DNA methylation patterns, at both the global and cell-specific level, associated with survival among Black and White women with ovarian cancer. This work will advance the discovery of molecular targets among understudied minorities, informing targeted prevention strategies, clinical decision-making, and the development of personalized therapies to reduce mortality in Black women with ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV (PWH) use cannabis more than the general population, but its potential beneficial/negative effects on the brain have not been investigated. Here, we will determine whether cannabis has beneficial or negative effects on cognitive functions strongly linked to HIV risk behaviors in PWH compared with healthy participants. We will then utilize an animal model of HIV to determine the directionality of effects of acute and chronic administration, withdrawal from such cannabinoid treatments, as well as effects of antiretroviral therapy using consistent behavioral tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In this project, we will study Pitt-Hopkins Syndrome, a childhood genetic disorder characterized by severe neurological symptoms, including intellectual disability, motor delay, absence of speech, constipation, and autistic behaviors. Currently, there are no specific treatment or cure for this condition, in part because little is known about how the brains of affected children are impaired. We will use cells derived from Pitt-Hopkins Syndrome patients and cultivated in vitro to understand what is altered in neurons and other cell types in the brain and to test strategies to correct the mutated gene involved in the disease and ameliorate the impaired characteristics and symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: For the cochlea to function properly in the adult, multiple cell types must mature properly into specific cell types, including hair cells, supporting cells and neurons. This proposal seeks to define the molecular signaling pathways necessary for the final steps of cell maturation in the cochlea, steps that are currently not well understood. Deciphering these processes is critical for understanding hearing loss and for developing therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Yerkes National Primate Research Center (YNPRC) maintains a colony of Indian origin specific pathogen free (SPF), pedigreed and genetically characterized rhesus macaques to supply animals for the large portfolio of AIDS research conducted at the Center. YNPRC had over $25 million in grant funding for nonhuman primate (NHP) AIDS research during FY20 in which was a 20% increase in funding since FY2013 with approximately 39% of rhesus macaques allocated to external AIDS investigators. The SPF colony at the YNPRC Field Station supports this colony with expert leadership and management to maintain and grow this colony of animals in support of AIDS research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phage VP882 is the first discovered phage capable of detecting bacterial host-produced quorum-sensing communication molecules, called autoinducers. Autoinducer detection by phage VP882 drives its lysogeny to lytic transition, resulting in host lysis. The proposed work will combine genetic, biochemical, and structural approaches to provide a mechanistic understanding of cross-domain communication between vibriophage VP882 and its host, the global pathogen Vibrio cholerae; it will also lay the necessary foundation for engineering phages responsive to particular sensory cues for phage therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical indications for metformin have expanded from the treatment of Type 2 Diabetes to use as a second line therapeutic to insulin in pregnant women with gestational diabetes, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and preeclampsia. Data suggest that metformin crosses the placenta and equilibrates in fetal and maternal circulation, elevating concerns of unintended fetal harm. This proposal aims to elucidate the effect that developmental exposure to metformin and maternal overnutrition has on beta-cell function and mitochondrial health in the pancreatic islets of offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in the U.S. with few interventions that effectively modify disease course. Pulmonary rehabilitation is one notable exception; yet, this service is grossly underutilized, especially within low resourced healthcare settings that provide majority of the care for socially vulnerable populations with COPD. The proposed study will test an innovate low-resource, community- based pulmonary rehabilitation program with social supports for patients with symptomatic COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The goal of this proposal is to increase our understanding of the role of immune cells in the early adaptation process of cardiac stress. The results of these studies will provide a platform to develop therapeutic strategies to enhance the adaptive remodeling of the heart, while postponing or even preventing heart failure. Cardiovascular disease and heart failure are leading causes of death worldwide, and interventions that can transform pathological into physiological remodeling will have a major impact on disease progression after cardiac injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We establish a new basic science-clinical science consortium to assess how arsenic affects the maternal epigenome to increase risk of neural tube defects. We use biological samples collected from an epidemiological study in Bangladesh as well as in vitro methods using cutting-edge technologies, including whole genome bisulfite sequencing DNA methylation arrays. Additionally, we will investigate DNA methylation changes following a short course of high-dose folic acid supplementation among women who had a pregnancy affected by spina bifida.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder, affecting 6.2 million individuals and families in the United States emotionally and financially, with patients suffering from devastating non-cognitive, prodromal symptoms such as anxiety, depression, agitation, and sleep disturbances early in the disease followed by cognitive impairment. With an aging population and the dearth of disease-modifying therapies available, it is imperative to investigate the mechanisms that contribute to early AD. This proposal will test the hypothesis that tau-mediated disruptions in the locus coeruleus-norepinephrine (LC-NE) system underlie the development of prodromal symptoms and uncover molecular alterations associated with LC-NE dysfunctions to develop effective therapeutic targets for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Children and adolescents who receive outpatient mental health care have multiple problems and disorders, and their most pressing problems often shift during treatment. These challenges are addressed by a flexible new treatment program called FIRST, developed in collaboration with mental health clinicians and guided by five empirically supported principles of change (e.g., calming, problem solving), each applicable to treatment of depression, anxiety/OCD, trauma, and misconduct. The proposed study will provide the first randomized controlled effectiveness trial of this new practice-adapted transdiagnostic treatment, plus an inquiry into the process through which it may work and therapist factors that may strengthen or weaken its implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we test the hypothesis that biochemical pathways of relevance in the biology of aging can be coopted to treat and prevent obesity and its complications. We focus on the activation of fat mobilization and utilization by a process called mitohormesis, which is thought to promote longevity through alterations in nutrient metabolism and energy balance. Our results will provide new insights into and a new paradigm to approach the pathogenesis of obesity and its treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The rate of bone repair slows with aging resulting in substantial morbidity and even mortality. This proposal will use heterochronic parabiosis (two mice of a different age share a blood supply) to identify the specific macrophage cell subpopulations and the proteins they secrete that are responsible for the rejuvenation. Our results will inform the development of new therapies to improve fracture healing in older individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The role of obscurin and Obsl1 as key determinants for diastolic function This project investigates molecular determinants for the development of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), a disease that accounts for approximately 50% of heart failure hospital admissions in the US. Mice that lack obscurin/Obsl1 die prematurely and develop diastolic dysfunction, a key pathogenic feature of HFpEF. Using this novel genetic model of diastolic dysfunction, we aim to uncover novel mechanistic roles of obscurin/Obsl1 for mitochondrial function, their inﬂuence on the cardiac metabolism, and on sarcoplasmic reticulum proteins that determine cardiac calcium cycling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Hydronephrosis diagnosed in utero but persisting after birth (PNH) affects tens of thousands of infants each year in the United States, but its management is complicated by ambiguous reporting of hydronephrosis severity and a relatively limited understanding of predictors of disease outcome and knowledge of the disease’s natural history. The proposed research uses the largest known pediatric hydronephrosis cohort to develop a tool to translates free-text ultrasound reports into coded PNH grades, predict the 2-year outcome using 3-month baseline data, and apply sophisticated modeling techniques to simulate the disease’s natural history. Taken together, results from this proposal will lead to the development of a standardized management strategy for PNH and facilitate the candidate’s transition to an independent research career in the development, dissemination, and implementation of novel treatment and management strategies for pediatric urologic disease, beginning with pediatric hydronephrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with type 2 diabetes have 50-100% higher risk of dementia than elderly individuals without type 2 diabetes yet much remains to be learned regarding how to best mitigate this risk. The proposed research aims to understand how specific characteristics of long-term glycemic control (e.g. level, variance, cumulative exposure, trajectories) and classes of diabetes therapies impact risk of dementia while taking into consideration important contextual factors, such as diabetes complications, in a large population of elderly patients with type 2 diabetes. The results of this project will have direct clinical translation for glycemic targets and will inform approaches to prevention of cognitive impairment in this population which is already at elevated dementia risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: NARRATIVE Epigenetic clocks are widely used in geroscience but little known about their modifiability and behavior across the lifespan. Here we use a human cellular lifespan system that recapitulates key hallmarks of human aging (DNA methylation signatures, ccf-mtDNA, inflammation) to map individualized trajectories in the rate of epigenetic aging among cells from healthy women and men, in response to glucocorticoid stress, and to targeted mitochondrial dysfunction. These high-resolution longitudinal multi-system data will provide new insights into inter-individual differences in aging trajectories, the modifiability of epigenetic clocks, and provide causal evidence for the of mitochondrial dysfunction as a potential biological determinant of epigenetic aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed studies will help delineate the biological processes occurring in the lungs of pneumonia patients, with cases anticipated to cluster into different types of lung responses. The sub-types of pneumonia will be investigated using innovative experimental systems and defined at both microscopic and molecular levels within the lung. Differentiating pneumonia sub-types will mean that current and emerging treatments can be delivered more precisely, to target those most likely to benefit and spare those who may be harmed instead.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This U24 network on emotional well-being (EWB) will catalyze the emerging field of the plasticity of well-being and will showcase how well-being can be learned and the consequences of such skill development on physical and emotional health and on prevention of disease. The network will also train new investigators in this area and will engage established investigators to contribute to this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement Gene expression is tightly controlled in time and space and is governed by protein-nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) interactions. There are hundreds of DNA- and RNA-binding proteins that regulate gene expression and many are mutated in disease, but we lack facile approaches to map these proteins to their DNA/RNA targets. Here we propose to develop an innovative set of tools that will give every molecular biology lab the possibility to obtain comprehensive cell-type specific protein DNA/RNA interaction maps, a necessity to understand gene expression regulation and therefore disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nucleic acids (DNA and RNA) and their building blocks (nucleosides and nucleotides) play central roles in all cellular events and, as such, have immense impact on the emergence of diseases and, in turn, on human health. Studying such cellular events is complicated by the non-emissive nature of the natural nucleobases, which necessitates the development of new fluorescent analogs of nucleosides, nucleotides and oligonucleotides. Faithful emissive nucleoside surrogates, combined with powerful real-time fluorescence- based methods, will further the fundamental understanding of key biological processes related to disease development and will have long-term impact on improving human health by advancing diagnostic tools and facilitating drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene therapy approaches to treat Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), a fatal neuromuscular disease, are currently being tested in patients, but will require anti-inflammatory co-therapies. This application will test the anti-inflammatory properties of FDA-approved mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) antagonists, which have been shown to have benefits for dystrophic pathologies. The efficacy of these drugs will also be compared with current anti-inflammatory treatments that have serious side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE How decisions related to emotional behaviors are generated in the brain is not well understood. Here, we investigate the molecular and neural mechanisms of fear- and anxiety-related behaviors elicited by sensory signals, using innate defensive behaviors towards predators as a model. This study will critically contribute to our understanding of pre-programmed brain machinery that controls emotion-related behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  We found that honokiol can activate multiple members of the sirtuin deacetylase family, which are critical regulators of the intrinsic antioxidant system working in different parts of the cells such as the cytoplasm, mitochondria, and nucleus. In this proposal, we would like to verify the role of sirtuins in the protective effect of honokiol against cisplatin-unduced hearing loss. The results of the proposed study will lay the groundwork for a clinical trial, in which honokiol is used in parellel with the antitumor drugs (cisplatin) in chematherapy for hearing protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis in the elderly and there is currently no effective treatment. In our experiments we've found that lymphatic vessels in mice with age-related OA have insufficient drainage of fluids from their joints due to decreased production of one protein (VEGF-C) and increased breakdown of another (VEGFR3). Our research suggests that a combined treatment, adding the lacking protein VEGF-C with a drug that inhibits VEGFR3 breakdown may well improve lymphatic drainage and result in a successful therapy for OA in the elderly.

PHR: NARRATIVE The human gut microbiota is a crucial environmental factor that influences the development of immune tolerance in childhood, thus making early-life live microbial interventions an attractive approach for allergic disease prevention. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal addresses two major needs and gaps identified in the most recent National Eye Institute planning statement, namely (1) to "understand the molecular mechanisms and pathways in cone photoreceptors that have not been as extensively studied as rods", and (2) to "elucidate the molecular mechanisms that lead to photoreceptor degeneration". We will be using single-cell electrophysiology from mice with targeted gene deletions to investigate basic mechanisms in cone light sensitivity, and to identify the nature of the changes that occur during the course of cone photoreceptor degeneration. Our work should provide new information about the function and dysfunction of the cones, which are the cells in our eye primarily responsible for visual detection during most of our waking hours.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Organic Photoredox Catalysts for Synthetic Method Development Garret M. Miyake, Colorado State University, Department of Chemistry The proposed research aligns with the mission of the NIH because it describes the development of technologies that will enable new chemical reactivity critical to advance the discovery and manufacturing of medicines and polymeric materials, ultimately enhancing human health. Through the mechanistically guided design of organic photoredox catalysts, the proposed work aims to eliminate the contamination and sustainability concerns posed by precious metal photoredox catalysts while unlocking unprecedented reactivity and mechanistic insights. As such, this proposal is broadly relevant to public health, as it will increase fundamental understanding of chemical systems, processes, and materials integral to medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research focuses on prostate cancer, one of the most frequently diagnosed cancers in men in the United States, and will identify bacterial enzymes involved in androgen biotransformation and biosynthesis in addition to obtaining bacterial species harboring these enzymes. This knowledge will serve to develop novel agents acting as potential inhibitors for the bacteria themselves and/or their androgen related enzymes, which could have a major impact on prostate cancer progression due to androgen bioavailability from bacterial sources. The project supports the foundation of an innovative approach to slow or prevent prostate cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: public health relevance in SARDs, affecting well over 20% of the general population. Further, the etiology and features of PASC in SARDs may be unique because of differences in their immune responses to infection and predisposition to autoimmunity and fibrosis.  These studies will comprehensively investigate the immunologic and clinical outcomes after COVID-19 in patients with SARDs. To achieve our aims, we have assembled a cohort of vaccinated SARDs, systematically identified all SARDs with COVID-19, and are prospectively enrolling patients into an observational study. In the first aim, we will investigate risk for breakthrough infection after vaccination among RA patients on immunosuppressants. We will follow SARO patients acutely infected with COVID-19 to determine whether immunosuppressants prolong viral shedding that may result in viral evolution. In the second aim, we will measure autoantibodies as well as antibodies to pathogens to determine changes induced by COVID-19 and identify antibody profiles associated with PASC among SARDs. In the third aim, we will obtain chest imaging and respiratory phenotyping to determine if COVID-19 may induce fibrotic lung disease in RA patients.  Dr. Jeffrey Sparks (Assistant Professor of Medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School, HMS) and Dr. Zachary Wallace (Assistant Professor of Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital, HMS) will lead these studies as Principal Investigators. Dr. Sparks and Dr. Wallace are rheumatologists and research leaders related to SARDs and the COVID-19 pandemic. The PIs have assembled a cohort of all SARO patients with confirmed COVID-19 in the Mass General Brigham system, composed of 2 large tertiary care centers and 12 community hospitals. They are prospectively enrolling these patients after COVID-19 to study PASC. These studies have high potential for impactful results related to risk of breakthrough infection and formation of variants, determining humoral immune correlates of PASC, and determining how respiratory viral diseases may impact SARDs patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The strong and irreversible ototoxicity significantly limits the clinical usage of aminoglycosides, a class of highly potent, broad-spectrum antibiotics capable of treating multiple life-threatening infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE Mutations in the sodium channel gene SCN8A result in a severe epileptic syndrome designated SCN8A-DEE, Developmental and Epileptic Encephalopathy, that is characterized by early onset seizures, profound intellectual disability, and impaired movement. We pioneered an antisense-oligonucleotide (ASO) drug treatment that prevents seizures and extends lifespan in a preclinical mouse model. We propose to develop improved viral and CRISPR treatments with longer-term effectiveness and reduced potential for side effects, and to elucidate the unexplored role of the cerebellum in the co-morbidities of movement and cognition in observed in individuals with SCN8A-DEE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project utilizes single-cell RNA sequencing data and a novel damage model that synchronizes the regenerative responses of supporting cells during proliferative sensory hair cell regeneration in the chicken hearing organ, the basilar papilla. Among the identified signaling pathways is one essential for S-phase entry of supporting cells during hair cell regeneration, and it is proposed to translate the findings towards adult mammals and evaluate regeneration in vestibular and cochlear organs. Finally, the re-establishment of proper hair cell-type specificity, hair bundle differentiation and function, tonotopic integration, and neural connection of regenerated avian hair cells will be characterized in-depth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Our ability to predict the sensory consequences of our actions plays a critical role in our day to day life. In the auditory system, such predictions assist us in listening to the sound of our own voice when we speak, allowing us to quickly correct any errors that we might detect. However, problems with this self-monitoring, for example after hearing loss, can lead to difficulties in speaking properly, and a better understanding of this process will lead to new approaches for hearing, speech, and other communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Food insecurity, poor nutrition, and economic disadvantage are critical social determinants of health that contribute to disparities in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), a serious diet-sensitive chronic disease affecting more than 20% of food insecure adults. There is a demonstrable need for food-focused interventions to address the diet quality of persons with, or at risk of, T2DM. Completion of our pilot study will produce recruitment, retention, adherence, and cost data for a future definitive randomized controlled clinical trial, bringing us closer to our long-term goal of a tested, efficacious model of diabetes care coordinated across Federally Qualified Health Centers and food bank networks.
