IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Callous-unemotional (CU) behavior is a multidimensional construct composed of low empathy, prosociality, and guilt behaviors that predicts severe conduct problems, violent crime such as homicide, victimization by peers, substance use disorders, and global impairment. This project will investigate the developmental neurobiology of emerging CU behavior (i.e., CU behavior and its precursors) by identifying neural correlates and risk and protective factors for emerging CU behavior during infancy and toddlerhood—when empathy, prosociality and guilt are rapidly developing. Elucidating the processes that underlie emerging CU in infancy and toddlerhood will have implications for informing the most promising targets of preventative intervention during developmental periods in which brain development and behavior may be most malleable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individual social needs—including food, housing, and transportation—are associated with biopsychosocial outcomes in a range of contexts and populations, but clinicians need to know more about how social needs affect cancer patients and their informal caregivers. This study will examine how the social needs of breast and gynecologic cancer patients and their caregivers affect both patient and caregiver outcomes in the year after diagnosis. Findings will inform targeted screening and intervention efforts to addresses the mental health and social needs of patients and caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a major cause of morbidity and mortality (6th leading cause of death in the United States). African American adults are at disproportionally high risk, and chronic inflammation may be a key biological risk factor. The proposed work will assess specific innate and adaptive immune cells, and genes expressed in these cells, and determine whether they are associated with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and dementia risk among African Americans from the population-based Jackson Heart Study, as well as target genes and biological mechanisms in immune cells for genetic variants previously associated with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulated prefrontal cortex-dependent cognition is associated with multiple behavioral disorders. Our ability to treat this dysfunction is hindered by a limited understanding of the neural mechanisms that underly prefrontal dependent cognitive function. Towards this goal, and building on recent observations in our laboratory, the proposed studies take a multidisciplinary approach to better understand neural mechanisms involved in the cognitive actions of prefrontal corticotropin releasing factor (CRF) neurons and the underlying circuit mechanisms in male and female rats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) preventive therapy reduces TB disease and death among people with HIV, even those receiving antiretroviral therapy. Despite 30 years of knowledge of the benefit of TB preventive therapy, it remains poorly implemented, with 10-30% of eligible individuals in low and middle income countries actually receiving it. The goal of this research is to test an implementation strategy based on choice architecture to make preventive therapy prescribing the routine, “default” approach and in doing so to overcome current barriers to prescribing during HIV care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A significant barrier in developing effective therapies to prevent restenosis is our lack of understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling endothelial cell regeneration during injury. This application seeks to remove this critical roadblock by bringing information associated to how, where, for how long and under which circumstances endothelial cells are induced to proliferate in the context of a fully functional vessel. Our proposal addresses the exciting possibility that manipulation of specific pathways could reset the entry of endothelial cells into a proliferative state and represent a powerful approach to address vascular repair in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic and non-traumatic musculoskeletal disorders are responsible for substantial morbidity, pain and disability, affecting athletes, soldiers, active working people and the elder population. We propose to generate suturable 3D vascularized muscle tissues from human pluripotent stem cells derived myogenic precursor cells (iPSC-MPCs) embedded in biomimetic biomaterials using advanced bioprinting techniques. The successful development of this technology will be applicable to other areas of regenerative medicine and can potentially be utilized for the treatment of skeletal muscle loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Natural products hold a crucial role in developing novel molecular tools, such as pharmaceutical agents and probes. Specifically, they provide a major driving force for discovering new chemotherapeutics and are the primary source of compounds for the effective treatment of cancer and infectious diseases. The proposed research aims to develop new strategies and methods to prepare and study promising small bioactive molecules based on complex natural products that are not readily accessible yet would be highly desirable if brought within the realm of medicinal chemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative In spite of decades of study, the interoceptive sense of movement remains poorly understood. This ambiguity prevents us from understanding the basic nature of the relationships between our reflexes and voluntary actions, between the predictions our brains make about how our bodies move and how we actually sense those movements, and between how our brains feel movement and the neural circuitry that makes this happen. Everything we learn about kinesthesia in this context is directly translatable into our clinical care model for advanced neural-machine interface amputees and individuals with stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Foxp3+ regulatory T cells (Tregs) are potent suppressors of inflammation, including allergic inflammation that underlies the most common type of asthma. We have found that allergen-specific Tregs that persist in the lung are critical for suppressing the recall response to allergen but their numbers appear to wane over time. The goal of this project therefore is to understand the mechanisms of resident Treg cell persistence and function in the allergic lung in order to enhance the durability and function of resident Treg as a new treatment strategy for asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart function vitally relies on well-controlled intracellular calcium regulation and abnormalities in this regulation can cause life-threatening arrhythmias and contractile dysfunction. This research project is focused on the main calcium handling protein SERCA. This research proposal is relevant to public health, as SERCA represents an attractive candidate for therapeutic targeting to improve calcium regulation and myocardial contraction in the diseased heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: There is an urgent need to reverse the troubling losses from the physician-scientist pool, and to this problem, we have designed a physician scientist training program at the Medical College of Wisconsin that will recruit and train the next generation of physician scientists. Trainees will be immersed in a well-resourced and supportive program that is designed with specific milestones, training, and metrics. This will enable them to lead and complete research projects and acquire the skill set needed to successfully compete for grants to further their career as a physician-scientist junior faculty at the Medical College of Wisconsin or another academic institution in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Deep learning (DL) via artificial intelligence (AI) neural networks is a powerful approach to construct accurate predictive computational models with applications across all life sciences. Existing models are biased because of an underlying assumption that the data used for training these DL networks are independent of each other and have been drawn from an identical distribution, which is untrue of biological datasets where samples are interdependent. This project will develop novel neural network architectures as powerful DL tools, made available as reusable software modules that can improve existing models with only a few lines of programming code, and will ultimately enable the generation of more accurate predictions and improve our ability to interpret biomedical data and what the models have learned which will be invaluable for study and treatment of human disease with an unprecedented degree of automation and precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometrial cancer survivors are a rapidly growing population with complex healthcare needs. Coordination of care between oncologists, gynecologists, primary care physicians, and other specialists may help to ensure that survivors receive the appropriate healthcare services to improve their long-term health. Our study will investigate whether greater care coordination after endometrial cancer is associated with several critical health outcomes, and will inform the development of interventions that seek to enhance the delivery of survivorship care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Intravenous lipid emulsions (ILEs) are an antidote to local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), a life-threatening syndrome caused by anesthetic overdose that often presents as seizures and cardiovascular instability. Intralipid®, the prototypical ILE of long-chain triglycerides derived from soybean oil, and other emulsions reverse local anesthetic-induced mitochondrial dysfunction in cardiac models, but this mechanism has not been explored in the context of central nervous system dysfunction. My preliminary data demonstrates surprisingly that Intralipid® can power neuronal synaptic function in the absence of glucose, and my proposal will systematically investigate the metabolic effects of ILE components to identify the mixture most capable of reversing neurotoxicity in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance  Prediabetes and type 2 diabetes result from progressive dysfunction of pancreatic endocrine beta cells; we have identified a secreted factor made in the exocrine pancreas that can protect against the loss of beta cell function. In this proposal, we focus on revealing new mechanisms involved in beta cell function. Understanding how this secreted factor carry out its protective role in beta cells will inform on how best to target it for diabetes prevention/treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolism of nutrients is misregulated in many diseases, including cancer. Certain metabolic pathways appear to sense the flow of nutrients through the pathway, or flux, instead of the concentration of nutrients, but the mechanism of this has been unclear. This project will investigate a novel potential mechanism for sensing metabolic flux, potentially leading to the identification of new targets for treating metabolic misregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Researchers have discovered new types of cells, called “senescent cells”, that are suspected to be involved in aging. We plan to use novel technologies we developed to find out how these cells develop, how they damage normal tissues, and how to kill them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular metabolism allows cells to grow, develop, repair damage, and respond to environmental changes, which is fundamental to life. Altered cellular metabolism contributes to the pathogenesis of many common diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, and autoimmune disorders, which are prevalent in Oklahoma. This Center for Cellular Metabolism Research in Oklahoma (CMRO) Phase I COBRE will create and nurture excellence in cellular metabolism in Oklahoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Impaired bone repair is a major public health burden. There are over 12 million fractures per year in the U.S., with up to 10% having impaired healing, resulting in substantial patient morbidity and societal costs. This research will identify genes that regulate intramembranous bone regeneration. The results of this project have the potential to lead to a novel treatment for this common disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteocytes serve as the major orchestrator of skeletal metabolism and many pathologic or disease conditions can now be ascribed to disrupted osteocyte functions. This proposal describes an innovative and comprehensive approach to investigate the osteocytic role of the transcription factor SP7. Ultimately, the long-term goal of this study is to determine not only how osteocyte-enriched genes function in bone disease, but also to enable the development of next generation therapeutics for skeletal diseases that target osteocyte development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in United States and causes more deaths than all cancers combined. Although cardiac ischemia is inexplicably tied to acid-base regulation and Cl- homeostasis in the heart, the mechanism remains incompletely understood. This proposal aims to reveal a missing molecular link between Cl- homeostasis and acid-base regulation in the heart. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fasting and caloric restriction are effective to treat patients with pre-diabetes or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), but intensive lifestyle changes are difficult for many to implement and sustain. We discovered a key pathway in the liver, which is activated during fasting, and which is sufficient to treat pre- diabetes and NAFLD in mice. In this proposal, we will define how Arg2 mediates its effects, and examine bring forth new therapies that mimic the actions of Arg2 to ultimately treat obesity-related metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal will provide critically-needed insight into the cell types responsible for repair and maintenance of distal mouse and human lung. Using several state of the art techniques, we will identify the course of differentiation of distal lung epithelial progenitors to reveal progenitor identities and signaling pathways involved in regenerative response to injury. Knowledge gained through this study will clarify failed regenerative pathways in chronic lung diseases and aid in developing novel therapies and treatments for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is a major public health problem in American children, but effective strategies to prevent the development of childhood asthma are not yet available. In an ongoing, diverse cohort of U.S. children (53% African-American or Hispanic) with a history of severe bronchiolitis, the investigators will elucidate the mechanisms of developing asthma and define subtypes (endotypes) by integrating genome, metabolome, and microbiome data. This research aims to identify novel approaches for primary prevention of childhood asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) are used to be readily treatable bacterial infections with the over-the-counter topical antimicrobial creams. With the emergence of both hospital- and community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA; the so-called “superbug”) and multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (MDPA), SSTIs can be serious and life-threatening because these bacteria are invasive and toxigenic. We propose to develop a broad-spectrum topical antimicrobial cream based on bismuth oxide (Bi2O3) nanoparticles to combat SSTIs caused by multidrug-resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative University of Utah Health will offer the Utah Stimulating Access to Research in Residency (Utah StARR) R38 Program to resident-investigators from six residency programs including Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Neurology, Medicine-Pediatrics, Obstetrics and Gynecology, and Pediatrics with the goal of transitioning resident-investigators to successful careers as clinician-investigators to conduct clinical, translational, community-engaged, and/or health services research. Trainees will be provided didactic coursework in research methods, leadership training and career development, and extensive mentoring throughout the program. The proposed outcome of the research training program is to increase the number of resident- investigators from primary-care serving and related specialties engaged in research aimed at reducing health disparities in cardiovascular, pulmonary, and related diseases impacting disadvantaged populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug development for autism is limited by our lack of understanding of how genes that contribute to autism risk function as members of complex signaling networks. Here, we investigate how autism genes alter signaling in three mouse models of autism using the network biology of protein interactions. We test hypothesis-driven strategies to correct ASD-linked signaling deficits and ask if treatment normalizes neuron function and behavior in mouse models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The usage of different transcription start sites (TSSs) is a fundamental way of gene regulation that can lead to different protein products with distinct function and stability or different transcripts with different regulatory responses in producing the same protein. Therefore, it is important to understand how different TSSs of a gene is selected in different cells, tissues, and developmental stages and reveal key genes that regulate this selection. The proposed research project is relevant to the mission of the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) because it will advance our understanding of the TSS selection mechanism with broad medical implication.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Evidence-based guidelines inform the resuscitation of infants after birth, yet implementation of evidence- based practices and national guidelines is not uniform. Organizational culture (the beliefs, perceptions, and values in an organization) is an important and understudied factor in implementation of evidence-based practices for resuscitation. This proposal seeks to adapt and validate a resuscitation-specific measure of organizational culture, examine the association between organization culture and implementation of evidence- based practices, and thereby identify potential opportunities to improve neonatal resuscitation process and ultimately patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: T-cells are a type of white blood cell that are needed to fight infections and can be artificially programmed to destroy cancer cells in patients. The goal of this project is to define whether increasing the activity of the gene BCL11B will expedite recovery of T-cells after bone marrow transplantation and improve the ability of programmed T-cells to kill cancer cells. The potential benefit of the knowledge gained from this project is the development of new methods to improve the recovery of the immune system after bone marrow transplantation, and ways to more effectively program T-cells to fight cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative  The central objectives of this application are: (a) to develop new, reliable, and efficient, methodologies that enable the construction of stereochemically rich scaffolds and (b) to achieve the concise chemical syntheses of naturally occurring small molecules that possess intricate chemical structures. The results of these efforts should lead to the development of new strategies and tools for the preparation of various molecules of importance, including medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Several neurological and mental health disorders have notable sex differences in their prevalence or severity, which can be further amplified when co-morbidity is considered. Here we study the lateral habenula - rostromedial tegmental nucleus - midbrain dopamine pathway, which is implicated in many of these disorders, and the effect of circulating sex hormones on its function. This research will help us to understand whether this brain circuit underlies sex differences in several recalcitrant mental health disorders and may lead to new forms of treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Although screening is a known strategy to facilitate early detection of autism spectrum disorders (ASD), screening during routine toddler pediatric check-ups is not universal. The current study will examine the feasibility of ASD screening in childcare centers, by exploring barriers and facilitators of systematic screening by childcare providers, and examining the performance of a widely used screening tool in this novel setting. Screening in childcare centers represents an important complementary strategy to increase access to early ASD screening, particularly for underserved children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is an independent risk factor for the development of chronic kidney disease, but current strategies for the prevention and treatment of obesity related kidney injury are incompletely effective. Lipotoxicity is a recently identified process that contributes to kidney injury in the setting of obesity, but the mechanisms underlying lipotoxicity in the kidney are not fully understood. This studies in this proposal will investigate the role of ATP6AP2 in promoting renal lipotoxicity with the goal of providing a basis for novel therapeutic strategies in the management of obesity related kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, schizophrenia, suicidal depression, and behavioral addictions all include components of dysregulated reward processing and impulsivity. The etiology of these disordered phenotypes can occur during adolescence when the underlying neural circuits are undergoing maturation. The proposed research will determine the timecourse and neural-circuit mechanisms of a pathological developmental trajectory and identify novel intervention and treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The primary focus of this research proposal is for the discovery and elucidation of novel biochemical pathways for the biosynthesis and metabolism of simple and complex carbohydrates in the human gut microbiome. The metabolic diversity within these bacteria contributes significantly to the maintenance of human health and physiology. The determination of the substrate and reaction diversity contained within these newly discovered metabolic reactions will provide unique insights into the molecular mechanisms for the evolution and development of novel enzymatic activities and will provide potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa poses a major threat to human health due to limited treatment options and its ability to become resistant to antibiotics. The discovery of new drugs targeting P. aeruginosa and other Gram- negative bacteria is especially challenging due to the exclusion of most small molecules by an impermeable cell wall, coated by an electronegative matrix of lipopolysaccharide (LPS). This proposal aims to develop anti- pseudomonal LPS transport inhibitors that may improve human health, but can simultaneously be leveraged to elucidate the regulatory pathways underpinning LPS transport in P. aeruginosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Myristoylation facilitates proteins’ association with the cell membrane, and their encapsulation into extracellular vesicles. This project will produce extracellular vesicles encapsulating Cas13d/crRNA ribonucleoprotein by Cas13d myristoylation and incorporating the spike protein into the EVs membrane to confer transfection specificity to target SARS-CoV-2 infected respiratory epithelial cells. The generated extracellular vesicles will provide an avenue for the treatment of COVID-19.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall Section The Mutant Mouse Resource and Research Center (MMRRC) at UC Davis (MMRRC-UCD) is the flagship of the MMRRC Consortim, and serves a leading role in facilitating research by identifying, acquiring, evaluating, characterizing, cryopreserving, and distributing mutant mouse strains to qualified biomedical investigators. The MMRRC-UCD ensures that scientifically valuable transgenic, knockout, and other genetically-engineered mutant mice and related biomaterials of human disease, development, and behavioral abnormalities are maintained for investigational use across the biomedical scientific community. The MMRRC-UCD provides expertise, infrastructure, resources and services to preserve mouse strains in perpetuity, protect them from catastrophic loss, avoid genetic and phenotypic drift, prevent pathogenic contamination and disease, and conduct resource-related research to advance the study of mutant mice as models of human disease, including cancer. The MMRRC-UCD fosters and promotes the discovery of new diagnostics, treatments, and prevention strategies against human diseases, including cancer, optimizes reproducibility of studies, and assures scientific rigor and transparency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Soil-transmitted nematodes (intestinal parasitic nematodes) are one of the most prevalent human parasites on earth, causing significant morbidity, especially in children; they are major drivers of impoverishment in developing countries. This application uses a novel, newly developed drug discovery pipeline and high- throughput screen (HTS) platform to screen two drug libraries for highly active compounds that target divergent intestinal nematode parasites. At the end of the proposed research, we expect to have discovered new compound(s) that have good-excellent therapeutic activity against the parasites in infected animals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an unmet need in the HIV vaccine field for immunogens that consistently elicit potent and broad neutralizing antibodies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduced T cell mediated immunity is a prominent feature of aging with important clinical consequences and is partially driven by diminished thymic function and altered naïve T cell development. Recent evidence suggests heterogeneity amongst naïve T cells that are generated during different developmental windows, but little is known about the intrathymic crosstalk that imprints naïve T cell character. This proposal focuses on understanding the novel role of epithelial-derived IL-13 in establishing medullary thymic function during early adulthood and how these pathways change during thymic aging, which may inform efforts to protect existing thymic function or reverse thymic involution to maximize T cell mediated immunity in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Persistent HPV infections alone are linked to ~ 4.5% of the total cancer incidence worldwide and there are no targeted therapies for HPV-related cancers. We have large body of literature highlighting the function of NRF2 in HPV- related cancers, however, we have a poor understanding of how NRF2 is activated in HPV-infected cells. In this proposal, we will determine the molecular mechanism by which HPV E1 activates NRF2 and the first high-resolution view of the KEAP1-E1 interface will pave the way for structure-based design of novel therapeutics targeting this critical interaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In this proposal we seek to characterize a novel effector from the pathogenic bacteria Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaires’ disease. We will explore the mechanism of action of the effector and its host targets in order to define certain aspects of molecular basis of L. pneumophila infection. We believe our work will pave the way for an improved understanding of the bacterial pathogenesis and creation of novel antimicrobial agents for the benefit of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as about 1 in 8 women in the U.S. will be diagnosed with breast cancer in her lifetime, and about 3 in 4 of those women will experience clinically significant sexual morbidity. Relevant to the mission of the NCI, this study aims to improve cancer care by establishing an Internet intervention that provides breast cancer survivors the greatest sexual health benefit for the least burden. Findings will also improve cancer-related sexual morbidity intervention science by evaluating how intervention components work, for whom they work best, and how they can be made more engaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The Children’s National Stimulating Access to Research in Residency (CNStARR) Program is a rigorous mentored program of career development and research training for pediatric residents from Children’s National Hospital and internal medicine residents from the George Washington University. CNStARR expands our existing capacity to recruit and retain outstanding pediatric and internal medicine residents with demonstrated potential and interest in pursuing research careers in content areas of interest to the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI), particularly in the areas of asthma and airway disease, congenital heart disease, and hematology and immunology. The overall goal of CNStARR is to develop independent clinician-investigators and academic leaders in scientific domains of relevance to NHLBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The sympathetic nervous system controls many important functions in the heart, including metabolism, through alpha-1 and beta-adrenergic receptors. In this proposal, we will pursue our novel preliminary data to determine whether and how alpha-1A adrenergic receptors regulate fatty acid oxidation and oxidative phosphorylation to provide energy for the heart. We also will continue our ongoing exploration of whether drugs that activate alpha-1A adrenergic receptors might be effective treatments for heart failure, a condition in which the heart has an insufficient supply of energy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Cryptococcus neoformans is a pathogenic fungus that causes fatal meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised individuals including HIV/AIDS patients. In this project, we will study the dynamic interactions between C. neoformans and mononuclear phagocytes in the brain in vivo. The study will facilitate the development of therapeutic strategies aimed at clearance of fungal infection in the brain by targeting brain mononuclear phagocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Structured RNA elements are essential for viability and virulence of pathogenic bacteria and viruses and therefore represent attractive targets for small molecule drugs. Massive ongoing efforts are focused on identifying RNA-targeting small molecules by high-throughput screening and functional assays; however, the binding of the candidate molecules to RNA cannot be directly assessed in vivo. We propose to develop a novel methodological approach for capturing and identifying small molecules that bind to the RNA in vivo, in live bacterial cells, and apply this method for finding cognate ligands for non-coding RNAs in pathogenic bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Genome instability is one of the critical drivers of normal and premature aging. This proposal aims to dissect the role(s) of genome maintenance by the Werner syndrome helicase (WRN) and to determine how the loss of WRN results in the accelerated aging phenotypes found in Werner syndrome (WS) patients. Successful completion of the proposed aims will provide a deeper insight into the pathophysiology of WS and WRN’s roles in preventing genome instability and cellular senescence during normal aging .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The thalamus and its subdivisions called nuclei play a critical role not only as a relay to the cerebral cortex but also in memory, emotion, consciousness, and arousal and have been implicated in many neurological and psychiatric disorders. Thalamic nuclei are not easily visualized in conventional MRI and specialized methods proposed for visualization and segmentation of thalamic nuclei are still not accurate, especially for small nuclei. The novel methods for improved visualization and automated segmentation of thalamic nuclei developed in this grant will help identify biomarkers with high sensitivity and specificity to be used in future studies for the identification, evaluation, and monitoring of treatment strategies in different conditions like Alzheimer’s disease, schizophrenia, and essential tremor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Summary The Clinical Trial Concept in the Oncology Landscape (CTC) is a virtual and in-person, hybrid course designed to educate oncology trainees and junior faculty from any cancer specialty in applying Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and scientific reasoning into effective clinical trial design. The course will accept junior oncologists and fellows/residents in an oncology specialty, who are novice in cancer clinical research. The course will deliver in Part 1, The Fundamentals of Clinical Research, a semester long virtual immersive educational experience across all areas of cancer clinical research, then culminate in an in-person Trial Concept Writing Camp (Part 2) during the annual American Association of Cancer Institute (AACI) Clinical Research Innovation (CRI) meeting where participants will be mentored by experienced clinical investigators from different AACI member institutions during which time, they will finalize a clinical trial concept (also called letter of intent (LOI)), the end product of this course. Participants are selected through a competitive application process consisting of a CV, personal statement, letter of support from a local clinical research mentor, and a career development plan. Accepted participants will first receive scientific and GCP training over 20 virtual sessions covering the 6 major modules of protocol development that encompass the eleven domains of clinical trial expertise, including oncology, science, medicine, business/negotiation, accounting, statistics, pharmacy, pharmacology, laws and regulations, ethics, and clinical trial management. The curriculum will be loaded on a web portal developed for educational purposes under another U24 NCI award to OSUCCC. The virtual training will use a flipped classroom approach to maintain participant attentiveness. At the CRI meeting, participants will interact with Key Faculty mentors, nationwide experts in clinical research, who will help them complete a realistic concept form that meets scientific standards. Participants will take part in pre- and post-tests to determine the cogency of the CTC curriculum for their professional practice, and the effectiveness of the course logistics. They will complete the course by submitting a finalized clinical trial concept to the CTC course directors. Afterwards, they should be able to use their concept to develop a full protocol at their own institutions or though the NCI clinical research networks or other clinical trial networks. After the course, public data will be used to track participants’ career trajectories to determine the long-term effects of the course on their careers, working with Academics Analytics, a company contracted with OSU. Impact. Investigators must apply GCP and the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH) guidelines to the design and scientific approach of their clinical research. The basics of clinical research are not taught in medical schools or residencies. The pool of clinical investigators has also decreased in the US, creating a serious shortage of clinical trial experts. At the same time, there has been an explosion of biological discoveries and technological advances. This innovative and necessary CTC course will address the need for thorough and specific training on clinical trial design and execution to eventually benefit patients with cancers and support the professional development of junior oncology faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A growing appreciation of the clinically relevant interactions between the brain and the immune system has reshaped our understanding of the pathophysiology of mental disorders while providing new insights into their prevention and treatment. This proposal addresses how the brain vasculature interacts with the immune system to impact the brain and behavior during development and in response to an environmental “second hit; all in the context of a condition closely replicating neuropsychiatric disorders, the 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. We propose to correct these abnormalities by interventions targeting dysfunction within the brain-immune axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation contributes to venous thrombosis, and suppression of inflammation may prevent or resolve venous thrombosis. The current proposal investigates the mechanism by which a newly identified inflammatory signaling pathway promotes venous thrombosis. The knowledge gained from our proposed studies will provide new insights into how inflammation contributes to thrombosis and aid in developing new drugs to treat venous thrombosis without increasing bleeding risk, a common problem associated with current anticoagulation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood obesity is a persistent epidemic in the United States, yet virtually no effective preventive strategies target the childcare setting where children eat 75% of their meals. ONE PATH will test the effect of adding responsive feeding and appetite regulation components to an existing, evidence-based program that intervenes on the childcare setting environment. The proposed research will evaluate whether ONE PATH increases responsive feeding in the classroom and home settings and promotes child awareness of their hunger/fullness to prevent overeating and unhealthy weight gain among families with children living in rural poverty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common aortic pathology and accounts for 10,000 deaths annually in the United States. This proposal investigates the development and use of peptide amphiphile nanofibers for targeting unique extracellular matrix features found in AAAs. This technology will serve as the foundation for a targeted therapeutic to prevent, diagnose, and/or regress AAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE In Bipolar Disorder, rates of suicide attempt and completed suicide are critically high; however, there are no existing medications that have been developed specifically to decrease the burden of suicide. Previous suicide attempt is a primary predictor of completed suicide; thus, there is a critical need to identify molecular mechanisms that underlie suicidal behavior in bipolar disorder, which could lead to new therapeutic targets for more effective treatments for suicidal behavior in both men and women. We propose an innovative approach using positron emission tomography brain scanning alongside symptom and cognitive assessments of individuals with bipolar disorder to study a novel target, the glutamatergic receptor mGluR5, which has been newly implicated in suicidal behavior in bipolar disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Iatrogenic hypoglycemia is the most prominent barrier to the safe, effective management of blood sugar in people with type 1 diabetes due to periodic over-insulinization. During insulin-induced hypoglycemia, glucagon secretion is diminished in type 1 diabetes which, in turn, reduces hepatic glucose production and increases the depth and duration of hypoglycemic episodes. We have observed that the naturally occurring protein C-peptide increases glucagon secretion in dogs during insulin-induced hypoglycemia, which increases hepatic glucose production; the experiments in this application will shed light on the translation of this finding to the human.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project uses a multimodal, longitudinal approach to uncover the neurobiology of psychosocial stress in human opioid use disorder, with potential to yield novel biomarkers that can be used to identify individuals who are especially vulnerable to stress-related relapse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To fully leverage the potential of the child care setting for childhood obesity prevention, initiatives must not intervene solely at the child care level, but rather they should also address the health needs of the child care providers. Providers suffer disproportionately high rates of obesity and their own poor eating and physical activity behaviors reduce their confidence and ability to model and promote healthy lifestyle behaviors to children. Go NAPSACC’s weight management program offers a highly implementable, scalable, and sustainable strategy that would improve our understanding of how child care providers own weight and health behaviors impact child care- based obesity prevention initiatives and, if effective, would optimize obesity prevention in the child care setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Inflammation is the primary cause of cell death and organ dysfunction in many diseases. Research proposed in this application will open the possibility of using acute intravenous (IV) treatments of emulsion containing medium-chain and omega-3 (n-3) triglycerides enriched in eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in targeting rapid n-3 fatty acid membrane enrichment as a new therapeutic approach to ameliorate adverse inflammatory responses. The planned experiments in cells and animal models will establish innovative methods that are adaptable for targeted, rapid delivery of oil-like therapeutic agents to specific cells or tissues, which will be significant to many fields, including immune responses to infection and inflammation-related tissue injury and organ dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Preconception carrier screening is a proven, evidence-based genetic screening approach that has the potential to prevent pregnancies affected by severe recessive genetic conditions, but widespread and equitable implementation of this testing has not been achieved. The proposed research program will evaluate diverse stakeholders’ preferences for how preconception carrier screening could be performed and the personal health implications of carrier screening. This program has the potential to inform implementation efforts to expand access to preconception carrier screening among diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a disease that affects more than one-third of the U.S. adult population, resulting in 300,000 deaths per year, and is highly associated with cardiovascular disease and intestinal inflammation. However, our knowledge about the pathways linking obesity to heart and intestinal disease manifestations is incomplete. This application will elucidate how obesogenic high-fat diet mediated intestinal changes increase the risk for atherosclerosis, which will provide critical new insights into the contribution of host-associated microbial communities to health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project will identify and characterize genetic variants leading to suicide risk in a resource of DNA from >10,000 suicides. Variants are identified from state-of-the-art whole genome sequence data in cases selected for enhanced genetic risk using unique genealogical data and young age at death. Suicides with identified risk variants will be further characterized using demographic data, diagnostic and medication data, autopsy data, familial risk, and polygenic background.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Reference cigar tobacco products are a necessary tool for measuring and reporting harmful and potentially harmful constituents in tobacco products as required under the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act. Three new, machine-made, sheet-wrapped, certified cigar reference products representative of large cigars (processed leaf filler, non-premium), little cigars (brown cigarettes) and small cigars (cigarillos) will be manufactured in one manufacturing run each to ensure product uniformity, and will have certified characteristics to allow for a proficiency testing program, instrument calibration, employee/student training, method validation and for investigational purposes. The University of Kentucky Center for Tobacco Reference Products (CTRP) will expand our program for tobacco analysis and reference tobacco products to support collaborative studies, improved constituent analysis, storage and stability research and the manufacture and distribution of cigar tobacco reference products with significant proposed improvements and development in all of these areas.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cigar Reference Products Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Since our discovery of Fic domains that mediate AMPylation, other diverse activities performed by bacterial Fic domains have been identified. In metazoans, Fic regulates by reversible AMPylation another protein called BiP(GRP78), which is an essential chaperone found in the endoplasmic reticulum that helps to maintain homeostasis in healthy cells. Our goal is to understand how Fic's activity is regulated, why it has been conserved in mammals and what other chemistries are used by orphan Fic domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The Strategies to Innovate Emergency Care Clinical Trials Network (SIREN) is an international multicenter clinical trials network. SIREN physicians and researchers study what treatments work best for patients with emergency conditions or injuries. Emergencies may involve heart, lung, or blood conditions, problems or injuries involving the brain or spinal cord, seizures, coma, or other traumatic injuries. The SIREN will study patients in ambulances and emergency departments, and the earliest stages of critical care, because many promising treatments may only work well if they are given very quickly after the onset of symptoms or injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Cytomegalovirus disease is a major opportunistic infection in immunosuppressed hosts. Characterizing the viral mutations that confer resistance to existing and new antiviral drugs is important in the genotypic diagnosis of resistance, cross-resistance and the selection of alternate therapy. Detailed understanding of the genetic mechanisms of resistance will inform the development of additional candidate drugs and antiviral targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efforts towards understanding how SARS-CoV-2 causes lung disease have been hampered by a lack of studies in novel circulating variants and a lack of relevant human lung models. The proposed studies will use a panel of primary viral variants and advanced single-cell analyses to study the early interferon response in novel lung organoid and slice cultures. Successful completion of this project will reveal mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2 pathogenesis and launch my career in the study of the host response to acute respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mapping the interactions between stress-inducible bacterial small RNAs and their mRNA partners will provide novel insights into regulatory networks. We propose to elucidate how small RNA regulators control target mRNAs to achieve precise control of complex physiological traits, including virulence. Systematic and quantitative analyses of a variety of small RNAs will expand our understanding of regulatory networks in bacteria, which may stimulate development of new therapeutic strategies for combating pathogens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Having previously demonstrated that a 10-week therapeutic horseback riding (THR) intervention produces significant medium effect size improvements in irritability, hyperactivity, social communication, social cognition, and word fluency in youth with ASD compared to controls, the current proposal will: (1) examine putative physiological mediators hypothesized to contribute to these as well as expanded outcomes; (2) evaluate the six-month durability of outcomes compared to controls; and (3) explore dose and sub-population effects of the intervention. We target a more impaired majority ASD subpopulation, youth ages 6-16 yrs. with psychiatric diagnoses, who may be more likely to benefit from THR given preliminary evidence of stronger positive outcomes of THR in this subgroup. We have demonstrated the feasibility of collecting ambulatory physiological data during THR in the target population, and now seek to determine if THR is a viable adjunctive intervention able to improve biologically measurable arousal states and associated outcomes (i.e., irritability, hyperactivity, social, communication, emotion regulation and caregiver quality of life) for the majority ASD population, those with co-occurring psychiatric diagnoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Permanent hearing loss caused by malformation of the inner ear or congenital or progressive loss of its sensory or neural cells affects up to one third of individuals by the age of 80 and generates significant social and healthcare costs. In this proposal, we use mouse models to investigate the role of the Fibroblast Growth Factor signaling pathway in forming the inner ear epithelium and neurons. Our results will contribute new knowledge to the long-term goal of harnessing developmental signals to drive hearing restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  The goal of the proposed research is to use a novel combination of imaging, artiﬁcial intelligence, elec- troanatomical mapping, and mechanistic computational modeling to characterize atrial remodeling and under- stand the causes for atrial ﬁbrillation recurrence in rhythm-controlled patients. Successful execution of the project will pave the way for a paradigm shift in the clinical procedure of atrial ﬁbrillation ablation and in the quest to eliminate repeat procedures, resulting in a dramatic improvement in the efﬁcacy of the therapy. The project will culminate in a pilot prospective patient study that will test the new ablation strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This program will increase the number of diverse students who enter top PhD graduate programs nationwide, tapping a major underrepresented pool of scientific talent essential for American innovation in basic biomedical research, biotechnology and pharmaceutics. Each year seven college graduates from groups under- represented in science (underrepresented minority or disability) will be competitively selected for a year of intensive basic biomedical research training in a Johns Hopkins laboratory, monthly scientific communication skill-building interactions with dedicated peer-mentors, monthly custom mentoring by the program director, and tri-yearly `mini-thesis' discussions with their chosen teams of scientifically-expert faculty advisors, in addition to ethics training and writing/peer-editing workshops to achieve long-term success in PhD or MD/PhD careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Vitamin E is an essential nutrient that is required for the integrity of cells, especially those of the nervous system. TTP is a protein expressed in the liver and the brain that regulates the levels and distribution of vitamin E in the body. We propose to study new, previously-undescribed functions of vitamin E and TTP and how they offer protection from disease. Upon the successful completion of the proposed studies, we will have resolved fundamental enigmas regarding the biology of vitamin E and TTP. These findings stand to influence a paradigm shift, likely to have profound impact on our understanding and treatments of relevant disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disturbances are pervasive and impairing among children in foster care but not a single prevention or intervention program for this fragile group targets sleep health. Poor sleep undermines effective self-regulation and stable biological rhythms, amplifying the negative impacts of early adversity/trauma on children's acute and long-term functioning. Consistent with evidence that optimizing sleep is critical for trauma recovery, we will adapt cognitive-behavioral treatment for pediatric insomnia, an efficacious intervention for various clinical and non-clinical child populations, for home-based delivery among children recently placed in a new foster home and evaluate initial efficacy, feasibility and target engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Bacillus cereus, a spore-forming, gram-positive bacterium, is a human pathogen commonly associated with hospital infections, foodborne outbreaks, and deaths. These serious health effects are mediated, in part, by a toxin produced by the bacteria. Here, we propose to identify how this toxin targets cells by discovering the heretofore-unknown cell surface receptor for the toxins. This work describes a new unbiased approach to study pore-forming toxins, potentially identifying common mechanisms used by other pathogenic bacteria, as well as providing a strategy to develop new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In cells, proteins condense to form dynamic, functional, liquid-like membraneless compartments, especially during times of stress. The regulation of how these compartments are assembled, disassembled, and maintain liquidity is not well-understood. In this proposal, we will determine how UBQLN2 and its interactions with other members of the protein quality control system contribute to regulation of membraneless compartments, and how dysregulation leads to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) are at high risk of developing Type 2 diabetes. We are proposing a randomized controlled trial evaluating shared decision making for diabetes prevention among overweight/obese women with a history of GDM and hemoglobin A1c between 5.7-6.4%. The primary study outcome is loss of >5% of body weight, and secondary study outcomes include uptake of behavior change, use of metformin, and increased follow-up screening for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This study is aimed at increasing our understanding of etiological factors associated with the most frequently occurring anxiety symptoms/disorders. Developmental shifts in fearful reactivity and the underlying neurophysiology will be examined via an intensive longitudinal design, elucidating change-related effects contributing to emergence of anxiety, and the influence of maternal sensitivity on these effects. Most salient predictors of early anxiety symptoms represent targets for preventative efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This research proposal responds to the challenge of improving scientific understanding of the cellular processes that lead to diabetes complications. Our objective is to demonstrate that a cause in diabetes complications that has been overlooked by diabetes researchers is intracellular 3-deoxyglucosone, a toxic metabolite generated by the fructosamine-3-kinase (FN3K) enzyme pathway. The project also aims to identify a selective and potent inhibitor of the FN3K pathway for further drug development as a new treatment modality for diabetes complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The proposed project will address critical gaps in current knowledge regarding the experience and management of posttraumatic shame – an emotion consistently implicated in the development, maintenance, and/or worsening of PTSD symptoms among women with a history of sexual or physical assault or abuse (i.e., interpersonal trauma). Existing treatments for PTSD often fail to fully address posttraumatic shame, and untreated shame represents an ongoing risk factor for the development or worsening of PTSD symptoms. Findings from this study hold promise for improving treatment efforts for shame and PTSD by clarifying aspects of how women experience and manage shame after interpersonal trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The myelin sheath is a crucial component in maintaining proper neuronal communication in the brain. The degeneration and failure to remove the myelin sheath is a common pathology that occurs in many neurodegenerative diseases however it is unclear how this clearance process fails. This proposal will investigate the dynamics in which microglia respond to myelin debris and how failure to remove it inhibits the remyelination process, providing insight into why this repair process fails in late stages of disease and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with an alcohol use disorder are more likely to exhibit other psychiatric or medical disorders, complicating access to, and the effectiveness of, different treatments. This proposal will investigate the genetic contribution of alcohol use disorder to risk of other disorders by studying an ethnically diverse sample, and integrating additional information from biological pathways and environmental measures to provide insight into the etiologic pathways underlying these disorders. The proposed project will provide a foundation for future studies that would allow stratification of individuals into personalized treatment programs based on their disease etiology, along with the promise of early identification of at-risk individuals to target with prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Epithelial-mesenchymal crosstalk tightly regulates the balance between cell proliferation and differentiation to sustain the frequent cellular turnover needs of the mammalian small intestine. While mesenchymal cells, particularly fibroblasts, function to support stem cells, fibroblasts have unexpected pathogenic roles that drive uncontrolled epithelial growth in intestinal polyp formation. This project is relevant to public health as it will reveal the underlying fibroblast-driven mechanisms in polyp formation and deepen our foundational knowledge on dysregulated epithelial-fibroblast crosstalk in disease initiation, which could ultimately lead to the identification of novel target cell types in preventing/treating intestinal cancer and other fibroblast-mediating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Trichotillomania severely impairs social, physical and mental well-being. Patient access to evidence-based treatments (EBTs) such as self-monitoring, stimulus control and Habit Reversal Training (HRT) is extremely limited due to a lack of trained providers and patients’ lack of willingness to seek treatment due to shame and privacy. We seek to increase the potency of EBTs and access to EBTs for TTM patients by developing a wearable device and mobile app system that passively detects a patient’s TTM episodes, creating an episode history with additional contextual information, and helps the patient reduce hair pulling with both predictive and real-time EBT reminders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOMA LINDA VETERANS ASSN RESEARCH & EDUC
PHR: Project Narrative The current obesity rate of 39 percent is anticipated to climb to 55 percent by year 2045 in the United States. Since obesity is becoming a prevalent and destructive health disorder linked to some of the leading causes of preventable death including type 2 diabetes (T2DM) and osteoporosis, there is an urgent need to understand the molecular pathways driving the pathogenesis of obesity-related disorders such as T2DM and osteoporosis. Based on our novel discovery that disruption of Kinase Suppressor of Ras (Ksr) 2, a gene recently implicated in obesity and T2DM, leads to a dramatic increase in trabecular bone mass, our proposed efforts in this grant application will delineate the mechanisms by which this obesity gene regulates the skeletal phenotype. The long-term goal of this proposal is to identify novel therapeutic approaches for prevention and treatment of fractures in obesity/T2DM-related conditions, thereby reducing the burden of these chronic diseases both on individuals and on society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Expedient access to new treatments for human disease is predicated on synthetic strategies that can access diverse families of organic compounds for evaluation. This proposal comprises a method for the controlled editing of carbon-hydrogen bonds within compounds that have the potential for treating human diseases, relying specifically on the aspects of their structure that typically present challenges for existing methods. Utilizing newly designed catalysts and reagents, modification can be targeted to particular carbon- hydrogen bonds, and numerous new functional groups can be introduced from a single precursor.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Aging muscle exhibits significant deficits in repair capacity. While exposure to a young systemic environment is shown to rejuvenate muscle regenerative capacity, reliable identification of these humoral youthful factors responsible for this effect remains challenging. The proposed work will provide an innovative approach to develop a biomimetic model system for more accurate and cost-effective identification of anti-aging factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE) Increasing clinical evidence suggests an association between bone metabolism and age-associated vascular events, particularly cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases. Our goal is to identify skeleton-derived factors that accelerate vascular aging through blood circulation. With this work we hope to develop unconventional but promising paths for the treatment of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.

PHR: Narrative The Tufts Post Baccalaureate Research Education Program (PREP) prepares recent college graduates who are members of underrepresented groups with the tools to enter into highly ranked biomedical PhD or MD/PhD programs, succeed and go on to join the next generation of scientific leaders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Overall NARRATIVE. Women are at twice the risk of the co-occurrence of depression and autonomic dysregulation, which is associated with a 3-5-fold risk of death from heart disease later in life, often with unrecognized and untreated depression. This SCORE will conduct a set of basic science and clinical studies that are synergistic for understanding the risk for sex differences in depression and associated health outcomes over the lifespan. We will identify pathways that will lead to translation into sex-selective therapeutics and will train the next generation to incorporate knowledge of sex differences into how we think about and treat disorders of the brain and their impact on general medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: LAC Narrative The goals of the proposed SCORE are to identify stress-immune pathway abnormalities beginning in fetal development that impact key stress-related neural circuits resulting in shared consequences for sex differences in lifelong depression and autonomic and other physiologic dysregulation. Our SCORE proposes a set of synergistic basic and clinical studies in tandem with cores to share technological expertise and enhance the training of the next generation. The LAC will oversee responsibility for: maintaining connections between sites and studies, setting up meetings and conference calls to review study progress, budget administration, organizing symposia and conferences, publicizing opportunities for trainees, supporting new initiatives, and implementing dissemination of the knowledge gained to the scientific and medical communities, policy makers, and the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our findings have the potential to describe the neural computations that form the basis for amotivation, a known transdiagnostic factor across several psychiatric and neurological disorders, including depression and schizophrenia. This research can therefore enable endophenotypic assessment of risk for these disorders and severity of motivational impairments in subclinical populations, providing a potential biomarker to aid in diagnosis and treatment outcome research, and facilitating development of and tests of efficacy for therapies aimed at reducing these impairments. This work carries promising future directions for studying motivational impairments in depression, schizophrenia, Alzheimer’s, and Parkinson’s, and to improve well-being and increase productivity in the general population.

PHR: The proposed Career Enhancement Core (CEC) will train the next generation of scientists in sex differences research as relevant to major depression. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extreme reactivity to sensory stimuli, or Sensory Over-Responsivity (SOR), is present in 50-70% of children across varied neurodevelopmental disorders, but SOR is not well understood and is rarely treated despite being associated with substantial clinical impairment. This project will integrate behavioral, fMRI, and GABA spectroscopy methods in a combined cross-sectional/longitudinal design to identify individual differences in the development of SOR and sensory regulation in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD). The study will also take a proof-of-mechanism approach to examine the ability of two emotion regulation strategies to engage neural sensory regulation regions, which, taken together with the longitudinal results, will directly translate to personalized and age-appropriate interventions for SOR in youth with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Resource Support Core (RSC) Core will provide technical support to synthesize and integrate neuroimaging, neuromodulation and physiological methods and analyses across the SCORE Projects. By providing a common image, physiological and experimental data acquisition and analysis framework, the RSC Core will facilitate the ability to perform intra- and inter-project analyses as well as larger-scale analyses. This will integrate not only the SCORE work, but other related NIH-funded studies at the institutions, allowing us to address on a still broader scale questions about sex difference in the neurobiology of MDD and the discovery work for the implementation of a novel, non-invasive therapeutic intervention. Thus, the RSC will increase the value of such data to the broader community when shared according to our Resource Sharing Plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Improving Brain Organoid Models by Mediating Metabolic Dysregulation Project Narrative Without accurate models of the human brain, we cannot understand the mechanisms guiding the formation and function of the diversity of human cells and circuits. Brain organoids are a promising model system, but they currently lack appropriate cell type specification and maturation due to high levels of metabolic stress. The proposed studies will use a data-driven approach to target metabolic defects and improve appropriate cell specificity for the more accurate study of human neuroscience.

Women are at twice the risk of the co-occurrence of MDD and autonomic dysregulation, that is associated with a 3-5-fold risk of death from heart disease, often with unrecognized and untreated MDD. This study will investigate fetal stress-immune antecedents to sex differences in adult MDD, mood circuitry in brain, and associated impact on centrally driven cardiac physiology in early midlife. Identifying early biomarkers for the co-occurrence of MDD, autonomic dysregulation and frank heart disease later in life will provide knowledge to intervene earlier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project 2 Narrative: Project 2 will begin to identify the sex-dependent impact of expiratory-gated transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation (etVNS) on the modulation of the stress response circuitry and associated physiology in major depressive disorder (MDD). We will evaluate a sample of 80 adults with recurrent MDD unmedicated (ages 51- 64, equally divided by sex) randomized to receive active or sham expiratory-gated tVNS during a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) session of a mild visual stress challenge designed to elicit a sympatho- excitatory state, with simultaneous mood and physiological assessments of steroid hormones and dynamic cardiovagal heart rate variability. We hypothesize that etVNS will effectively modulate, in a sex-dependent manner, specific brainstem-cortical pathways of the stress circuitry and attenuate physiological deficits in MDD. Results will contribute to future development of etVNS as a novel non-pharmacologic therapeutic for MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will identify the cellular and physiological neural pathways whereby prenatal overexposure to the stress hormone, glucocorticoids, cause long-term, sex-selective changes in adult anxiety- and depressive-like behaviors, hormonal and autonomic nervous system responses to stress. Developmental programming is the permanent adaptation of the fetus to changing environmental signals in utero. These studies will identify the brain circuitry underlying the sex-biased developmental programming of behavioral, endocrine and autonomic responses in adulthood and address potential therapeutic mechanisms and approaches whereby these changes can be ameliorated in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The major cell types of many of our internal organs, including the thyroid, thymus, lung, stomach, liver, pancreas, intestine and bladder arise from a common embryonic tissue called the gut endoderm. A rigorous understanding of how the gut endoderm normally forms, including knowledge of the origin of its resident cell populations, how these cell types are generated during embryonic development, and how they are diversified to form individual organs with distinct characteristics, will underpin logical efforts to understand the manifestation and progression of diseases in these vital internal organs, tissue regeneration potential and repair, as well as the progression and design new therapeutic strategies. The broad aim of this project is to use a combination of state-of-the-art embryological, genetic, single-cell genomic and imaging techniques to determine the origin and fate of the embryonic gut endoderm, and to investigate the cell behaviors driving its formation in the embryo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Muscle stem cell exhaustion is one of the hallmarks of aging and leads to gradual impairment of tissue structure and function. Aged stem cells exhibit a decline in resilience, manifested as a reduced resistance to extrinsic and intrinsic stresses, rendering them more susceptible than young stem cells to processes leading to cell death. The main focus of the studies of this proposal is to explore the mechanisms that promote stem cell resilience, how those mechanisms decline with age, and interventions that may promote stem cell resilience in older individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In vitro assays suggest that Vitamin A derivative, retinoic acid, regulates numerous metabolic genes which undergo profound changes in expression levels during metabolic transitions such as adaptation to starvation, or in response to insufficient insulin signaling in type I diabetes. However, remarkably little is known about the fate of vitamin A metabolism and retinoic acid levels during such transitions. Based on our preliminary data, we propose to test a hypothesis that the rate of retinoic acid biosynthesis is carefully adjusted during metabolic transitions to enable proper remodeling of hepatic energy metabolism, while in type 1 diabetes this mechanism fails thereby exacerbating the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pneumonia and other acute inflammatory diseases of the lungs, such as the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), result in damage to the alveolar epithelium and endothelium. Alveolar macrophages are critical orchestrators of alveolar repair, however the mechanisms that underpin their function remain largely unknown. The objective of this proposal is to create a Program that will determine the factors that regulate macrophage function and determine how macrophage subsets contribute to lung repair. Achieving the goals of this proposal will enhance our understanding of lung repair and pave the way for new strategies to hasten recovery from lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Puerto Rico faces frequent power outages due to the damage caused by natural disasters to its electric grid, which can in turn negatively affect the aging population (≥50 years) who are more likely to have multiple chronic health conditions. Research has demonstrated that access to energy independence through direct access to solar power can have positive health impacts on the population. We propose to explore, from a multilevel perspective, the perceived barriers and facilitators for adopting energy independence as described by individuals, communities, and policy makers, while also documenting resilience related variables that can explain effective chronic disease management among aging populations in need of electricity-based therapeutic treatments (i.e., renal disease, respiratory diseases, diabetes).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Vitamin B1 is indispensable for normal human health due to its involvement in oxidative energy metabolism/ATP production, reduction of oxidative stress, and mitochondrial function. Its deficiency occurs in conditions like IBD, sepsis and chronic alcoholism. Humans obtain the vitamin from exogenous sources (i. e., diet, and the gut microbiota). Our objectives are to understand the physiology/cell biology of vitamin B1 uptake along the intestinal tract and how pathophysiological conditions/factors affect the process. Results should assist in the designing of effective strategies to optimize vitamin B1 nutrition, and thus, improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to Particulate Matter (PM) metals during pregnancy is known to be harmful to both mother and the new born. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is one such harmful effect of exposure to PM metals. In the natural environment we are always exposed to mixtures of chemicals with different toxicities. Unfortunately, methods of identifying those mixtures are limited. In this K01 application, we are proposing a novel method of pollutant mixtures identification and we will investigate their association with CVD risk factors.
