IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a need for rapid, accurate and sensitive assays or diagnostic platforms that can confirm exposure and predict acute and delayed radiation injury to different organs and tissues. While metabolomics has been proven effective in identifying biomarkers of acute radiation injury, there is a paucity of studies focused on circulating biomarkers that predict the development of organ-specific or delayed radiation injuries. This project aims to identify metabolic biomarkers of radiation injury to three major organs at risk: kidney, heart, and brain following exposure to low- and high-linear energy transfer radiation, and develop a kit-based assay for assessing and predicting injury in these organ systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance. The number of cancer survivors is steadily increasing; for example, in 2019 an estimated 16.9 million individuals in the United States alone were considered cancer survivors. With this positive upward trend in survivorship, the long-term lung toxicity of radiation therapy gains importance. To address this critical need, we propose a simple, sensitive, and low-dose imaging tool that utilizes a single x-ray projection to detect the early onset of radiation- induced lung fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric high-grade gliomas (pHGGs) are one of the most common and aggressive forms of brain cancer, with a median survival of 9-15 months. We aim to study a subtype of pHGG which harbors H3.3-G34R, ATRX and TP53 inactivating mutations. Our goal is to assess the molecular mechanisms by which H3.3-G34R impacts the biology of pHGGs, influence the tumor immune microenvironment and the response to therapeutics, including immune-mediated mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE A substantial barrier to improved treatment for sepsis is lack of in-depth knowledge of endogenous factors that modulate production of the cytokines that drive morbidity and mortality. We have identified mammalian IRGM proteins as novel inhibitors of inflammatory cytokine production. This proposal will define the mechanisms through which these proteins protect against sepsis-induced inflammation and sepsis-related mortality, enabling the development of novel therapeutics and/or diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Patient enrollment is a key determinant of the success of National Cancer Institute (NCI)-sponsored clinical trials. Clinician scientist, Stephen Chun, M.D. at The University of Texas, M.D. Anderson Cancer (MDACC), established the NCI-sponsored radiation clinical trial program in MDACC’s Houston Area Location (HAL) integrated academic satellite campuses which has led to unprecedented increases in enrollments from economically and ethnically diverse populations. With the NCI cooperative groups, Dr. Chun serves in leadership roles that support trial analysis, concept development, and patient enrollment, and this NCI R50 funding mechanism will enable Dr. Chun to expand NCI-sponsored enrollments in the MDACC HALs and his leadership efforts with the NCI cooperative groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of our study is to investigate mitochondrial dysfunction modulated by neurotransmitter serotonin and protective role of SSRI in depression, diabetes, and dementia (3Ds). Our study will be conducted using three transgenic mouse models and three cell models representing 3Ds pathology and representing 3 major brain areas. The outcomes of this research will provide information on whether citalopram confers protective effects comorbid effect on depression, diabetes and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a leading cause of heart failure and death, and there is an urgent need to identify new molecular targets that could lead to the development of more effective treatment strategies. Our research is focused on a protein called ATF4, which acts as a switch that turns on genes essential for cardiac muscle function. By studying how ATF4 works, we hope to understand how mutations case DCM and identify new ways to treat patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Energy metabolism is central to virtually all cells in the body, and metabolic reprogramming, a fundamental alteration of tissue metabolism supporting the rapid growth of cancer cells, is particularly pronounced in glioma and other brain tumors. From a therapeutic perspective, this alteration of normal processes provides an opportunity for highly novel therapies which aim to reverse these abnormal metabolic processes is the goal. This projects seeks to develop an innovative approach for the non-invasive imaging of brain tumor metabolism using MRI of deuterated glucose in order to provide a powerful new tool for improved diagnostics, therapy planning, and assessment of treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease is a chronic illness that represents a significant public health and economic burden, and there is an urgent need to improve our understanding of modulators of intestinal inflammation in order to identify novel therapeutic targets. Based on our recent findings that specific diet-induced microbial metabolites trigger pathologic activation of the group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) and associated type 2 inflammation, the focus of this proposal is to dissect the role of this diet-microbiota axis in the regulation of intestinal inflammation.

PHR: Project Narrative Salt sensitivity of blood pressure, with or without hypertension, is associated with increased cardiovascular risk and overall mortality; reduction in NaCl consumption is a treatment of salt sensitivity. However, decreasing salt intake in some may actually increase the increased risk for hypertension, and cardiovascular and renal diseases and death. Identifying genes that cause salt sensitivity and, in this proposal, inverse salt sensitivity would be a step towards precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to evaluate the long-term efficacy of a Plasticity-based Adaptive Cognitive Remediation program (PACR-CT v.2.0) for the prevention of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This proposal aims to examine the longer-term benefits of a novel, neuroplasticity-based, computerized & web-deliverable training program suite five years from the initial 10 weeks of training and test the interactive effect of previous training and 10 weeks of booster training. These outcomes will provide deeper understanding of the neurobehavioral status of a study population 5-years after the initial 10 weeks of program completion and of the benefit of the booster training and its interaction with prior-training. Based on the results of our study, the optimal training schedule to sustain and potentially further-grow program-delivered benefits will be implemented.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE The sodium-dependent citrate transporter NaCT plays a key role in fatty acid biosynthesis. In this multi-PI R01, we will combine structural (cryo-EM), dynamic (single molecule FRET and molecular dynamics simulations) and kinetic (transport and binding assays) techniques to understand the transport mechanism of NaCT and its bacterial homolog VcINDY. The information obtained will help in understanding the molecular pathogenesis of various metabolic diseases such as diabetes, obesity and cancer, and may aid in the development of potential treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative In the kidney, NaCl transport depends in part on the renal transporter NKCC2, an apical Na+/K+/2Cl- co- transporter the thick ascending limb (TAL) of the loop of Henle. The molecular mechanisms that control apical membrane NKCC2 levels involve endocytosis, recycling and exocytic insertion. We found 2 proteins (ALMS1 and ACTN4), that cause human diseases associated with kidney damage, high blood pressure and abnormal renal physiology, that interact with NKCC2. We will study the biological mechanisms by which ALMS1 and ACTN4 maintain normal renal function and NaCl transport, and how dysfunction occurs when they are absent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The federal agencies and professional organizations have mounted a significant effort to address an increasingly recognized public health problem, Early Childhood Caries (ECC), among the underserved population. A better understanding of the biological factors related to this pediatric oral health disparity is urgently needed.  Leveraging an archived underserved birth cohort, our multidisciplinary team proposes using cutting- edge metagenomic sequencing and analysis tool, combined with a high-dimensional statistical machine learning approach, to examine the early-life oral microbiome development and identify its multilevel determinant and association to ECC. ECC risk factors revealed via prediction models could be used as targets for ECC early prediction and prevention specifically suitable for underserved racial minority children.

PHR: Obesity and obesity-related diseases have become one of the greatest threats to human health and a tremendous financial burden for individuals and societies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. The goal of this project is to develop a new image-correlated genomic technology that will improve the detection and characterization of genetic disease susceptibility, response to environmental factors, and help develop potential treatment regimens that arise based on knowledge gained from use of the technology. The method combines high resolution optical microscopy with DNA sequencing to allow researchers to obtain specific DNA sequence information from targeted nuclear regions in user-selected cells in the population under study. The technology will offer new insights into how genes are regulated by the environment and how the cell’s nucleus structurally reconfigures itself in response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-acquired pneumonia is the most common serious pediatric infection and a leading cause of hospitalization for children in the United States, yet wide variation in care and limitations of current management approaches suggest that evidence-based tools are necessary to improve clinical decision- making. This proposal will improve health outcomes for children with pneumonia by developing and broadly validating a risk prediction rule that will make care safer and more effective by minimizing hospitalization and resource use in children who are at low risk of severe disease, while targeting more intensive management to those at higher risk to prevent progression to severe outcomes. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the strategic objectives of NHLBI to develop novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to prevent, treat, and cure lung diseases and to optimize clinical and implementation research to improve health and reduce disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US health care system leads the world in administrative complexity and its associated costs. Cancer is a complex and often high-acuity condition with persistent disparities in health outcomes, making cancer care delivery a priority setting for assessing patient administrative burdens and identifying solutions. The proposed research uses qualitative, survey, and claims data in a sequential mixed methods analysis that will enable the measurement and diagnosis of administrative burden across cancer care settings and produce evidence identifying and motivating actionable organizational or policy targets for clinical leaders and policymakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Only ~22% of the human protein coding genes have been found to have a phenotype‐causing variant, the molecular basis of at least 3,298 phenotypes is not known, and many more Mendelian phenotypes have not yet been described. These data together with the fact that the vast majority of the disease‐causing variants investigated up to now are single‐nucleotide variants in the coding region suggests that there is a long way to go if we are to identify the molecular basis of every Mendelian phenotype, the details of the phenotypes, and the origins of the associated phenotypic variability (Sobreira and Valle, 2016). Enhancing genomic and phenotypic data sharing including better partnership with the patients will be fundamental to the discovery of the disease genes, the understanding of the diseases' mechanisms and development of treatments; since, this project focused on genomic and phenotypic data sharing will have broadly beneficial consequences for genetics and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Limited evidence suggests that depression, anxiety and cognitive impairment often cluster in older adults with atrial fibrillation (i.e., psychiatric multimorbidity) and may have a multiplicative negative effect on health outcomes such as poorer oral anticoagulant medication adherence and health-related quality of life. This K01 project will explore: (1) the prevalence of specific dyad and triad combinations of psychiatric multimorbidity; (2) how psychiatric multimorbidity affects oral anticoagulant use and outcomes; and (3) factors that influence successful anticoagulation in patients with psychiatric multimorbidity. Understanding the impact of psychiatric multimorbidity on oral anticoagulant use and success and understanding factors that influence success will help identify useful targets for intervention to ultimately improve the health of atrial fibrillation patients with psychiatric multimorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative One of the most common and serious auditory complaints is difficulty understanding speech in complex environments containing multiple sound sources and reflections. Many millions of people have difficulty in such environments, especially older people and those with hearing loss. The long-term goal of our work is to understand the binaural and spatial hearing mechanisms through which listeners can succeed in these complex auditory environments, leading, ultimately, to better evidence-based treatment approaches for individuals suffering from hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Surgical re-attachment of torn tendons to their bony insertions is a clinically significant problem, especially in the shoulder and knee (e.g., current failure rates after rotator cuff repair range from 20% to 94%, depending on the patient population). This research will define the critical developmental events that lead to a robust tendon- to-bone attachment and explore their role during healing. Results will lead to enhanced tendon-to-bone healing and subsequently in improvements in the health and quality-of-life of individuals afflicted with rotator cuff and anterior cruciate ligament injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neoglycosylation epitopes have been widely used to aid in the diagnosis as well as the management of metaplasia and cancers; however, the function of these epitopes is unknown. Here, we begin to study how these epitopes orchestrate the metaplastic and oncogenic transformations in foregut metaplasias and cancer using in vitro cell and organoid culture as well as murine models. Specifically, we focus on the transition from sialylation to sulfated epitopes, which has been associated with increased likelihood of progressing to gastric cancer by numerous groups over the past several decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The evidence that physical exercise reduces falls in older adults with cognitive impairment is currently both limited and inconclusive, making it difficult for recommending best practices. The proposed study is intended to fill this gap. The primary objective of this project is to determine the efficacy of the therapeutically tailored, cognitively enhanced, dual-task Tai Ji Quan: Moving for Better Balance intervention in reducing the incidence of falls among older adults with mild cognitive impairment, a population that is at an increased risk of falling and increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias. Because the problem of falls is directly relevant to the growing aging population in the United States, our project has the potential to have broad societal impact by ameliorating risk of falls in older Americans with cognitive impairment, improving their physical and cognitive health, and lessening the health care burden due to falls and falls injuries and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulation of stem cell functions is crucial for tissue formation, growth, and homeostasis in adult organisms. Our study seeks to investigate how the transition of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) into transit amplifying cells (TACs) is regulated in the continuously growing adult mouse incisor in support of tissue homeostasis. Ultimately, this study will reveal how the trigeminal nerve serves as a niche environment for MSCs and elucidate the signaling network that regulates the interactions between MSCs and TACs in maintaining tissue homeostasis, which may lead to new strategies for stem cell-mediated tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to elucidate the changes in white matter microstructure that signal the shift from healthy to pathological brain aging using advanced diffusion MRI methods. Expected outcomes from this study include clinically feasible MRI biomarkers with which to empirically test a proposed conceptual model of white matter- related changes in aging and AD, thereby providing translational support for trials of myelin/glia-focused therapies which are grossly underexplored for asymptomatic AD. Thus, this study is poised to have an impact on the evolving conceptualization of how aging leads to AD and, critically, how this can be prevented or treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Chronic environmental exposure to the heavy metal manganese (Mn) through occupational and industrial sources causes motor and not-motor neurological deficits, culminating in metal-induced Parkinsonism. Even though it is well known that Mn neurotoxicity primarily affects the globus pallidus and striatum regions, the molecular mechanisms underlying the metal-induced differential neuronal vulnerability and olfactory alterations are not well understood. In this proposal, we intend to characterize the role of a compensatory signaling pathway mediated by the neuropeptide prokineticin 2 in Mn-induced olfactory alterations and basal ganglia neurotoxicity and to further evaluate the translational neuroprotective efficacy of activating this signaling pathway using both cell and animal models of Mn neurotoxicity.

PHR: Although multimorbidity affects >36 million older adults in the US, there is a paucity of data to guide medication prescribing by multimorbidity burden. This proposal will leverage high-quality data and innovative methods to evaluate the impact of multimorbidity on modulating the safety and effectiveness of cardiometabolic therapies among older adults. Study findings will help patients, caregivers, and clinicians to make individualized evidence- based treatment decisions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome after allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant is a highly morbid manifestation of chronic graft-versus-host disease which is poorly understood, hampering our ability to intervene effectively. We hypothesize that cumulative burden of symptomatic and asymptomatic respiratory viral infections contributes to the development of BOS and progressive lung dysfunction, leading to poor outcomes. In this proposal we will conduct a multicenter longitudinal prospective study on the association of respiratory viral infection and lung function trajectory in patients at risk for and with a clinical diagnosis of BOS, by utilizing home spirometry, self- collection of viral PCR, and a novel serosurvey (VirScan), to fully characterize the natural history of BOS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain affects up to 100 million people in the United States alone, and extended treatment of pain with opiates is one of the largest contributors to the current opioid crisis. Chemical compounds from the cannabis plant, including cannabidiol (CBD) and several terpenoids, show potential promise in the treatment of chronic pain, but the molecular mechanisms and long-term ramifications of cannabidiol/terpenoid treatment remain unknown. This proposal seeks to test whether long-term co-treatment of CBD and terpenoids is effective in managing chronic pain in experimental models, as well as where and how in the brain the pain-relieving effects of cannabidiol/terpenoids occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant proposes to interrogate the specific role(s) of PHF21B (plant homeodomain finger protein 21B) in neuronal function relevant to social recognition impairment; this is relevant because social cognitive impairments are a central feature of several neurodegenerative, neuropsychiatric, neurodevelopmental (e.g., autism spectrum and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) conditions, and also occur following acute brain damage after traumatic brain injury and stroke. We present new evidence showing that mice with PHF21B deficiency have significant social memory deficits, characterized by significantly increased social novelty index when compared to wild-type animals; therefore, we propose to characterize the role of PHF21B in the hippocampus and to identify its target genes and regulatory mechanisms relevant to social memory. The results from the proposed studies will provide novel insights into the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying epigenetic changes that affect social recognition memory and may facilitate the development of conceptually novel pharmacological targets to address social memory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Recent efforts to understand the mechanisms underlying metabolic disease, revealed microglia as critical mediators of hypothalamic neuronal function in the regulation of both body weight and glucose control. Based on our recent findings, we propose to investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which metabolites produced by the gut microbiota regulate microglial function in the mediobasal hypothalamus. This study will provide novel insights into microbiota-regulated molecular pathways in hypothalamic microglial cells relevant to body weight regulation and metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to define the role of the efferocytic islet macrophages in regulating autoimmune diabetes. We place an emphasis on the efferocytosis process taking place in the pancreatic islets and aim to dissect the associated immunosuppressive elements. The anti-inflammatory effects will be evaluated in the model of autoimmune diabetes, to understand the key mechanisms leading to the protection from this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes mellitus is a leading cause of morbidity in the United States, with diabetes and prediabetes together affecting more than 100 million individuals at an estimated cost of >300 billion dollars per year. Type 1 diabetes is caused by loss of the insulin-producing pancreatic β-cells. The proposed project will identify critical events that contribute to β-cell failure in Type 1 diabetes and therefore identify new targets for therapeutic diabetes interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia are non-neuronal cells in the CNS that can potently affect the function and integrity of neuronal synapses. Here, we will use novel approaches to study whether intracellular organelles called lysosomes can simultaneously regulate multiple microglial attributes that impact synapses, revealing new strategies for targeting these cells to preserve synaptic function throughout the lifespan. This work will determine how regional differences in microglial lysosome function during aging may contribute to regional differences in synapse loss and dysfunction, which are tied to age-related decline in movement and cognition and may increase risk of neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The immune system could recognize and eliminate cancers; however, tumors have the capacity to evade immune elimination by generating immunosuppressive microenvironments. Recently developed immunotherapies for cancer can overcome these tumors’ evasive actions and, in some cases, have led to durable, long-term survival; however these immunotherapies may also result in mild to severe inflammatory reactions and, in some instances, life-threatening autoimmunity. This project will apply new genetic tools to define the molecular mechanisms of these unwanted inflammatory adverse events and may propose approaches that may reduce the incidence and severity of these immune relate adverse events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Takotsubo syndrome (TS) is increasingly recognized in clinical settings and is associated with considerable long-term cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Several important gaps in our knowledge of the pathophysiology of TS limit our ability to effectively treat and prevent this condition. Understanding whether heterogeneity in triggers and stress reactivity may play a role in the pathophysiology and prognosis of TS will provide the rationale for the design and testing of properly targeted interventions to improve prognosis for this important patient group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrotic lung diseases represent a largely intractable set of disorders accompanied by progressive morbidity and mortality. The cytokine TGFβ1 is the master driver of fibrotic disease but likely also deters effective lung regeneration after major injury. This program is directed at identifying and bringing to the clinic pathways to both attenuate fibrosis and concurrently improve lung regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative The Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) study is a longitudinal study of unprecedented size and scope, with the potential to transform understanding of the neurobiology of substance-use risk. However, individuals in this cohort face a unique developmental challenge—entering adolescence during the COVID-19 pandemic. This application leverages recent advances in Bayesian machine learning to carefully delineate neurodevelopmental trajectories of substance use risk with specific consideration of the societal and individual effects of COVID-19 using longitudinal data from ABCD (ages 10-14, N>10,000).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research is to understand the development and maintenance of the colon epithelial layer, which lines the final segment of the human digestive track. Many diseases, ranging from inflammatory bowel disease to colon cancer involve the misregulation of colon differentiation and growth, yet little is known about colon development. Thus, better understanding the requirements for proper regulation will yield new strategies for treating diseases of the colon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Our understanding of mutations in disease genes has advanced remarkably in recent years, but our ability to interpret the effects of mutations in cis-regulatory elements (CREs) that turn genes on and off remains rudimentary. In this proposal we will develop a strategy for the identification of mutations in CREs that may predispose to neuropsychiatric disease. In this way, we will pave the way for better and more precise genetic diagnosis in patients suffering from these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE  Oxidative damage is considered important in aging, in the development of cancer and in many degenerative diseases. Moreover, impairments in cell signaling processes controlling proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis are associated with many disease states. An enhanced understanding of peroxide-scavenging enzymes known as peroxiredoxins (Prxs) and the roles they play in both cell signaling and antioxidant protection will thus have important implications for the prevention of human diseases. Notably, enhanced Prx expression in tumors can impart radation resistance to these cells. In addition, the role of Prxs in protecting human pathogens against killing by the immune system implicates Prxs as targets for the development of new therapeutic agents to combat infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The UW PREP program contributes to enhancing the diversity of the biomedical research community by annually recruiting seven fellows from a pool of recent graduates belonging to groups underrepresented in the biomedical sciences to prepare them for successful application to and graduation from first-rated biomedical pre-doctoral programs. The fellows will engage in a year-long intensive research project and receive professional training in scientific writing, public presentations and scientific communication and in the bioethical conduct of research. All fellows will apply for admission to multiple PhD or MD/PhD programs during their tenure in the program, with the goal that at least 75% of them will be accepted into pre-doctoral program and at least 75% of these will graduate with a doctoral degree, as was accomplished in the first two funding periods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developmental and psychiatric disabilities, including autism, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder, impact the health, functioning, and quality of life of millions of individuals and their families. Genetic causes of these conditions are being discovered at a rapid rate, yet there are many unanswered questions about the wide and variable range of symptoms and outcomes seen in people who have these genetic disorders. We propose a comprehensive and novel strategy to accelerate the detection and description of genetic causes of brain disorders, including the identification of additional factors in a person’s genetic (familial) background that contribute to their risk or resilience for developing mental health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES Spontaneous preterm birth (PTB<37 weeks of gestation) is a major pregnancy complication, and infectious or non-infectious inflammation contribute to over 70% of all PTB and neonatal morbidities. Here we propose to develop, validate, and utilize a disease model of PTB by recreating feto-maternal (F-M) uterine tissues on an organ-on-chip (OOC) device, to test the efficacy of an anti-inflammatory drug delivered via extracellular vesicles in reducing PTB risk by diminishing inflammation. The F-M interface OOC model will recapitulate both the fetal and maternal side of the F-M interface in terms of their structure and functions, the fetal and/or maternal side inflammation models faithfully represent the propagation of inflammation predisposing to PTB, and be used to test whether potential therapeutic molecules suppress inflammation in each layer of the F-M interface.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Built upon our prior project, the objective of this renewal application is to create an enriched DS knowledge base (eDISK) and to develop a translational informatics framework (iDSIK-Mine) with innovative informatics approaches to facility DS research using real-world, multi-site EHR data. This is the first project to develop a translational informatics framework to advance our DS knowledge using multimodal data sources. The successful accomplishment of his project will deliver a novel informatics framework with valuable tools and resources for identifying DS efficacy and safety from multimodal data sources, and enable us to understand how patients (e.g., depression patients) use DS using the real-world EHR data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: The results of the proposed study will begin to elucidate the link between severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) exposure, central and peripheral inflammation in pregnancy, and psychiatric and cognitive sequelae postpartum. We will identify central and peripheral markers of subacute and long-term neuropsychiatric sequelae of SARS- CoV-2. The results of this study will have important implications for mental health in the vulnerable periods of pregnancy and postpartum, and will identify targets for personalized treatment to ameliorate long-term neuropsychiatric sequelae of Coronavirus Disease-19 (COVID-19) and other infections.

PHR: GABAergic dysfunction is strongly associated with autism, schizophrenia and childhood epilepsy. Increasing experimental evidence points towards imbalances between the excitatory and inhibitory circuits in the brain as a prominent component in the etiology of these illnesses. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite four globally approved vaccines, rotavirus remains a significant pathogen of severe diarrhea in children under five, accounting for nearly 130,000 deaths annually. We will use cutting-edge methods to understand how structures of viral components control virus replication and assembly of infectious particles. We expect our studies will provide a roadmap for gaining mechanistic insight into replication and maturation pathways in other viruses and help develop new antiviral strategies to counter rotavirus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) is used by primary care providers and emergency departments to identify patients who are at risk for substance abuse or who require treatment for substance abuse. SBIRT identifies over 10 million patients per year in need of referral to treatment or behavioral modification. However, only about 15-20% of patients follow through with these recommendations. This is a proposal to develop a smartphone based app that is designed to increase adherence to recommendations for referral to treatment and behavioral modification in non-adherent patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to public health: Candida glabrata, an important human fungal pathogen and second leading cause of invasive candidiasis, can infect a wide variety of immunocompromised individuals, represents a significant threat to global public health and commonly shows resistance to antifungal drugs, especially azoles. This application will determine how translational efficiency mechanisms control azole resistance in C. glabrata. Ultimately, this study will provide a better understanding of global translational regulatory circuits and pathways that control C. glabrata drug resistance as well as identify and characterize several key factors important for this process that could potentially serve as targets for the development of novel and more effective antifungal strategies.

PHR: Over the last 10 years, the technology in consumer wearable devices has improved their ability to collect heart rate and movement via accelerometry noninvasively to measure free-living physical activity energy expenditure and sleep. No studies have examined the validity of consumer wearable devices for children ages 5 to 12 years. This project is significant because it will be among the first to establish the use of consumer wearable devices, which have the ability to estimate free-living physical activity energy expenditure and sleep of youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In premature infants and people with specific alterations to immune function, Candida albicans causes infections of the central nervous system (CNS) leading to death or devastating neurodevelopment deficits in surviving patients. Very little is known about the mechanisms by which C. albicans causes CNS disease. Our project aims to use a novel mouse model of C. albicans CNS infection to characterize the transcription factors required to cause CNS disease. This exploratory grant will set the stage for more in-depth studies with the ultimate goal of identifying potential strategies to prevent or better treat these infections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will study a new policy that eliminated bus fare citywide in Kansas City, MO. The policy's impact on bus ridership and associated impacts on physical activity, healthy eating, weight status, and economic barriers to health will be evaluated. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of rural Americans are not sufficiently active to achieve health benefits; social support interventions and civic engagement projects to change the built environment are promising strategies to increase physical activity. We will randomize 16 communities to receive either a group-based walking program or combined group-based walking plus civic engagement program. Working with rural libraries, we will increase their capacity to implement the programs; we will evaluate change in physical activity, cardiovascular fitness, and health outcomes in participants in both programs and conduct an implementation and process evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current proposal seeks to understand why metformin appears to have negative effects on mitochondrial adaptations under certain conditions. The project proposes that how well mitochondria work may dictate a positive or negative outcome during metformin treatment. Understanding these mechanisms will help avoid detrimental outcomes in individuals who take metformin to prolong the healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The ability for Herpes Simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) to productively replicate or establish silent infection in neurons is a poorly understood process that directly influences HSV-1 disease. In this proposal, we characterize HSV-1 replication and cellular transcription using drop-based microfluidic approaches to assess the diversity of replication outcomes with single-cell resolution. These analyses will provide incredible insight into the effect of the cellular environment on the range of HSV-1 replication in neurons and subsequent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE College-age youth do not have easy access to expert referral coordinators to get referrals to appropriate mental health care, due to the stigma of seeing a referral coordinator in-person, long wait times to get an intake appointment in the university counseling center, or limited or no referral counselors available in their higher-education institution. We propose to automate the referral process, focusing on college-age youth, by bridging online assessments and curated, up-to-date mental health provider networks. Our automated online referral platform will use expert-trained machine learning to provide users with personalized referrals for mental health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cefiderocol is a novel siderophore cephalosporin that retains activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a multidrug-resistant pathogen that is a leading cause of healthcare associated infections. This proposal seeks to understand the prevalence of changes in the cefiderocol import pathways in clinical isolates of P. aeruginosa and their association with cefiderocol resistance. It will provide information to guide detection of isolates at risk for resistance in the clinical microbiology laboratory, as well as an understanding of the mechanisms of cefiderocol resistance that emerge at clinically relevant doses of the antibiotic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding what genes and pathways are responsible for the tumor formation in patients with OD and MS (untreatable diseases) and the degree to which they influence the medical outcomes related to cancer formation is expected to allow for more precise diagnosis of these patients and give rise to new types of treatments for patients with OD and MS and for patients with related, more common, non-syndromic forms of cancers such as chondrosarcomas and gliomas. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately protecting health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Prion diseases are rapidly progressive, fatal neurodegenerative disorders caused by prion protein  aggregates spreading through the brain and spinal cord. We will use directed and unbiased  proteomics experiments to determine how prions trigger synaptic dysfunction and neuronal  degeneration in well-characterized, highly reproducible neuronal and animal model systems, as  well as patient samples. We expect that the proposed studies will elucidate the signaling pathways  that drive synapse loss in prion disease, and uncover new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although vancomycin is the most commonly prescribed antibiotic to hospitalized patients in the United States, it unfortunately carries a well-known risk of kidney injury. The proposed research will test whether administration of vancomycin via a continuous infusion, as opposed to more traditional intermittent infusion, is less harmful to the kidneys based on specific measurements of kidney function and injury. If the infusion strategy influences toxicity as we hypothesize, it could mean safer use of this antibiotic for the millions of patients that receive this medication annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the steady rise of patients with liver disease in the United States, the demand for liver transplantation has continued to increase while the supply of organs has remained unchanged creating a pressing need to address this organ scarcity. Stem cell derived hepatocytes are often suggested as an alternative cell source for organ transplants, however, the current inability to derive robust and fully mature hepatocytes limits their clinical and scientific utility. The goal of this proposal is to identify and examine important cellular interactions for directed hepatocyte maturation in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Previous efforts at targeting human voltage-gated sodium channel subtype 1.7 (hNaV1.7) for the treatment of chronic pain have failed due to low therapeutic safety windows from lack of subtype selectivity. Creating peptides selectively targeting hNaV1.7 using a combination of validated computational design strategies is a promising solution. The experiments proposed will allow us to design a library of de novo peptides mimicking Protoxin-II, determine the residues critical for selective hNaV1.7 inhibition, and aid in the methodological and translational development of targeted therapeutics for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Polymerization of the protein actin into helical filaments and branched filament networks powers the directed motility of eukaryotic cells and some pathogenic bacteria. Cofilin and glial maturation factor (GMF) are two members of the actin depolymerization factor homology (ADF-H)-domain protein family that accelerate actin filament network reorganization and turnover through severing and debranching. The proposed studies will determine the structural basis of filament mechanical properties and severing by cofilin, and evaluate how filaments and branched filament networks respond to physical force.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will characterize a novel form of immune defense against RNA virus infection in epithelial cells. By describing how the RIG-I-like receptor DRH-1 activates anti-viral defense in the nematode C. elegans, we may uncover novel forms of cell-intrinsic as well as systemic immune responses driven by epithelial cells. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge about living systems in order to reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the development of effective antiretroviral therapies, HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND) remain prevalent but the underlying causes are complex and still poorly understood. We discovered that amyloid precursor protein (APP) restricts HIV-1 replication in brain-resident immune cells but in evading this restriction, HIV-1 accelerates APP processing into neurotoxic Aβ products. This proposal builds on new preliminary data that begin to reveal the underlying mechanisms of restriction by APP and the neurotoxic consequences of viral evasion strategies, and begins to explore the potential of inhibitors targeting APP processing as multifunctional therapeutics that simultaneously limit HIV-1 replication and neurotoxin production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There are many reasons why individuals afflicted by Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) would benefit from being diagnosed earlier. The goal of this research is to develop computer algorithms from data collected by financial bureaus to identify people who may be at risk for ADRD and who should receive clinical evaluation. Financial data is likely to be an important tool for helping with early diagnosis because people’s financial decisions are typically some of the first things affected by the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The traditional view of the cerebellum as solely a motor control center has been revised in favor of a broader regulatory role, which includes limbic functions. These functions likely depend on the interaction between the cerebellum and key nodes in emotional circuits, such as the amygdala and nucleus accumbens; however, these interactions and their disruption in mental disorders are not understood. The central goal of this proposal is to dissect the connectivity between the cerebellum and the limbic system, using a combination of approaches that span levels of analysis, and to link the connectivity to learned behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Epigenetic alterations are a hallmark of aging and contribute to a variety of age-related diseases including cancer, neurodegeneration, and metabolic disorders. However, specific epigenetic modifications, such as an H3K4me3 deficiency, promote longevity and induce transgenerational benefits. This project will identify novel molecular mechanisms that govern these positive effects on aging and have the potential to be targeted to protect against the rapidly growing public health burden of age-related diseases.
